PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients and calls upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
Any your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Promotion Foundation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned.
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products:
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petitions of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal for or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Deregulation and Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to express their opposition to the privatization and de-regulation of the Australian Telecommunications system and to the proposed implementation of timed local calls and directory assistance charging.
Your petitioners pray that the Australian Government will take the necessary action to prevent any such privatisation, de-regulation, timed local calls, and directory assistance charging.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 58 citizens) and Zakharov (from 120 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its Advisory Committees which propose radical changes to the Constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which give more power to the Government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weaken the role of the Senate.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Durack (from 799 citizens) and Panizza (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We, the petitioners, request the Government to ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Hamer (from 24 citizens) and Patterson (from 12,074 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Childs (from 550 citizens) and Gietzelt (from 30 citizens).

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY INSTITUTE OF TECHNICAL AND FURTHER EDUCATION ORDINANCE 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my notice of intention given yesterday, I now withdraw Business of the Senate, notice of motion No. 1, standing in my name for today for the disallowance of the Australian Capital Territory Institute of Technical and Further Education Ordinance 1987, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 71 of 1987 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910. I seek leave to make a short statement relating to the withdrawal of the notice of motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave notice of my intention to move disallowance of the Australian Capital Territory Institute of Technical and Further Education Ordinance because of my severe reservations about the Government's provisions for the new Technical and Further Education (TAFE) Institute. Representations were made to me on this subject by many TAFE teachers and students, and by the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation. I wrote to the Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, requesting in particular reconsideration of the membership, powers and functions of the proposed advisory committee for the new Institute. The Minister has undertaken in writing to introduce by way of an amending ordinance most of the modifications to the Government's arrangements which I requested and he has promised to table that ordinance by the end of this sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: I compliment the Minister for his willingness to consider my requests in the constructive spirit in which they were made. I believe that the new Institute of Technical and Further Education will be greatly improved by the more independent and more representative advisory committee created by these changes. TAFE teachers, students, administration and the Teachers Federation have expressed satisfaction with the changes. I am further delighted that the Minister has moved quickly and demonstrated his good faith by the early announcement of appointments to the upgraded advisory committee. I look forward to the formalising of these changes when the amending ordinance is tabled shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This matter has been before the Senate previously, when the Liberal Party moved disallowance of the same ordinance. We withdrew that motion after we had contacted the Minister, and the letter that he gave in relation to his undertaking was incorporated in Hansard at that time.

Restoration to Notice Paper

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Order of the Day for the second reading of the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987 be restored to the Notice Paper and be an Order of the Day for the next day of sitting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a Government statement responding to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987 and seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Cash Transaction Reports Bill was referred back to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for examination and report. The Committee tabled its report on 28 April 1988 and the Government is now in a position to respond to the report.

Before proceeding to the report I wish to thank the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for their efforts. The Committee received over 50 submissions and took evidence in Canberra and Sydney. Apart from the members of the Committee I also wish to thank, on behalf of the Government, all parties who lodged submissions and gave evidence before the Committee. The Government believes that its consideration of the Bill has been greatly enhanced by the views put to the Committee.
I now turn to the Committee's recommendations. The principal recommendation is:

That the operation of the Cash Transaction Reports Bill be reviewed after a suitable period of time, preferably not longer than 3 years, and that the review include the economic, taxation, privacy and law enforcement implications of the Bill.

Certainly it is Government policy that all new initiatives should be subject to review to assess their effectiveness and efficiency. As the Committee itself concluded, the scheme of the Cash Transaction Reports Bill is novel and innovative. There is only one precedent for this type of legislation, the Bank Secrecy Act in the United States of America. It will take time for the Cash Transaction Reports Agency to be established and operational. Much work needs to be done to educate the private sector and the public at large on the requirements of the legislation. In order to ensure that there is a reasonable time in which the legislation can prove its worth, and I have no doubt that it will, the Government will require that the operation of the legislation be reviewed and a report tabled in Parliament no later than three years after the coming into force of the cash transaction reporting provisions.

The Committee also recommended that there be certain technical amendments made to the legislation. In addition, the Committee referred to concerns of firms engaged in armoured vehicle cash carrying operations. Because of the special circumstances of such cash carriers, and because these firms maintain records sufficient to enable investigators to follow the money trail, the Government proposes to amend the Bill so as to provide a mechanism to relieve such firms from the obligation to report under clause 7. The Government proposes to move these amendments at the committee stage of the debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1987-88[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1987-88APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1987-88SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1988-89SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1988-89SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1988-89]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 April, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I suggest that it may suit the convenience of the Senate to have a cognate debate covering Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88, Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89.
—Is it the wish of the Senate that that course be followed? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) has just indicated, this morning we are dealing with not merely Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88 but also Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88. Cognately with those three Appropriation Bills we are dealing with Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89. Normally we would debate the Appropriation Bills separately from the Supply Bills, but without wishing to be in any way provocative, I think I would have to say that the mess into which the Government has allowed the business of the Senate to drift over the course of the past month or two has rendered it necessary to bring together the debate on these otherwise quite separate sets of Bills. The Opposition has agreed to their being debated cognately on this occasion because of the impossible legislative program now confronting the Senate. I think I am correct in saying that apart from these six Bills which we are now beginning to debate, there are already another 11 Bills on the Notice Paper-in fact, there are now 12 Bills because the Cash Transaction Reports Bill has been restored to the Notice Paper this morning on the motion of Senator Tate. There is also a whole raft of Bills to come from the lower House, including not least the referendum Bills which are to be debated in the House of Representatives this week and to which we, in this place, shall have to devote a great deal of time in the final two weeks of our own sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: In these Appropriation Bills which I will discuss first, the Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures which are additional to the appropriations for 1987-88 made late last year under the original Appropriation Acts, Nos 1 and 2, and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act (No. 1). These additional appropriations are required to meet commitments which have been approved by the Government since the Budget, as well as requirements, in some cases, of an ongoing nature. As the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) noted in his second reading speech on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3), the principal factors underlying these requirements include certain unavoidable cost and price increases and other parameter changes since the Budget was prepared, in particular, the impact of the national wage case decision and the Australian Public Service office-based second tier pay agreement in the last few months.

Of the additional appropriations in the three additional Appropriation Bills totalling $654.7m, the major amount of $501m is sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 3). It is fair to add that these additional appropriations in these Bills are offset in large part by savings in the appropriations made by Appropriation Act Nos 1 and 2 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1987-88 which have resulted from a further scrutiny of the originally proposed appropriations in some areas since this legislation was first passed by the Parliament.

The Opposition, of course, will not oppose these Bills, but with a view to expressing our concern at the state of the Australian economy, for which the Government's budgetary policies are considerably responsible, we shall move an amendment to the second reading motion for Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and that amendment will now be circulated. I should say in passing that in view of the fact that the Appropriation Bills are being debated cognately with the Supply Bills, we shall not move a separate amendment to the second reading motion on Supply Bill (No. 1) as we otherwise would have done. However, we ask the Senate to treat the proposed amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) as relating also and equally to Supply Bill (No. 1). I now read into the record the nature of the amendment which we will move to the motion for the second reading of the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88:
At the end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate notes:
(a) Australia's $86.77 billion net foreign debt at the end of December 1987 and its continuing balance of payments deficit on the current account which increased by $1185 million during March 1988;
(b) the Government's inappropriate response, which has been to increase taxation revenue collections to the highest levels in post-war Australia; and
(c) the urgent need to reduce public sector outlays as the major element of a Government policy response to our current economic difficulties''.

As a result of the delays in coming finally to debate these Bills, we find ourselves, regarding paragraph (a) of the amendment, with approximately one hour and 10 minutes until we receive the balance of payments figure for April as distinct from the figure for March--

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to rewrite your speech, do you?
—No, I will not be re-writing my speech, Senator; but, as the Duke of Wellington said, it is a damned close run thing. The figure for March is cited in the first paragraph of our amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that many of my Opposition colleagues, and doubtless other senators also, will be discussing in the course of this debate specific aspects-in some cases very specific aspects-of the expenditure programs for which the additional appropriations are now sought. Therefore, I shall concentrate my remarks chiefly on the more general aspects of Australia's budgetary and economic position to which our amendment specifically relates. This Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's post-war history. Despite the now notorious trilogy undertaking of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the 1984 election campaign-namely, that, among other things, the proportion of taxation to our gross domestic product (GDP) would not in future years be increased above its 1984-85 level-we have actually seen further increases in both 1985-86 and 1986-87, and it is palpably obvious for anyone to see that we will certainly see a further increase in 1987-88.

All the signs are that this financial year in particular the Government's coffers will be utterly overflowing with revenue derived from the new and increased taxes, together with the significantly enhanced level of tax enforcement in the past few years. In case my last comment should be misinterpreted in any way, I am not in the least questioning the need for the best possible tax enforcement on the part of the Australian Taxation Office. What I am pointing to is that the additional revenues which are accruing to the Treasury from that source should assist the Government in achieving what is today the most pressing need in the budgetary area-namely, cutting the level of tax rates in this country.

On 15 September last year it was estimated that the deficit in the 1987-88 Budget would be $27m. In reality, of course, that deficit was $1,027m, because the figure was arrived at after taking account of what I think has previously been called in this chamber some creative accounting on the part of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). This was done by including as an offset to the Government's expenditures the receipts from a proposed program of major asset sales totalling $1,000m, which, in the view of many, should rather have been seen as a financing transaction rather than as a part of the Budget leading to the bottom line to be financed. However that may be, the fact is that today it is generally expected that the final outcome for this year's Budget will be very different from the figures laid down last September.

Although we on this side of the chamber do not have access to the kind of detail and revision of estimates which the Government has at its disposal through its departmental structure, nevertheless all the dogs appear to be barking that we shall see at 30 June this year, or shortly thereafter when the numbers finally go up, a surplus in this year's Budget in the order of $1 billion to $1.5 billion-that is, $1,000m to $1,500m. I note in passing that the outlook for 1988-89 would appear to be even stronger with prospective surpluses in the next financial year of the order of between $2.5 billion and $3.5 billion-$2,500m and $3,500m-being freely discussed without, I think, the slightest semblance of contradiction from the Treasurer or any other authoritative economic spokesman for the Government.

I add in that connection also that those figures were being bandied around on the basis of no policy change assumptions and, in particular, even before last week's Premiers Conference, which, as we all know, has cut the prospective Commonwealth payments to the States in 1988-89 by some $650m. I think that no-one on this side of the chamber would question the need for the States in our federal system to have to bear their share of the problems of fiscal restraint which the whole of Australia is currently facing. Whether or not the level of that cut in the Commonwealth's prospective payments to the States in 1988-89 is exactly appropriate-on the Treasurer's figures, I think that amounts to a cut of 4.2 per cent in real terms-may be a subject for discussion on another day. I do not propose to go into that this morning.

What one does notice, however, and what is worthy of remark, is that this further cutback of 4.2 per cent in real terms, after adjustment for inflation, in the Commonwealth's payments to the States in 1988-89 will follow a similar cut of no less than 4.7 per cent in real terms-at the moment that is still an estimate, but I imagine at this stage of the year it is a very good estimate -in the Commonwealth's payments to the States in the current financial year. In that connection, one should compare the cut of 4.7 per cent in real terms in the Commonwealth's payments to the States with the Commonwealth's approach to its own expenditure programs in its Budget-that is, the programs which are administered by its own Ministers-of bringing down a Budget which saw in overall net terms no cut at all. In fact, the Government budgeted for a very marginal increase of 0.1 per cent in real terms.

When the Treasurer makes his economic statement on Wednesday evening next week, and later on the Budget itself, the eyes of many Australians, and certainly all informed Australians, will be focused upon the Treasurer's performance in cutting back the spending programs of his own ministerial colleagues in the Commonwealth's own Budget in 1988-89. I think it must be said that if there is to be any sense of fairness about the policies of fiscal restraint which the Government, quite rightly-I do not question the policy at all-is seeking to impose upon us all, including State governments, we will have to see an equivalent degree of sacrifice being accepted by the Commonwealth in its own spending programs to the cut which, last week, it imposed on its payments to the States. That, I think, will be something on which to focus on Wednesday night of next week.

The Treasurer has said, publicly looking ahead to 1988-89, bearing in mind particularly in that regard that we are debating not merely the additional Appropriation Bills for the current financial year but also the Supply Bills for 1988-89, and been supported publicly in this by the Prime Minister also, that he will be aiming for a sharply increased surplus in the Commonwealth Budget for 1988-89. Again, I would like to put it on the record that the Opposition does not disagree with that objective. It is true, as the Treasurer and Government economic spokesmen have said, that the total public sector borrowing requirement in Australia today is still, given our economic circumstances, too high. What we do disagree with is the means which apparently the Government will be using to achieve that much enhanced budgetary surplus in 1988-89, namely taxing more and more in order to finance the still quite bloated levels of the Government's own expenditures and, I might say, doing so by, among other things, burdening not only individuals but also businesses with new incentive-sapping taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax.

All of this is going on at a time when our balance of payments is still in a pretty desperate mess. I say that, of course, without knowledge of the figures for April which, as I have mentioned earlier, will be published in just under an hour from now. However, what I think we must all understand, I feel sure the Government Ministers also do understand, is that whatever those figures may or may not reveal, one month's figures or a few months figures do not change the overall picture. I will return shortly to what that overall picture actually is.

At a time when, as I say, our balance of payments is still in a pretty desperate mess and when our external indebtedness, refered to in paragraph (a) of our proposed amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 3), is still climbing, it is very disquieting that we should have this degree of complacency on the Government's part. After all, as paragraph (a) of the proposed amendment states, Australia at the end of the last calendar year in December had a net foreign indebtedness amounting to $86.77 billion. To refresh any memories that may need refreshing, that is more than four times the comparable figure of just over $21.3 billion of net external debt with which Australia was encumbered at the end of June 1983, just after the present Government came to office. In 4 1/2 short years the Hawke-Keating Government has presided over a more than quadrupling of Australia's net foreign debt. We are continuing to add to that already very high level of outstanding debt at a rapid clip. In reviewing Australia's credit rating in the international bond markets the international credit rating firm Moody's Investors Service Inc. stated in March:
The pace of adjustment since 1983 has been steady but slow relative to several other OECD countries that have faced similar deficit problems.
Moody's went on to say:
A pertinent question is whether this gradualist approach to reform will succeed rapidly enough to prevent external borrowing requirements from reaching unacceptably high levels.

What are we effectively doing about this? The balance of payments deficit this year was originally estimated in the Budget Papers at $11.5 billion. It is now probable that it will end up at the end of the financial year at somewhere between $10 1/2 billion and $11 billion. Time and again in this Senate the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has boasted about the big improvement in Australia's balance of payments deficit for this year which such figures would in his opinion indicate. He has talked about the deficit of 6 per cent of gross domestic product which we experienced in 1985-86, he has pointed to the reduction of that deficit to about 5 per cent of gross domestic product in 1986-87 and he has pointed triumphantly to the estimated 4 per cent or possibly a shade under 4 per cent of gross domestic product in the current financial year.

The Opposition, on the other hand, has steadily pointed out that the improvement this year is due entirely to the sharp improvement in our international terms of trade and in particular to the sharp improvement in the international prices of many, indeed most, of our major export commodities. We pointed this out in the aftermath of the Budget itself, the do nothing Budget for 1987-88. We pointed this out again in the wake of the October crash last year of the international stock exchanges and, indeed, of the international foreign exchange markets. We also said that the pace of adjustment being pursued by the Government was simply not fast enough to deal adequately and responsibly with Australia's economic problems.

I must say therefore that I was fascinated to see a couple of remarks that the Treasurer made, very relevant to those matters, in his opening address to the Premiers foregathered here last Thursday for the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting. I interpolate that these were not off the cuff remarks of the kind which the Treasurer may have been thought to have made when he delivered his famous banana republic comments on the John Laws radio program almost two years earlier to the day. They were part of a formal statement of position which is always made by the Treasurer on these occasions to set the scene, set the stage, before the Government moves in to debate with the Premiers what they should or should not receive from the Commonwealth in the year ahead. What the Treasurer had to say first of all about the balance of payments-I am quoting from a transcript issued under the authority of the Treasurer's office-was this:

Exports are growing more strongly than the Budget forecast which was for 4 per cent growth-they are actually running at about 7 per cent. Despite that, imports are rising quickly as well-at about the same rates as exports. The problem is that what we-
that is, the Government-

call net exports-that is, the level of import competing and exporting products in excess of those imports-are not showing any change at the moment. Put another way, they are not contributing to the reduction in the current account deficit.
At the moment-
these are the words I want to stress-
the current account deficit is being held-and reduced-by the fortuitous lift in commodity prices. If that were to change we would be left exposed and vulnerable again.

I can only say that I am delighted to have the Treasurer finally concede the point that the Opposition has been making in this place for the past seven or eight months. I do not wish to short change the Treasurer's contribution to the debate. He went on further to say something else which the Opposition has been pressing upon this Government not only for the past seven or eight months but for a very long time beforehand. As recorded on page 15 of the transcript of the Premiers Conference, he stated in respect of our international debt situation:
We cannot claim-
that is, we in Australia-
to be in control of our own sovereignty while we owe someone else $100 billion of gross debt.
The figure was nearer $111 billion at the end of last December but I leave that aside. He continued:
While that gross debt is there and is being added to, albeit more slowly than in the past, our position as a nation is not secure.

Again I congratulate the Treasurer on the note of reality which at last has been allowed to creep in after two whole years, particularly the last nine months, of telling us rather different stories. While I am referring to the Treasurer's remarks in the course of last Thursday's Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting, let me refer for one moment-that is all the time I have-to the particularly vindictive actions of the Treasurer and this Government generally against the Government, and hence the people, of Queensland. The Commonwealth's offer to the States contained the following paragraph relating to borrowings by State authorities:
The Commonwealth therefore proposes that the global limit on authority borrowings be $4,700 million in 1988-89. This represents a reduction of 11.2 per cent on the 1987-88 limit of $5,293 million.
That is a reduction of $593m. The Commonwealth went on to say:

. . . ABS statistics on the net borrowing requirement suggest that in recent years Queensland's net PSBR had been significantly below its global limit. Those considerations underlie the illustrative distribution of global limits set out in Table 2, which shows an initial reduction of $300 million . . .

(Extension of time granted) I thank the Senate. The Commonwealth proposed that this reduction of $593m in the global funding limits of the State authorities be distributed by first reducing Queensland's share by $300m and then distributing the remaining $293m cut among all the States, including Queensland, the result being that the total cut proposed for Queensland would be $367m out of a total proposed cut of $593m. I do not have time to go into the full vindictiveness, the full discriminatory implications, of that proposal, which of course was the subject of argument last Thursday night, resulting, for the first time in my memory, in a disagreement at the end of the day and a refusal by the Premier of Queensland to accede to those kinds of standover tactics.

Let me turn in the three or four minutes remaining to me to the Supply Bills which are also before us this morning. The purpose of these Bills is to seek interim appropriations for the services of the Government for the period 1 July 1988 to 30 November 1988, by which date it is expected that the equivalent Appropriation Bills, which will form part of next year's Budget, will have been enacted. Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $8,689m for the ordinary annual services of the Government. Supply Bill (No. 2), which deals with the capital works and services, payments to the States, and so on, seeks interim appropriations totalling some $2,064m, again for 1988-89. Again, I point out that the Opposition will not be opposing these Bills. As I remarked at the outset, had they been discussed separately we should have moved a general amendment in relation to the second reading of the first of them, to express our dissatisfaction with the state of Australia's finances, including its external finances at this time. However, we have already so moved in the case of the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and, as I have said, we will not be duplicating that.

I make the point also that at the committee stage of the three Supply Bills the Opposition will move certain amendments to the schedules of the three respective Bills, which relate in each case to the item Advance to the Minister for Finance. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we are debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88, Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89. The Appropriation Bills actually appropriate an additional $654m for the purposes of the Government in the current financial year. The appropriations for additional funds have been offset by savings of some $566m on expenditure authorised by the previous Appropriation Acts for this financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Supply Bills in fact are for the interim part of the next financial year. They appropriate amounts of money for the period from 1 July 1988 to 30 November 1988, until the full Budget is passed later in the year. Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $8,600m for the ordinary annual services of the Government, and Supply Bill (No. 2) seeks interim appropriations of some $2,000m for expenditure on capital works and payments to the States. Capital works, of course, involve non-recurrent items and are the subject of Supply Bill (No. 2).

The Government's economic strategy at the moment is to respond positively to the decline in our export prices which has occurred in recent years, in relation to prices that we have had to pay for imports. As a result of that so-called terms of trade collapse, the Government had to make some fundamental changes to its budgetary strategy, compared to the strategy of previous years. There has been a commitment to structural adjustment of the Australian economy, requiring a reduced balance of payments current account deficit, essentially to try to boost our external proceeds in relation to the payments that we make overseas. We have a priority of bringing foreign debt under control within that structural adjustment and to develop new export oriented manufacturing industries to provide an increase in foreign exchange earnings in the long term.

The 1986 Budget and the economic statement of May last year began the process of adjustment, with substantial reductions of Commonwealth expenditures. This was done in order to reduce total domestic demand within the economy. The objective of that was to reduce the spill-over effect into imported goods. The policy was also to reduce the public sector borrowing requirement, to reduce foreign borrowings by the government sector of the economy. The 1987 Budget has continued the policy of fiscal responsibility. I am pleased to note that as of today the estimate is that there will be a surplus of some $580m for the current financial year, as compared to a Budget figure last year of an overall deficit of some $27m. So, at present we are looking at a Budget surplus of $580m, and, of course, the final figure will be available in a couple of months. That compares with the financial outcome for last financial year of a total deficit of over $2,000m.

It is very important to note that the prospective surplus this financial year is in fact the first in many years in the Commonwealth Budget sector. I was interested to hear the remarks of Senator Stone, who preceded me in this debate, because, of course, Senator Stone was the Secretary of the Australian Treasury, the head person there giving macro-economic policy advice to the Fraser-Howard Government for many years. In going through the Budget records before speaking this morning I noted that there were no Budget surpluses at all over the period of the Fraser Government, when Mr Howard, the present Leader of the Opposition, and Senator Stone, now the Leader of the National Party in this place, were in charge of the economic affairs of this country. According to the records available to me this morning, during that time there was never a Budget surplus. Therefore, it must be placed on record that there has been a dramatic turnaround in the finances of the Commonwealth of Australia since Mr Howard was sacked from the Treasury portfolio in 1983.

In the Budget this year there will be a cut in Government spending of 2 per cent in real terms. To simplify the economic jargon, that means that in fact Commonwealth spending will be rising 2.7 per cent less than the measure of inflation in the community. As to the likely result for this year and for last financial year, they are the only two consecutive real declines in total Commonwealth outlays, total Commonwealth Government spending, in the past 30 years. So, there has been a tremendous change in economic policy in recent years. Of course, within that period of 30 years we had the period when Mr Howard was Treasurer; he brought down five Budgets from 1978 to 1982 inclusive. Senator John Stone was his adviser in the Treasury. Never during that period were two Budgets in a row brought down where there were real cuts in government spending.

In this financial year the Hawke Government has taken positive action to reduce Commonwealth Government debt. In fact, the Government will repay some $1,000m of Commonwealth Government overseas debt and the same amount of domestic bonds this year. Again, no other government in more than 50 years has made repayments of both external and domestic government debt. I believe that the Government's economic strategy is working, and I refer to the Government's move to correct the external imbalance, that is, the excess of our import payments over our export proceeds, without inducing recession or drastically attacking Australian living standards.

The Government has pursued a strategy of restraint, with fairness in the community. It has distributed the burden of economic readjustment across all sectors of the community and, I am pleased to say, it has rejected the traditional conservative agenda of shifting the burden of economic adjustment on to the poor and needy sections of the community. The Hawke Government has not slashed government services to the needy and the disadvantaged and nor has it made unemployment a deliberate instrument of economic policy.

Of course, that was the agenda of Mr Howard and his New Right acolytes at the last election in 1987; it was an agenda which was decisively rejected by the Australian people. It is what they did in government; in fact, the whole record of the Howard Treasury is one of trying to cope with an increase in cost of living, increases in the consumer price index, by regulating the level of unemployment in the Australian community. They did not see employment as a right of the people; they saw it as a residual in the economic equations, and accordingly they varied the level of unemployment in an attempt to reduce the rate of increase in inflation, as measured by the consumer price index-and that approach failed. The Liberal Government left office with 11 1/2 per cent inflation and unemployment in the 10 per cent range. It found that it had to create more and more unemployment to produce a given effect on the consumer price index-and as I say, that policy failed.

This Government's policies are in contrast to the Liberals' policy of industrial and social confrontation. The Hawke Government has made a managed response to the problems in the economy and at the same time has made special provision to protect those persons most at risk during the period of slow growth in national income that we have experienced in recent times. I instance the family package announced last year, which has in fact provided a substantial boost to low income families with children. The scheme is targeted at households whose head is in the work force, and substantial payments of $22 a week per dependent child are made under that package.

In contrast to that policy response to Australia's economic problems, we have had the Howard and Stone record during the period from the late 1970s to the early 1980s. Now we have claims by Senator Stone, Mr Howard and Mr Peacock that the pace of economic adjustment at present is not fast enough. Those three gentlemen insist that the Government should cut more deeply into expenditure. However, empty boasts and claims are easily made. The practice of policy implementation on the Treasury benches is much more difficult than the life of sitting on the back bench in Opposition. I must say that so far this Opposition has not really delivered the goods with its policies; it gives no cause for joy to the Australian people. This has been a very poor Opposition in terms of getting together policies and actually showing the Australian people that it is an alternative government with alternative policies.

It is relevant to ask just how the Opposition's breast beating about the cutting of government spending compares with its own record in government. There is plenty of data on that very relevant question. We can go right back to the period when the then Mr Stone was sitting over the road in his chair in the Treasury, Mr Howard was in the Treasurer's office in this building, and Mr Fraser was the Prime Minister. It is interesting indeed to look at the record to see how their actions in that period compared with their rhetoric as political figures in running this country. It is particularly relevant to note that in 1978-79 in the first Budget that Mr Howard brought down as Treasurer, the Budget outlays-that is, Commonwealth Budget expenditures-as a proportion of Australia's gross domestic product were 27.0 per cent. In the last year that Mr Howard was Treasurer and when Senator Stone-who is moving amendments in relation to the legislation before us-was advising Mr Howard, Budget outlays were not 27.0 per cent or 28.0 per cent of gross domestic product: in fact, they were 28.7 per cent of gross domestic product. Therefore, in that span of five years of Howard Treasurership with Senator Stone advising him, Budget outlays, as a proportion of Australia's gross domestic product, rose by 1.7 percentage points. They did not fall. I well remember the rhetoric of the 1975 election campaign, as I am sure you do, Mr President. There was the `turn on the lights' syndrome; there were claims about small government and about cutting government expenditure back. However, the reality is that when Opposition members are on the Treasury benches they do not cut government spending; in fact, they allow it to increase. The record shows that over the five years of Mr Howard's Budgets government spending rose 1.7 percentage points against Australia's gross domestic product.

It is also relevant to look at Australia's economic performance in that period under these people. As I have said, Senator Stone will move an amendment in relation to the legislation before us as it relates to the state of our economy. Let us look at what was happening when he was at the Treasury advising Mr Howard on how to run the Australian economy. In 1982-83, Australia's cost of living rise was a massive 11.5 per cent. In the March quarter of 1983, when this Government came to power and when Mr Howard was thrown out as Treasurer, the consumer price index was rising by an annual figure of 11.5 per cent. We had an unemployment rate in that recession of 1982-83 of 10.4 per cent. That was the record of Senator Stone, Mr Peacock and Mr Howard, who now come in here with quick fix solutions to the problems of the Australian economy. Their record was double digit unemployment and double digit inflation.

In fact, in the last year that Mr Howard was running the Treasury 186,000 Australians were thrown on the industrial scrapheap and out of work as a result of Mr Howard's desperate gamble to try to reduce inflation by reducing demand in the Australian community. The final insult to the Australian people was the disclosure that the prospective Budget deficit of 1983-84, when the previous Government left office, was $9,600m. That sum was piled up, for this Government to deal with, by the spendthrift policies of Mr Howard, advised by Senator Stone at the Treasury. That is a record of failure and mismanagement. The previous Government left the Hawke Government to clean up double digit unemployment and a double digit cost of living rise. The Howard-Stone regime failed to deliver economic growth and employment opportunities.

They were equally unsuccessful in their ideological crusade for smaller government. I have already pointed out the rise in gross domestic product accounted for by Commonwealth Government spending under that previous regime-a 1.7 percentage points rise in total outlays at a time when these members of the previous Government were going around the Australian community pointing to the virtues of small government and saying that they would bring it about. However, year in and year out they were adding to the proportion of gross domestic product taken by Commonwealth Government spending. In fact, Mr Howard, advised by the then Mr Stone, overshot expenditure estimates in every one of the five Budgets they brought down together. In every one of the five Budgets from 1978 to 1982 Mr Howard, as Treasurer, advised by the then Mr Stone, overshot the original expenditure estimate. That is the record of those gentlemen, and they now have the cheek and gall to lecture us here on how to run the Australian economy and conduct the Australian Government's finances. They left us with a prospective Budget deficit of $9,600m and we have turned it into a surplus in 1987-88.

Three of the five Budgets brought down by Mr Howard, advised by the then Mr Stone, blew out beyond Budget projections. That culminated in the massive blow-out of $2,700m in 1983. That was the record on the fiscal front of the Howard-Stone team, and now they want to go back to the Australian people and say that they have the credentials and the runs on the board to manage the Australian economy in the future.

I now want to consider the area of taxation, which I find particularly interesting in view of the amendment foreshadowed today by Senator Stone in relation to the legislation before us. Mr Howard, advised by the then Mr Stone, had little success in stemming the growth of total government receipts, and income tax receipts in particular. It is interesting to note that in 1978-79, the year of the first Budget that Mr Howard brought down as Treasurer, total government Budget receipts, as a proportion of gross domestic product, were 23.8 per cent. That is the figure in the appendix to the Budget Papers-23.8 per cent was the relationship of Commonwealth Government Budget receipts to Australia's gross domestic product in 1878-79.

In 1982-83, the year of Mr Howard's last Budget-and again he was advised by the then Mr Stone, now Senator Stone and mover of amendments in the Senate on fiscal and macro-economic policy-Commonwealth Government receipts as a proportion of gross domestic product were not 23.8 per cent, the original figure; they were not 24.8 per cent; they certainly were not 25.8 per cent; they were in fact 26.1 per cent of gross domestic product. So after the talk at the time of the 1975 election about turning on the lights, cutting back the size of government and putting income back in the pockets of Australians, these people put their hands deeper and deeper into the pockets of the Australian taxpayers.

In 1978, Mr Howard introduced a Budget which involved taxation and Commonwealth Government receipts totalling 23.8 per cent of gross domestic product. His last Budget produced a figure 2.3 percentage points higher. In preparing all of those Budgets right through that period he was advised by the present Senator Stone about how to conduct the Australian Treasury. It is also interesting to look at taxation receipts within that total revenue figure because they also rose sharply over the same period. From 1978-79 to 1982-83 Commonwealth Government taxation revenue as a proportion of the gross domestic product rose from 21.7 per cent to 24 per cent. Over that period of five Budgets there was a lift of 2.3 percentage points in the share of Australia's gross domestic product taken by taxation.

Last year, on 7 October, in this place Senator Stone said that no purpose was served in examining the economic record of the Fraser Government. I simply pose the question: If the Fraser Government had had a successful economic record would Senator Stone have been so modest last October? It is a disastrous record not just in terms of micro-economic policy and policy outcomes but also in terms of taxation and government expenditure. Obviously Senator Stone is not proud of his record under the Fraser Government, and nor should he be on the basis of the facts that I have put to the Senate today. The credibility of words can be judged only by corresponding actions. The fact is that the economic policies of the Fraser-Howard Government as advised by Senator Stone failed. So there can be little credibility to the Opposition's criticism of the present Government's policies.

It is interesting to note, for example, that Senator Chaney, who is present in the chamber, said on 21 September last year in his speech on the Budget that there is insufficient wage restraint in Australia. He seems to have forgotten the wages explosion in the last years of the Fraser Government. I well remember the wages explosion in the early 1980s. In fact, it is very interesting to look at the average weekly earnings for full-time adults in the period 1980-81 to 1982-83. For example, while Senator Chaney says that at present there is insufficient wage restraint in Australia the fact is that average wages rose by 14.2 per cent in 1980-81; in the following financial year, 1981-82, there was a 13.3 per cent rise; and in the following year, the last year of the Fraser-Howard Government, which was advised by the then Mr Stone, there was a 14.2 per cent rise in average weekly ordinary time earnings for full-time adults. So in every one of those years there were double digit wage rises, yet Senator Chaney says now that there is insufficient wage restraint in Australia. However, when it was in government the coalition's record on the wages front and in the industrial area was one of total disaster and calamity for the Australian economy.

On 7 October last year Senator Stone said in this place that real unit labour costs are too high. However, let us check the facts and look at the record when Mr Stone was sitting over the road in his big chair at the Treasury, advising Mr Howard on how to run the Australian economy. It is very interesting that in terms of the index of real unit labour costs in Australia in the 1970s there were increases and not decreases. If we look at the non-farm sector, which is what the economists look at because the farm sector is heavily affected by seasonal conditions, the index of real unit labour costs rose from 105 points to 107 points while Mr Howard was Treasurer. By comparison, in the first four years of the Hawke Government since 1983 the index has fallen from 107 points in 1982-83 to 97 points in 1986-87. Real unit labour costs have fallen in every year of the Hawke Government. That can be contrasted with the period when Mr Stone was advising Mr Howard on how to run the Australian economy, when they rose significantly.

I turn now to the question of taxation and particularly the whole question of consumption taxes. The Alice in Wonderland quality of Liberal Party thinking is maintained in its new tax policy. In recent years Mr Howard has repeatedly promised to scrap the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. In fact, I think his famous quotation is that he would scrap the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax `lock, stock and barrel'. Mr Howard went to the Australian people time and time again with the statement that he would scrap those taxes `lock, stock and barrel'. However, it seems that, as a result of recent policy discussions within the coalition, a watered-down version of the capital gains tax will now be put to the Australian people by the Liberal Party. I hope that I am not saying anything that is incorrect; that is my interpretation of the coalition's new tax policy, that there is to be a version, albeit watered-down, of the capital gains tax. I understand that there is also to be a version of the fringe benefits tax in the coalition tax policy. Despite all the statements about scrapping the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax lock, stock and barrel those very taxes now miraculously appear in the coalition tax policy. It is yet another reversal on the taxation front by the coalition.

I would like to find out what is proposed in relation to the other element that was dealt with in our tax statement in 1985, that is, the termination of tax subsidised lunches in restaurants. What is the coalition's policy on that? Time and time again the Government was castigated in this place and in the House of Representatives for ending that tax rort which was available to highly privileged people in the Australian community-a tax rort that cost over $300m every year just to allow a certain section of the community to eat lunches in restaurants at taxpayers' expense. I would like to hear what the coalition will do about that. Will it restore that tax rort? Will it bring back the free lunch, that great rort within the Australian tax system? We do know, whatever the decision in that area, that the Liberals are planning a new tax directed at ordinary Australians because the Liberal Party has said that it will rationalise the Australian sales tax system.

I have been a student of sales tax in a professional sense for many years and on my interpretation the only way that one can significantly rationalise the Australian sales tax system is to expand the sales tax base. Essentially only two areas are left in terms of physical products into which the sales tax base can be expanded, and they are food and clothing. As I see it, that is the only way that the Liberals could significantly rationalise sales tax. Food and clothing are the only significant areas of the Australian economy where substantial revenue could be gained from a rationalisation of the sales tax system. Of course, historically both of those areas have been tax exempt for many years.

As a result of this so-called rationalisation of sales tax by the coalition we could find that a whole range of items in the Australian community could be subject to an indirect tax, including a loaf of bread, a bag of flour, a meat pie at the football-which Senator Walsh is so fond of talking about-and children's shoes. That is the inescapable conclusion. If one looks at the fine print in Mr Howard's major statement on taxation to Parliament on 12 March 1981 one sees that not many areas remain to be taxed. Unless one taxes services, the intangible elements of the Australian economy, to rationalise sales tax significantly one must tax food and clothing. I make it clear that the party of which I am a member, the Australian Labor Party, is not in that game. We will certainly not go down the road of placing a tax on a loaf of bread or a meat pie and a whole range of food items and clothing including children's shoes. Those items are all up for grabs.

TALK.START.PARA: —You tax food now.

—That is a very good point. Senator Messner makes the point that we tax food. In fact, I think Opposition speakers came up with about three items. They parroted off orange juice and, I think, potato chips and soft drinks. They are the only three food items they could think of. Snack foods and the like are about the only items that are taxed. But the Opposition is considering putting a tax on such things as a loaf of bread, meat pies and flour-all the staples of the Australian community. That is what will come out of the Opposition's rationalisation of the sales tax system. The Opposition will not be able to get significant revenue unless it moves into the food and clothing areas. One has only to read Mr Howard's speech in the House of Representatives in March 1981 to reach that conclusion. He made it very clear then that if one is to get significant revenue from a sales tax in this country, one has to move into the substantially untaxed areas. That is what it is all about. These people will hit staple items in the community. They say that they will not have a consumption tax but they will have a disguised consumption tax in the form of a sales tax on food and clothing which will seriously disadvantage ordinary Australians. Of course it will disadvantage ordinary Australians; they spend all their income. They cannot afford to save their income and therefore be exempt from the tax. They have to spend all their income in their daily lives. It is very difficult for people to put aside savings when they are on low incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to be very vigilant in scrutinising the fine print of the Liberals' hastily cobbled together tax policy to ensure that they do not move down this road of putting a massive sales tax on the staple items purchased by the Australian community. I am delighted that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has ruled out a consumption tax being levied by the Labor Government. I utterly and totally repudiate consumption tax and a further expansion of the sales tax as proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the debate on the Appropriation Bills and I do so in order to address the body of my speech to a subject to which I have devoted considerable attention since I have been in this place-that is, funding for people with disabilities. Before I do so, I point out that I had the pleasure of hearing a couple of comments made by Senator Maguire about the tax policies of the Liberal Party of Australia. I suggest that he take time to read that policy. I wish to correct some of the comments that he made. For a start, there is no mention of entertainment tax. As Mr Howard quite categorically stated, there will be no entertainment tax in our new tax policy. Senator Maguire then went on to try to discredit our tax policy by bringing up the old furphy of consumption tax.
—I was talking about the free lunch. You are going to bring back the free lunch; $300m worth of rorts.
—There is no mention of free lunches and you know that Mr Howard himself said that there would be no entertainment tax whatsoever.
—You do not know what you are talking about. For three years you have been saying that you would bring the free lunch back.

—Senator Maguire does not know what he is talking about either because he went on to talk about consumption tax and there being no tax on food. We all know that there is a tax on orange juice and on other items at the moment.
—What about bread? You are going to tax bread, aren't you?
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—I just wish to make the point that Senator Maguire has misrepresented the Liberal Party tax policy in two ways. He tried to say that we would bring back the free lunch when in fact the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said that that was not the case, as did Mr Peacock. Also he is trying to bring up consumption tax again when all that has been said by the Opposition is that we will rationalise sales taxes which are already in existence anyway. Some people see them as a consumer tax because they are being applied at the moment to orange juice and that sort of thing.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the subject which I raised initially-that is, funding for people with disabilities. Whilst I believe that this Government has tried to claim that it is doing the best for people with disabilities, in actual fact it has deceived these people into believing that they are receiving more funds, when they are not. I stress that my prime motivation is to ensure that the many valuable programs that are operating throughout Australia at the moment should receive adequate funds to ensure their survival. I know that this is a sentiment which is shared by honourable senators on both sides of the House. I note that Senator Tate is in the House and I know that his thoughts turn particularly to the disabled and those people in need. I have sought to bring this matter before the Senate before and I have been accused of trying to beat up the situation. It has also been said that the situation that I have portrayed is incorrect. I was very interested to read an article in the Sydney Daily Telegraph on 26 April this year which quotes the Executive Officer of the Association of Rehabilitation Facilities, Mr Kevin Burn. The article said:

Some handicapped people in sheltered employment could be left in the cold under Federal Government funding proposals, rehabilitation chief Kevin Burn believes. He said there was concern about the ability of the Government to meet the cost of its new work ideas for the physically and intellectually handicapped.

It is very interesting to note that the sorts of comments which I have been airing for some time are now being reported throughout Australia in the Press. There is concern-and it is very real-about the viability of such programs. As I said earlier, and perhaps this has not been the intention, the Government has been making more funds available in some areas, but has been taking them out in others. One can put more into the pot but, unfortunately, if one is taking it out all the time, the soup becomes a bit thinner. Therefore the people who are supposed to be receiving these benefits are not getting what they should.

In dealing with this subject, it is appropriate to consider the guidelines issued by the Department of Community Services and Health with regard to its programs for people with disabilities. In its pamphlet, the Department goes to great trouble to spell out the aims and objectives of these programs and I think it is again appropriate that I take this opportunity to share with my colleagues the Department's assessment of its disability services program. That assessment says:

The disability services program can fund non-profit community based organisations and State and local government authorities to provide a range of services for people with intellectual, physical, sensory or psychiatric disabilities, provided these services meet with ongoing support needs. Services which can be assisted include accommodation support, respite care, advocacy, information, support and employment, competitive employment training and placement, independent living training, recreation and print disability services.
These are all worthwhile programs and ones which deserve support. But the key to the Department's guidelines is in its wording:
provided these services meet with ongoing support needs.

It is clear to me and it becomes even clearer as I delve into the matter that there are a good number of programs which are providing such services which have an ongoing demand for their assistance and which are very supportive in their role. But if present trends continue, these will miss out altogether.

The present position is that in some cases the intellectually handicapped and sheltered workshops have not received funding for the current financial year, even though we are nearly at the end of it. Only last month I received letters from some areas, particularly in Tasmania, where they had had no indication of what their assistance would be for maintenance and equipment this year.

Nobody can deny that in the community services area requests for funds have by and large always exceeded the available allocations. But in recent years less money is being made available to many segments which are providing funding for disability services. Largely this has coincided with a number of innovative demonstration projects. These projects themselves have proved to be very successful and I congratulate the Government on its initiative in bringing them forward. But as I said earlier, it is another case of trying to get more out of the same pot, more out of the same amount of money, and all this is doing is creating problems in other areas. If the Government is to honour its ongoing commitments, the existing projects must suffer. I think that was brought about by replacing the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act with the Disability Services Act. I believe that it has caused a lot of trouble. The Government, in trying to do the right thing, again has fallen into a trap. Section 3 (c) of the Disability Services Act states:
to ensure that services provided to persons with disabilities-
(i) further the integration of persons with disabilities in the community, and complement services available generally to persons in the community;
(ii) enable persons with disabilities to achieve positive outcomes, such as increased independence, employment opportunities and integration in the community; and
(iii) are provided in ways that promote in the community a positive image of persons with disabilities and enhance their self-esteem.

That is a very fine and positive outlook to adopt; but in fact what the bureaucrats are doing, using the guidelines set down in the Act-I saw such a case only the other day-is taking the less intellectually and physically handicapped people from a sheltered situation, in supported employment where people support them, and their friends, and placing them in the community, where they are at risk. To do that they have to be provided with minders, welfare officers, whose quite significant salaries have to be paid for.

In achieving that end, all the Government is doing is taking away the available funds that could be used to provide the services that are needed in existing areas such as sheltered workshops. Whilst the Government's intention has been laudable and the Act's intention is laudable and praiseworthy, in fact the system is just not working. It is creating more demand on the funds that already exist. Because extra funds are not available, the present organisations do not have the money they need to carry on.

When equipment and maintenance funding requests are not met and the cost has to be met by the organisation, thus depleting its funds, that can affect the financial viability of that facility. We must bear in mind that quite a few organisations provide essential products to our community. A supported employment centre which I visited a couple of months ago provides brooms and brushes for the local zinc company. Those items are not provided by anyone else. The people providing the service are deaf. Under the new Disability Services Act and the way it is interpreted by the bureaucrats, it was thought that it would be a good idea to take those people from that centre and move them into the zinc company's premises.

That fits in very well with the Act's intentions. It could be seen that those people were being placed in the work force, thus achieving the Government's aims. But all it did was create a union situation. Those people who were taken from the environment which they were used to felt that the sooner they got back to their own premises the better. Builders and the like place great reliance on cupboards and timber products produced by sheltered workshops, all of which need money for equipment maintenance. That is one of their most essential requirements for funds so that they can keep their machinery up to scratch. When we are nine months into the year and they still do not have any commitment to funding for that equipment, the viability of their operation is affected.

In an effort to resolve some of the matters which have raised themselves during my deliberations, I have taken the opportunity in this chamber to ask a number of questions of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook). It is appropriate that I take this opportunity to take Senator Cook to task for some of his comments. While Senator Cook may claim that overall expenditure has grown over the years, what he fails to say is that the number of services throughout the country has increased by 141 per cent over the last 10 years-that is, 1976-77 to 1985-86-while the grant moneys being made available to groups have increased by only 50 per cent over the same period.

If we look at these figures over the industry as a whole and, therefore, the actual expenditure which is being put into disabled programs, we see that in real terms it has decreased by some 83 per cent or $86m over the same period. Unfortunately, I could not attend the Estimates committee hearings, but Senator Walters asked quite a few questions pertaining to funding on my behalf. As yet, I have not received a reply. I suspect that what has been made known to me by members of those groups is true.

The Minister stated that capital funding has not been severely cut. He went on to clarify that by saying that it has been cut, but not severely. We need to make the point that the financial resources of those groups are not such that they can afford to absorb cuts. Any cut, regardless of its size, is a severe cut. The Minister also stated that the Government has never been able to provide, nor indeed is it committed to, automatic entitlement for service provided. That is a total abrogation of the Government's responsibility to assist under the Act, for the Act gives a much broader definition of those individuals who should be assisted. Don Grimes, a former Minister, was responsible for the Act. It is well known that he said that, under the new Act, when it replaced the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, recipients would not be any worse off; in fact, they would be better off. That is not the case.

I have received letters from sheltered workshops and supported employment areas which show real concern about what is happening. When the Act was enacted, the present Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) put out a news release which stated:

The Government's newly-introduced Disability Services Act recognises that `People with disabilities have a right to be part of the community-to fulfil their aspirations in terms of employment, day-to-day living, and recreation.
That is fine. The news release went on to say:
This means that people with disabilities have greater opportunities for improvements in their quality of life as a result of the Government's initiatives.

As I said earlier, those are very good initiatives and aims, but what is happening is that the Government is coming up with all these new ideas and very little extra funds. Therefore, the whole thing is falling apart. It is a very serious situation.

A great deal of the capital funds which have been made available over the last few years has gone into accommodation services. Those accommodation services have grown extensively, due to the deinstitutionalisation principle adopted by the Commonwealth and the States. What this means in effect is that the number of accommodation services which can be made available is decreasing and that there are few institutions available for the up and coming disabled who are now approaching the service providers with a need for such accommodation. The costs associated with supplying these services have simply not kept up with the demand and this has been at the cost of existing services.

I firmly believe that this Government cannot take an attitude where `no funds' can be used as an excuse. For too long the needs of the disabled who are least able to present their case have been ignored. In my State of Tasmania, I have been made aware that centres are awaiting money for essential equipment and maintenance and that these funds simply are not available. Quite clearly we have a situation where the expectations of the disabled in Australia have been heightened by the new disability services legislation. This increase in expectation has flowed through to families and to those providing these services. However, the large waiting lists which are now being experienced by these groups are testimony to the underfunding and, in some cases, the defunding which has occurred over the past decade.

I would suggest that probably most senators on both sides of the House would at some time or other have had something to do with disabled people, particularly the intellectually disabled. I never cease to be amazed and impressed by the wonderful feeling that the disabled have for each other and the affinity that they have with the people who come to visit them. The people who work in these situations-the volunteers and the paid workers who control these organisations-have a great pride in what they are trying to achieve. They, too, have a great affinity with the people they are working with.

I am told that the young people who are working in supported employment areas cannot wait to get back to work. Intellectually and physically handicapped people who believe that they are doing their bit for this country-in fact, they are doing it very well-almost queue up to get back to work after a holiday period. Work is one way in which they can show their self-esteem and create some pride for themselves. As I said earlier in my speech, they are almost in a club situation in which they rely on each other so much for support. It is very distressing to me to read in letters that I have received-and I will quote from a couple of them-that the lack of funding could mean a drop off in services and an increase in the waiting lists. One letter said:

When equipment and maintenance funding requests are not being met and where this cost is being met by the Service, the depletion of the organisations funds could well affect the financial viability of the facility.
The letter went on to say:
. . . a large number of disabled employees in Supported Employment and other services are going to be severely disadvantage if the Government do not provide adequate funds to meet the stated goals.
This is a very serious state of affairs. A letter which I received from the Society of St Vincent de Paul stated:
. . . expectations of the disabled in Australia have been heightened by the New Disability Services legislation as it has for their families and service providers.
It went on to say:
The large waiting lists are a product of under-funding and defunding . . .

People, particularly the intellectually handicapped, who cannot be catered for under these schemes, naturally cause problems at home. It is a sad fact that the pressures they bring to bear on their families because of their disabilities result in some cases in marriage break-ups. These are some of the concerns that the people running these organisations have been putting to me. I think that the people who are involved with the Disability Services Act should take note of what is being said by concerned people in the community who do not believe that the legislation is achieving what it set out to do.

It should also be realised in regard to the service of programs for the disabled that the Federal Government has always provided and probably will continue to provide a very small share of funding towards the cost of disability services. Those who operate such programs are being asked to adhere rigidly to a set of guidelines-in many cases, this arrangement has not received widespread approval from within the industry-in order to receive Federal funds. To sum up, the Government is really providing only between 20 and 30 per cent of the total amount of money required to run most of these services. Yet, it wants 100 per cent of the say. The people who are providing the bulk of the finance and assistance are the volunteers or the paid managers.

The 70 to 80 per cent of the money that is provided to keep these services running comes from volunteer organisations that initially get their money from the public, from the taxpayer. There is no doubt that the man in the street parts with that money in a much easier fashion than he does when he has to pay the tax man. Nevertheless, the responsibility is on organisations that collect the charity dollar. We know that there is a lot of competition for that dollar, whether it is for disabled people, overseas aid or the myriad of other charities that seem to be growing at a greater rate than the available money is.
