We have a situation in which people in volunteer organisations who have been giving their time for nothing are being told by this Government and the people in charge of community services what they have to do, and they face very strict guidelines-all because the Government provides 20 to 30 per cent of the funds. The word would soon get out amongst the voluntary groups if the amount of money were reduced and the supported employment services and other services folded. Who would blame these people for that when they are giving their time for nothing?

The effect on the morale of the volunteers is another aspect of this disability services legislation. What we are seeing is a new direction. The bureaucrats keep on telling the people who are doing the work, `Trust us-everything is going to be all right'. In fact, it is not all right. We have arrived at a situation where there is real concern amongst the institutions right around Australia. As I said earlier, this concern was picked up initially by Kevin Burn, who is the Executive Officer of the Association of Rehabilitation Facilities. Quite a large article on what he had to say was published in the Sydney Daily Telegraph. I think this Government should keep in touch with this important aspect. Organisations such as the ones I have spoken about have every right to be concerned.

Organisations in Devonport which are actively involved in private enterprise type operations provide work for dozens of intellectually handicapped people, some of whom make very fine articles of furniture for a very captive market. These organisations are actively involved in tendering for work. As well, funds are being raised by charitable methods. As I said earlier, the whole situation will fall in a hole if volunteers withdraw their labour because we have interfered with charities.

In conclusion, I do not think we need point out to the Australian taxpayer the fact that the Government, for its part, should seek to work in close cooperation with all charitable organisations throughout Australia. The Government should take another hard look at the level of funding it is providing. It should encourage all of the different organisations that came under the old Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and which now come under the new Disability Services Act to extend their activities. It should give them an incentive to continue in the way that I think we would all like them to continue. Also, the Government should encourage those volunteers who give of their time and effort in such a good fashion and in the true Australian spirit of mateship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 and cognate Bills. The Opposition has foreshadowed an amendment, paragraph (c) of which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (c) the urgent need to reduce public sector outlays as the major element of a Government policy response to our current economic difficulties.

Of course, this is a typical Opposition response. When we asked the Opposition what it would do of course it went all funny as to which particular public service it would cut. The Opposition will not tell the Australian people which public service it will cut to make this the major emphasis of its policy. What we do know is that finally it has adopted a tax policy that seems to be a confused muddle; at worst, it signifies a deep conflict within the coalition parties. All political parties understand the problem of fiercely opposed views on which a compromise, which means all things to all people, is worked out. However, the Opposition has taken this to an art form. The Opposition has got it to the stage where, when one looks at its policy, one finds that it says that it will not have a consumption tax, that it will rationalise the existing indirect tax system. As Senator Maguire has adequately pointed out, this is a Clayton's consumption tax. The Opposition throws out a sop to its own constituency by announcing a watering down of the capital gains tax. However, the Opposition makes it impossible to administer. When it comes to tax loopholes we know that the Fraser-Howard Administration was a past master at showing people how, if they were wealthy enough and skilled enough, they could avoid taxation.

The Opposition goes on to say that the fringe benefits tax will be made more flexible. However, it then says that this will be by way of a tax on employees rather than employers. The Opposition goes back on its policy of wiping out the assets tax but says that it will make that test more generous. The Opposition further says that it will help families. It does not say that it will help all families. Of course, the obvious inference will be that it will help the families it has always helped, that is people who are rich and comfortable. Therefore, the Opposition has a tax policy that means everything to everyone or nothing to anybody. I believe that the Opposition tax policy reflects the turmoil in its own ranks.

As Chairman of Estimates Committee A I would like to refer to another manifestation of this attempt by the Opposition to play politics. I do not dispute the Opposition's right to be political when it comes to Appropriations. What I would like to point out is that in regard to the particular proposed additional expenditures we have a reservation expressed by Senator Bishop, Senator Alston and Senator Chapman. I want to go through that reservation briefly to indicate that the Government senators did not support this position and, indeed, do not view with concern the number of matters they listed. The report itself was three pages but there were five pages of reservations from the Opposition. I want briefly to go through and show that most of the issues raised are really make weight issues to try to create a sham problem. For example, the first point raised in the Opposition reservation regards the expenditure on resource planning. The reservation document stated:
The Director of Resource Planning, Mr F. Kovachevich, admitted $200,000 had been `lost' and then `regained'. According to Mr Kovachevich the mistake was made by the Department of Finance.

Two days after the hearing on 12 April the Department of Finance wrote to the Committee stating that their records showed that the information given by Mr Kovachevich was incorrect. At the subsequent committee hearing on April 19 1988 the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce presented a letter which denied the substance of the Department of Finance's letter and held to its original view.

That simply means that there was an amount of $200,00 and a mistake was made to the extent that an amount of money was allocated to a program area rather than as an administrative expense or running cost. It is a simple matter of that nature. This was indicated very clearly. I think the simplest way to clarify this is to refer to page A65 of the 19 April Estimates Committee A transcript and seek leave to incorporate Senator Bishop's questions and the answers given by Mr Palfreyman.
Leave granted.
The transcript read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of questioning by this Estimates Committee last week I asked a question concerning the loss of some $200,000. The evidence given by your officers was, very simply, that the money had got lost. Subsequently we have had an indignant letter from the Department of Finance asserting:

SPEECH.PARA: We request that you contact the Chairman of the Senate Estimates Committee A seeking to have your comments withdrawn and providing a more reasonable explanation for the transfer of funds.

Subsequently there was a letter from Mr Palfreyman, from your own department, saying that the initial explanation stands. Can we have some comment on the apparent disagreement as to what happened with the $200,000 and who is correct?

Mr Palfreyman-In answering the question last week, Mr Kovachevich, who is my Director of Finance, indicated that there was a need to transfer $200,00 from program funds to administration funds and that resulted because of an error by the Department of Finance. Perhaps he should not have pointed the finger as such, because it certainly provoked that Department. I am not able to speak for it. However, I draw your attention to the Department of Finance letter which seems to us to indicate that, when we told it about the error in the Budget documents, that occurred at a much later point in the process, and by the time it was picked up the Department could not do anything about the Bills, and so forth. My office has advised me that that advice occurred the day after by telephone and in writing the following day. So from our viewpoint we believe that changes could have been incorporated. Having said that, I emphasise that we are not talking about new funds. We are really talking about a transfer from the program budget to the administrative budget for this program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The language is fairly strong. The Department of Finance stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Our records show that this assertion is clearly incorrect.

That is, there was an error. I note that you say that, as soon as the error was discovered, you notified the Department and a broadsheet detailing the break-up of all new policy funds was provided to the Department of Finance on 3 September 1987. Was there an accompanying letter with that broadsheet?
Mr Palfreyman-Not that I am aware of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was a minute kept of the telephone advice to the Department of Finance?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Palfreyman-I did not ask my officers, but I assume that that is the case because they have been quite precise in their reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there was no letter stating, `I write to confirm my advice of yesterday that you are in error'?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Palfreyman-No. In that sort of climate things happen fairly quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps in light of all this you might have to protect your back a little more carefully and write a letter next time?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Palfreyman-We do not feel terribly defensive about this matter. It is a normal transactional thing at this time of the year. We disagree with the view that Finance has put forward. Departmentally, we are sorry that it has had to come out in this way and involve the time of the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Finance was fairly vociferous in its objection to your saying that it was an error.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Palfreyman-I cannot speak for the Department of Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonetheless you feel that the money has now been satisfactorily accounted for?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Palfreyman-Yes. As I say, it was never a case of asking for additional funds. It was a transfer from the program vote to the administrative vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, there is no question of misappropriation of money. There was, if you like, a contest between two departments as to what they had done. However, it was simply a matter of dispute between two bureaucracies, if you like. Certainly, the Committee was not in a position to adjudicate. It was dealing with the industry accounts. I think that to make this a major issue is to wrongly see the role of Estimates committees.

SPEECH.PARA: The second item in the reservation regards the cement industry. I will just briefly read a segment of the Opposition reservation, which stated:

The Minister told the Committee that the recently established cement industry monitoring body was not set up in response to allegations of dumping by the industry and that no part of the monitoring body's responsibilities will involve the consideration of dumping complaints. This statement appears to conflict with a press release dated 24 March 1988 issued by the Minister which states inter alia, that the body will specifically:
`a) monitor the progress and outcome of dumping complaints lodged by the industry;
e) monitor the efforts of the industry to meeting competition from imported cement.'

Senator Button did say that the monitoring committee was not set up in response to allegations of dumping. This is true. As was explained in the Press release of 24 March 1988 the committee was set up to assess the current competitive position of the industry. This is a lot wider question than just dumping. The Press release referred to the committee being able to `monitor the progress of the industry on a range of issues'. The committee will not, as Senator Button said, consider dumping complaints. The Australian Customs Service considers dumping complaints. One of the five responsibilities of the committee is to monitor the progress and outcome of dumping complaints. This means that the committee will ensure the timeliness of the investigation and assess the implications of the findings of the Customs Service of the dumping allegations. Therefore, the committee will not be directly considering the dumping complaints. Of course, that often happens in government. I am pleased to say that in Australian Customs Notice No. 88/96 of 16 May it was indicated that there will be an inquiry into dumping of cement in Australia. Every honourable senator from every political party knows that representations have been made by the industry. Of course, in this case once again there is an attempt to make a problem where one does not exist. The processes have been followed and the Minister has quite clearly indicated the situation and has been quite proper in what he has said.
The third reservation that was raised stated:

The First Assistant Secretary of the Technology and Investment Division, Mr Terry Hilsberg, sent a memo on 22 July 1987 to all staff members in the Industry Research and Development Branch. The memo stated:

` I am writing to express my thanks for the excellent work you have performed through the year. In particular, I would like to commend you for achieving that important goal of exhausting monies allocated to IR&D Branch during the 1986-87 financial year.
I am sure your efforts in the coming year will prove to be equally successful.'
The Opposition continues:

The attitude of one of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce's senior officers is disturbing in that the only item that Mr Hilsberg singled out for praise was the expenditure of the money allocated to the branch. It is our view that exhausting monies allocated should never be a goal in itself.

The Committee was faced with the problem that Mr Hilsberg had left the Department so it could not inquire into why he had sent the memo. The Minister indicated that he would want to know why that memo had been sent. It is ridiculous that an Estimates committee be required to go on a witchhunt when the officer concerned has left the Department. It appears he was overenthusiastic in his endeavours, nevertheless the simple fact is that an Estimates committee cannot go into matters when the relevant officer is not present and that officer's views do not reflect the view of the Minister.
The fourth item in the Opposition document concerns an answer to a question relating to the Government's information industries strategy. The Minister told the Committee:

What we are asking in respect of companies is that they establish, in the period specified, a 50 per cent export-import ratio. If DEC, for example, or Hewlett-Packard are importing into this country $1 billion worth of equipment at the same time they will export half that by value.

The document goes on about that for some time; I will not read all of it. This is clearly a complex issue, but a straightforward one, in that the requirement of partnership for development programs is that transnational corporations must devote 5 per cent of their turnover to research and development and attain an export-import ratio of 15 per cent over the duration of the agreement. The durations vary somewhat, from five to seven years, to fit in with the strategic planning horizons of the corporations. Only value added in Australia is counted towards the export targets. The importation of goods for re-export would add similar dollar values to both imports and exports and so not significantly drive the export-import ratio towards 50 per cent. Even the importation of components for simple assembly prior to export will not be adequate since little value added is gained from assembly operations. Senator Button correctly stated that in the Hansard report of the Committee's hearing on 19 April, at page A64. In response to Senator Alston, who asked whether it was a fact that the figure of 50 per cent applies to the degree of value added in Australia, Senator Button replied yes. If there is any lack of precision in answers or in Press releases it has resulted from taking it for granted that the export targets were specified in terms of value added activities only. There would be no point otherwise.
In relation to the sixth item raised in the Opposition's document, the Opposition starts off:

We note with concern the Minister's statement that he was not satisfied that the barrier at airports and ports was adequate to meet the requirements of the Customs Service, quarantine and immigration.
This is a very simple matter. The Minister was asked by Senator Bishop, very simply:

Could the Minister say whether he is satisfied that the barrier at airports and ports is adequate and meets the requirements of Customs, quarantine and immigration, and in particular in respect of the smuggling of illicit drugs?
Senator Button replied no, following which Senator Bishop asked:
You are not satisfied?

Senator Button again replied no. How could Senator Button or any other responsible Minister say he was satisfied with the barriers when illicit drugs are still being smuggled into Australia? Making anything of this quite straightforward reply from the Minister is simply trying to distort the fact that any Minister would have to reply that he could not be satisfied, otherwise he would be being irresponsible.

The next item in the Opposition report is perhaps the main issue. As honourable senators can see the other issues are relatively trivial but this one refers to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The Opposition that we know so well is not dealing adequately with the economic issues facing this country and it has a confused policy, but it still tries to besmirch the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Opposition document states:

We note with concern the evidence given with reference to the so-called urgent renovations, costing $750,000, requested by the Department for Kirribilli House, ostensibly to make that residence suitable for the accommodation of Guests-of-Government during the bicentenary. Evidence showed that it could well be that the expenditure was merely to make Kirribilli House a second residence for the Prime Minister, in which case the figure of $250,000 for interior decoration of the ground floor rooms cannot be justified. The Committee was informed that no Guests-of-Government have stayed at Kirribilli House since March 1983, but that the Prime Minister had on many occasions.

The evidence does not back up the assertions in the Opposition's statement. In my view the last paragraph is particularly sinister. It is venomous. It attempts to attack the Prime Minister, and goes against the evidence taken by the Committee when dealing with this issue. I will refer to some of the answers given to show that the assertions that the Opposition members make in their minority report are incorrect. For example, Senator Michael Baume asked:

So the urgent and expensive renovations, which we understood was to prepare Kirribilli House for the bicentennial year for the use of guests of government, were simply to prepare it for the use by the Prime Minister during the bicentennial year? Is that the situation?
The officer, Mr Blick, replied:

The renovations are not complete yet. They were substantially delayed in recent times by the rains in Sydney and the difficulty of getting contractors for what are fairly small jobs by contractor standards.

It is significant, first of all, that delays had been caused by rain in Sydney. Any person who comes from Sydney would have to agree that the rain has caused tremendous problems, particularly for the building industry. Senator Michael Baume asked another question:
Has it nonetheless been capable of occupancy by the Prime Minister?
Mr Blick replied:

Yes. It has not been continuously capable of occupation by the Prime Minister because there was a good deal of construction work and redecoration work going on in a number of the downstairs rooms during that period.
I do not have time to go through all of the questions and answers. I refer honourable senators to them on page A68.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many overseas guests did stay there?
—I will first go on to one other question by Senator Michael Baume:

SPEECH.PARA: Are you saying that after this expenditure of half a million dollars, as I recall it, in the previous year, Kirribilli House was still not in an adequate state of repair for guests of government?
Mr Blick answered:

The expenditure in the previous year rendered the structure of the building safe and suitable. The rendering meant that the inside finishes of the building were totally unsuitable because, as you would understand, there was a lot of damage to surfaces caused by the sort of work that had to go on. Therefore there was a need for a redecoration program to render the place suitable to accommodate guests of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many since 1983?
—The point has been made. I could go on and read the whole of page A69, where it is pointed out--
—It is just a holiday home so that he doesn't have to live in his electorate with his constituents, is it not?

—No, that is not true, but it is true that the Prime Minister was able to live in the accommodation because the work was occurring particularly downstairs and outside, as I have just pointed out. It is drawing a long bow to assert, as the Opposition has attempted to do, that this expenditure was for only the Prime Minister's benefit, as that is quite wrong. The point is that we are talking about a guest of the Government, a head of state, coming to the place. Apparently, members of the Opposition would be prepared to put a person from another country into a place where there are bricks and mortar lying around, into a place which would be inappropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I want to make about the report concerns a lesser matter on which I do not intend to spend much time, other than to point out that it relates to a $10,000 request for settlement regarding the Builders Labourers Federation. It is sufficient to say here that the Minister said very clearly that he would ask his officers to investigate the matter; thus, once again this matter has been put in the dissenting report for political purposes. The Minister, of course, is quite happy to obtain the information that was sought.

On behalf of other members of the Committee, I wanted to refer to those matters. Opposition senators will speak later in the debate; I happened to be speaking at this position on the list, so I am not replying to them at this stage. It is typical of the Opposition to be engaged in a nitpicking exercise and ignoring the major issues that this country faces.

I now turn briefly to a non-controversial matter, although I suppose it might be regarded as controversial by some people. I refer to expenditure in the arts area, and particularly to the $43.9m that the Australia Council expended on the arts in 1986-87. Of course, that figure excludes administrative costs. I know that funding for the arts is never enough and one is always disappointed with the amount of money that goes to the arts. However, I want to refer to one enterprise in particular which is very important. Over the past two years Australia has been very fortunate to be the venue for the first and second Wondabyne sculpture symposiums in the Gosford area of the central coast of New South Wales.

The 1987 sculptures were created at Wondabyne where they now grace the river in perpetuity. The 1988 symposium took place in the hills of Mount Penang, Kariong, where more sculptures now rest. This makes Gosford the sculpture capital of Australia. I would hope that Senator Puplick would agree with me on this. Twenty-five world class sculptures have been created. Both symposiums received widespread media acclaim, both internationally and locally.

In simple financial terms, the two symposiums have provided forever sculptures worth $1.5m, for an outlay of something less than $150,000. The magnificent outcome has been achieved by international cooperation and cultural exchanges. We have had sculptors from Australia, Bulgaria, Burma, Georgia in the USSR, Mexico, Japan, Papua New Guinea, Nepal and France. The Japanese sculptor was from the Edogawa ward in Tokyo, a ward of 500,000 people, which has a sister city relationship with Gosford. The sculptors have donated their time free in a generous gesture to help resurrect the profession in Australia. Australia's contribution has been to provide air fares, accommodation, expenses-but no wages.

I feel a bit disappointed about the sources of funding for these projects. I assisted Lawrence Beck, one of Australia's leading sculptors and the prime mover in the organisation of the symposiums, in his search for financial assistance. This brings me back to the matter of the Australia Council. Its contribution to the first symposium was $5,000. In the event, no contribution has been made towards this year's bicentennial symposium. Funding for these events falls within the auspices of the Visual Arts/Crafts Board, which is one of five different funding bodies within the Australia Council. For the year 1986-87, the then separate Visual Arts Board provided $4.7m in grants. I acknowledge that funding for the Council has been cut by 2 per cent in real terms. However, how are these priorities determined? I am told by the Visual Arts/Craft Board:
Priority is given to contemporary projects on the cutting edge, not to what is seen as the very conservative sculpture [like Wondabyne].

That seems like gobbledegook to a person like me, but it is the sort of thing that is being said. The previous Labor Government in New South Wales, of course, did contribute, and private organisations have contributed. I would like to pay a tribute to the Mayor of Gosford, Dr Patricia Harrison, and her council for the excellent work that has been done. A significant part of the funding and other assistance came from the local business community in Gosford; for example, Gosford Quarries (NSW) Pty Ltd provided stone worth $40,000, and a number of other organisations participated. It is important to acknowledge organisations that are prepared to enhance the culture of a significant area like the central coast.

A further point that I want to make in the few remaining minutes that I have is that this very successful venture has not been without its costs. It has left the sculptors exhausted and out of pocket. The exhaustion results from the fact that they have only six weeks to work on projects that would normally take four months. I regret to say that two Australian sculptors were sacked from their jobs because of their participation in the symposium. Both had part-time teaching jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —They lost their grant when the local member ceased to be a Minister, didn't they?

—No, they had part time teaching jobs. It is nothing so politically sinister; it relates simply to the way that the middle level bureaucracy is incapable of assisting people who are working in this field. They lost their part-time teaching jobs with the Newcastle Technical College. This type of narrow thinking in this lower or middle level of the bureaucracy could happen in no country other than Australia. I indicate to Senator Puplick that I am hopeful that the new State Minister-and I hope that the senator will make representations to him-will look more sympathetically at the administration and structure for artists in this category. I think that this matter should be treated in a bipartisan manner in order to enhance our culture.

SPEECH.PARA: Lawrence Beck conducted a survey amongst Australian sculptors: only one Australian sculptor, Stephen Walker, can work the necessary hours to enhance his art. Other sculptors have left to become professors of sculpture at Princeton, Harvard, and other American universities. So, I wish to draw attention to this very real problem. I could develop the matter further but time does not permit me to. However, I do believe that in relation to this small section of our art world there is a need to be much more sympathetic to the particular nature of the people who ply this art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that I wish to raise during the debate on the Appropriation Bills is one that concerns all Queenslanders and, indeed, all Australians. I raise it now, before the May statement, in the hope that the Government will see fit to take some action when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brings down the economic statement next week. The problem to which I refer is the road funding crisis and the prospect of further reductions in Commonwealth road funding allocations. I remind the Senate that just recently, as part of Queensland's Bicentennial celebrations, the Hinkler Bicentennial Air Race was held. It was named, of course, in honour of our courageous and famous aviator from Bundaberg and Queensland, Bert Hinkler. It was fortunate that an air race and not a car race by road was organised. I doubt that a car race would have been possible, given the conditions of outback roads in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government has an abominable track record on this issue and seems determined to continue with the same attitude. I believe that it is important for the Government to do something about the road funding crisis. Last month, the Queensland Local Government Association convened a meeting attended by representatives of 12 organisations that have joined forces to oppose any further cuts in Commonwealth road funding allocations in the Government's May economic statement. Representatives from the following organisations were present at the meeting: the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland, the Main Roads Department, the Australian Roads Federation, the Queensland Road Transport Association Ltd, the Asphalt Pavement Association, the United Graziers Association of Queensland, the Queensland Graingrowers Association, the Queensland Canegrowers Council, the Municipal Officers Association of Australia, and the Australian Workers Union. This group represents a wide cross-section indeed of community, road construction, industry and employee bodies that are directly affected by fuel taxes and road construction activity. The meeting unanimously agreed that the cutback in the Commonwealth Government's allocation to road funding over the past four years has had serious consequences for the people of Queensland, and that further cuts would be neither reasonable nor acceptable.

The impact of the cuts to date can be summarised as follows: There is an inability to keep up with the demand for new and upgraded roads to cater for the needs of the transport industry and the individual motorist. The existing road networks are falling into disrepair because of the decline in maintenance allocations. There have been increased operating and maintenance costs for the transport industry and the private motorist because of declining road maintenance standards. Traffic black spots are not removed as quickly as they should be. These trouble spots occur because so many roads have become incapable of handling the increased traffic flows. Jobs have been lost in road construction and maintenance in both the public and private sectors. This has had a particularly detrimental effect on the economy of many provincial and rural centres.

It was resolved at this meeting that the following commitments should be sought from the Federal Government. The first commitment sought is that there will be no further reduction in the total current level of Commonwealth road expenditure-that is, $1,245m per annum. Federal spending on roads has been at the same level since 1984-85 but, when inflation is taken into account, we see that funding has declined by 25 per cent. In real terms, that works out to over $300m. The second commitment sought is that at least 6c per litre, and preferably 7.5c per litre, of the current fuel excise levy be dedicated for road construction and maintenance and that the amount be indexed. This increase is justified by the Local Government Association on the basis that it partially compensates for past failures to index fuel excise dedicated for roads. The third commitment sought is that road funding remain a special purpose grant and not be absorbed into the financial assistance grants paid to the State or local governments. This provision is essential to ensure that road users and all levels of government are aware of road funding allocations made from the fuel taxes collected by the Federal Government.

I was interested to read a report of an address given recently by the Queensland Commissioner for Main Roads, Mr Eric Finger, to 17 Burnett councillors at Nanango. He pointed out that the fund cutbacks by the Federal Government would affect upgrading and repairs to roads under Main Roads Department and local authority control. He said:
We will be struggling to maintain what we already have built and to keep up the rate of progress in upgrading main and shire roads.

I worked for the Main Roads Department over 35 years ago. I can remember driving around Queensland at that time and worrying about the roads and the need for money to make improvements to them. I can remember when the then Commissioner for Main Roads went up to Cooktown. He said that the road was too bad and that, as secretary, I could not possibly go. He would not take his wife, either, but he and others had to travel on the roads. Queensland is now reaching the stage where bitumen roads are being turned back to gravel roads because not enough funds are being made available for roadworks by the Federal Government.

Mr Finger said that Queensland's share of the fuel tax which the Federal Government put back into roads had been cut by 5 per cent to 16 per cent. A sum of $2m a year had also been cut off funds for local roads, money which councils spent. Mr Finger said that the decline in roads funds from the Federal Government had been a problem for Queensland for a number of years and was getting worse. The State Government had borrowed large amounts of money in recent years to bridge the gap between needs and what Canberra provided. Perhaps that is some of the loan money that the present Queensland Premier is saying he needs and is not being given permission by Canberra to get. Referring to the State Government loans, Mr Finger said:
Repaying those loans will take a lot in the next few years.

He went on to say that the State Government had taken action to help meet loan repayments by raising vehicle registration fees. He said he was aware that the Department and some local authorities had reduced roadwork staff because of the decline in road funds. He told the Burnett District Local Authorities Association delegates:
I can bring you no good news, only that there is a grim outlook ahead for both the Main Roads Department and local authorities for road building in the next few years.
Indeed, a councillor from Isis Shire Council, outside Bundaberg, said that it was time that local authorities started to fight for a fair share of road funds. He said:

Our roads are collapsing for need of funds, yet all we get from Canberra is bad news. People are being asked to put new cars on to second class roads because of Federal cutbacks in the share of fuel tax which goes to roads.

I believe that there is certainly a great need for this Government to ensure that it does not cut back funds any more. Indeed, it should make an increase in the funds available for road works, not just highway works but works throughout Queensland and, indeed, Australia.

The Royal Automobile Club of Queensland recently undertook a State-wide survey of roads and found that country roads are so rough that motorists often drive on the shoulders rather than on the potholed bitumen. Many roads become impassable when it rains, and roads are deteriorating more rapidly than city and shire councils can repair them. The Hawke Government has consistently refused to increase the level of funds made available to State governments to maintain and construct roads throughout the nation. It seems that the Government is happy enough to allocate funds for highways between major cities and provincial towns. The Government seems to think that highways are great vote catchers, but I understand that in future there is a possibility that even those roads will suffer under a Federal plan for a per capita funding system. The Queensland Minister for Main Roads, Mr Gunn, has stated that 2,000 Queenslanders will lose their jobs if that recommendation is adopted. A very serious situation is looming, not only in Queensland but throughout Australia, unless the road funding problem is addressed and resolved.

It is time that motorists were told the truth about the petrol taxes they pay: Every time a motorist pulls up at a petrol bowser, more than half the money spent on petrol goes to the Federal Government-indeed a great deal more than half, I might add. For every litre of petrol or diesel purchased, the Government takes about 30c in tax. During this financial year, motorists will pay more than $6.5 billion in petrol taxes. Their contributions rise in line with inflation, yet the Government has chosen to cut the funds allocated to building and upgrading roads. Funds allocated to the Australian land transport program have declined by 8 per cent and the highly publicised bicentennial roads development program has been cut back by $140m since 1984-85. When funds are reduced to such an extent, a greater financial strain is unfairly placed upon State and local government authorities. I say `unfairly' because, while the Federal Government continues to tax road users at such discriminatory levels, it must accept most of the responsibility for road funding.

The facts speak for themselves: Less than 20 per cent of all fuel tax collected by the Federal Government at the petrol bowser is returned to road funding. How is the Government getting away with such miserable treatment of the Australian motorist? During this financial year, fuel taxes will account for about 9 per cent of Federal Government revenue, yet road funding accounts for just 1.6 per cent of Federal Government expenditure and there is quite a difference between 9 per cent and 1.6 per cent. In real terms, it means that this financial year the Government will raise approximately $7 billion from fuel taxes, compared with $1.245 billion, which is the amount planned for expenditure on road construction and maintenance.

I am sorry to say that this Government seems to believe that there are votes only in major highways-not in the less important roads, and especially not in rural areas. Of course, that is a major complaint for those of us who represent huge States, and Queensland is, as I have noted on many occasions, seven times the size of Victoria.

Roads provide lines of communication; they are the arteries for the transport of people and produce. Many people living in the outback use a far greater amount of fuel than urban dwellers and consequently they pay a greater amount of fuel tax, yet their roads are probably the worst in Australia. Good, safe roads are vitally important to country people and the motor vehicle is often their most effective and immediate mode of communication with the outside world. If their incomes were better they might be able to afford aeroplanes to fly to their destinations and would not have to drive on the roads, and I would not blame them for that. Regrettably, the further west one ventures the worse one finds the state of the roads.

A fairer proportion of fuel revenue must be set aside for roads. Motorists have, unfortunately, become the milking cow for the nation, and I am sorry to say that a very meagre proportion of funds milked in the form of fuel excise actually benefit the average motorist. In fact, things have become so bad in my area of South Burnett in Queensland that the local councils decided to place a cartoon in our local newspaper. The cartoon is headed `Guess who's ripping us off?' and it shows the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talking to one another at the `Labor Servus Station', a petrol station. Mr Hawke is saying to Mr Keating, `So out of 30.5c excise--'; Mr Keating then interjects and says, `We'll keep 25c and give `em 5.5c for roads. What more could they want?'. In fact, I suggest that they want a lot more than that.

We need good roads throughout Queensland and I suggest that all senators in this chamber would say that they also need good roads in their States. Councils need funds to keep their road gangs employed. We need good roads to assist tourism in Queensland and I am sure that Senator Reynolds, who is present in the chamber at the moment, would agree with that. We need good roads for transporting the grain harvest and cattle and for all other industries which rely so heavily on road transport. The maintenance of existing roads is certainly a real headache. I feel quite sure that everybody in the Senate, particularly senators from both sides of the chamber who represent Queensland, would hope that when the present road programs are completed the Government will see its way clear to making further funds available for roads. Indeed, I believe that that hope would be shared by senators from all States of Australia.

I recently asked the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) whether he could explain to the Senate why the percentage of fuel tax revenue which is spent on improving roads had dropped from 67 per cent in 1984-85 to 27 per cent in 1987-88, when the tax on fuel is automatically increased in line with the consumer price index, and I asked that he give an assurance that the percentage of fuel tax revenue allocated to all roads, not just highways, would be increased from the present 5.355c a litre to at least 7c a litre to enable the condition of country roads throughout Australia to be improved. I certainly hope that we see this increase in the May statement rather than have so much money put into Consolidated Revenue. I think that that is very important indeed. Those who use fuel and are thereby forced to pay the Government's fuel tax should be able to expect a fairer share of revenue in the form of safer, well maintained roads. I hope we see that when the May statement is brought down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88, the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 which the Senate is debating cognately today allocate funds, as Senator Stone mentioned at the beginning of his contribution, to meet needs associated with departmental expenditure. They are funds additional to those appropriated in the Appropriation Bills passed in the 1987 Budget session. The autumn Budget session of this Parliament appropriates funding through Appropriation Bills to make up the total parliamentary approved expenditure of the government of the day. It is this expenditure that is eyed off by groups such as the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Council of Social Service, the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Chamber of Commerce, the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled and any of a plethora of interest groups that represent specific people in the community when they call for decreased, increased or varied government expenditure. The Business Council of Australia and other groups which purport to represent-although I am not sure that they actually do-the interests of business and industry in this country are particularly vocal when it comes to demanding on an almost, and quite depressingly, weekly basis through the newspapers and radio that this Government, and indeed all governments, reduce spending.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two interesting facets in these demands by groups such as the Business Council of Australia or individuals such as John Elliott. First of all, they never call for extensive cuts in corporate welfare. They only ever demand extensive cuts in social welfare. Secondly, having called for cuts in the areas of social welfare expenditure, health, social security, education and so on, they do not ever say what services have to be reduced. In other words, having called for the Government to cut its spending programs in the areas of social security payments, health care and education funding, they do not then bite the appropriate bullet and say in which areas those cuts should be made.

So we hear honourable senators in this place in one breath demanding that governments cut expenditure and, in the other breath, demanding that there be increased spending in their particular pet areas, such as assistance to people with disabilities as argued by Senator Calvert. I will not argue with that nor will I argue with the legitimacy of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's recent contribution in demanding that there be more appropriate road funding. What I am saying is that we cannot have the continual hypocrisy from groups such as the Business Council of Australia or people such as John Elliott or anybody else in claiming that there must be massive cuts but then either asking for increased expenditure in their pet areas or refusing to say where those cuts should be made. This is hypocritical. It is also cowardly and it is matched by their arguments that these cuts in spending on health, social security and education should, in justice, finance corporate tax cuts which they say, quite untruthfully, are higher in Australia than in any comparable Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) country. It is important that these headline grabbing claims be examined in some detail because we are faced with not only the credibility of people making such claims but also the damage that can be done to Australian families, ordinary individuals in this country and to people in need if the claims are accepted by governments and acted upon.

Let me take first of all the claim that Australia is a highly taxed country. Anybody who has looked at the 1987 OECD figures will be aware that really only Turkey offers a significantly better tax deal than Australia. There are a couple of other countries that are marginally more generous than Australia through the tax system, but Turkey is the only one with really a significantly better tax structure. I would say that Turkey offers other problems to corporations or individuals who wish to take themselves out of Australia and find a better tax deal. In the area of corporate tax alone, as distinct from the general burden of taxation in this country, few comparable countries have significantly lower tax rates. It is easy to see why this is so. A quick look at a recent issue of Australian Business magazine dated 11 May 1988, which touts itself as a collector's item because it lists the top 500 companies, is very revealing.

According to this issue, some of Australia's biggest companies pay less tax than the average pensioner and certainly much less than families struggling to survive on average weekly earnings or less. Companies such as Elders IXL Ltd are paying tax of 10.5c in the dollar, Brierley Investments 10.8c, News Corporation 17.7c, Fletcher Challenge, a New Zealand based group, 19.8c, BP Australia Ltd 2.3c, IEL 4.1c, the Bond Corporation 8.9c, the Bell Group 10.5 and Ansett Transport Industries 14.3c. Given those sorts of figures of tax paid by some of the top 500-I might add that all of those companies are in the top 50-it is quite outrageous that so much attention, credence and credibility is given to the sweeping statements by the managing directors and chief executives of these sorts of companies, all demanding that governments cut spending on the poor and on Australian families generally in order to give these companies an even smaller tax commitment. In most cases, they are paying less than 15c in the dollar when the nominal company tax rate is 49c in the dollar. They want spending cuts so that corporate tax rates can be reduced, which will presumably then see them paying less than 5c or so in the dollar in tax on a regular basis.

However, as I said earlier, what is worse is that these people never specify who is to be further disadvantaged. They specify who is to be advantaged. They say, `We will cut government expenditure in the health, social security and education sectors and we can then reduce company tax and the top marginal tax rate for high income earners'. But they never then turn around and say who will be actually disadvantaged, who will lose out, where the hard decisions will be made and who makes them when spending cuts of the sort they call for are implemented.

For example, health care cuts are high on the list of those areas that some big business people and people in Opposition parties would like to see cut. Who will lose out? I venture to say that even if they did make some suggestions about who would not have access to health care treatment-one cannot cut health care funding and still allow unlimited access to health care treatment-it would not be those highly paid executives who are demanding spending cuts, but who also want full access to health treatment for their frequently self-inflicted diseases and illnesses resulting from stress and from over-indulgence in tobacco and alcohol. They will not want the so-called blow-out in the health care budget to be reduced by cutting their access to health care treatment. So they must therefore want cuts in other areas. Will they therefore suggest that the Government cut the health care funding budget and, in doing so, reduce access to benefits such as hip replacements for elderly women, cancer treatments for young children and life support systems for very premature babies? All I want is to hear from these same people who are demanding cuts in health care the areas in which they would like to see access reduced.

We get the same lack of detail in calls for cuts in social security expenditure. We need to note here that the Labor Government with, I might add, the full support of every Liberal and National Party senator who was here at the time, has already reduced the living standards and disposable income of people such as ex-service men and women by cutting their pensions by 2 per cent and low income families who have 15-year-old children in the last two non-compulsory years of school-that is, years 11 and 12-by removing their access to Austudy. We have seen widows on class B pensions required at the age of 45 or when their youngest child turns 16, to go off the class B widow's pension and on to unemployment benefits or go out and get a job. Every one of the businessmen-it is businessmen in the main who are demanding these sorts of cuts-are the ones who would refuse to employ a 45-year-old woman who has been out of the work force for 20 or more years because they give no acknowledgment to the managerial and other skills that a woman develops over that period in running a home, in budgeting, in keeping everybody's ego in place within the family and generally acting as a public relations and personnel officer in the household. Those women will not get jobs easily and yet their standard of living has been reduced by having the widow's class B pension taken away from them. Their self-esteem has been reduced because they are now forced on to unemployment lines at the Commonwealth Employment Service on a regular basis because the jobs are not out there in the community for them.

Given that those cuts have already been made, where else do people such as John Elliott and groups such as the Business Council of Australia, the National Farmers Federation and the chambers of commerce around the country want cuts to be made?
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STATE GOVERNMENT INSURANCE COMMISSION OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the Minister's comment yesterday that, while the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) is investigating the Bell-Bond-State Government Insurance Commission (SGIC) of Western Australia deals, it would be inappropriate for him to make any comment on particular matters raised in questions last week from Senator Lewis, Senator Hill and me. Meanwhile, he said that the NCSC had been asked to keep the Attorney-General's Department informed of any developments. Is the Minister aware that a spokesman for the NCSC was quoted in last Monday's Australian Financial Review on several aspects of these matters? If it is appropriate for the media to be given such information, and given that the NCSC is keeping the Attorney-General's Department informed, I ask the Minister: First, is it a fact that the State Government Insurance Commission of Western Australia sought a guarantee of confidentiality before agreeing to supply the NCSC with answers to a second set of questions about its Bell share purchase and $150m underwriting agreement? Secondly, has that guarantee been given and, whether it has or not, have the answers been provided to the NCSC? Thirdly, if no answers have been forthcoming from the SGIC of Western Australia, and if lack of cooperation is hindering the investigation, what action has the Government taken or will it take, including by way of a direct approach to the Western Australian Government, to ensure the cooperation of the SGIC in resolving the current uncertainties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the article in which certain comments were attributed to an NCSC spokesman, as reported, apparently, in last Monday's Australian Financial Review. As a result, I believe, of the questions that have been asked in the Parliament, including the Attorney-General's response yesterday to certain questions in another place, the NCSC has provided the Government with information on the steps it is pursuing. Honourable senators will appreciate that, as I emphasised in my answer and as the Attorney emphasised yesterday, neither of us-certainly not the Attorney-is in a position of direct ministerial responsibility for the NCSC. A peculiarly difficult situation is created in that the body is answerable to a ministerial council of which the Attorney is a member. Nevertheless, the Government has been advised of details of questions which the NCSC has put to the parties to the share sales and of matters upon which the NCSC has sought counsel's opinion. However, at the moment I am not prepared to prejudice NCSC investigations by disclosing further details of the NCSC's intended course of action.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question whether certain guarantees were sought by the State Government Insurance Commission before it would answer certain questions, I will refer that matter and see whether the NCSC is willing to give any reply at this stage, given the fact that, as I have said, there are certain intended courses of action and it is very desirable that they not be prejudiced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his response and the spirit in which it was provided. I ask whether he is in a position to provide the Senate with any indication of when he will be in a position to give the Senate further information arising out of the information with which, I understand, he and the Attorney-General have now been provided by the NCSC.

—I am not in a position to do so. As the honourable senator will understand, the NCSC has many courses of action open to it. Until it has resolved what course to take, I certainly cannot set a date as to when that might be. In accordance with the convoluted provision for ministerial responsibility-in other words, taking into account the views of the Ministerial Council-no doubt as much information as possible will be made available to the Parliament.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Home Affairs, who is responsible for electoral matters. I ask the Minister whether his attention has been drawn to a statement made on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation last night by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, in the context of an interview on the Government's referendum proposal for one vote one value, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . were I a member of the Queensland Liberal Party I would be arguing very hard with them for a State electoral system that was fairer.

Did the Government give any consideration to achieving Senator Chaney's aim of a fairer electoral system for Queensland by legislative means rather than by an amendment to the Australian Constitution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Macklin first introduced his Bill into this chamber to use the legislative route, I think it was the intention of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to look at the legal arguments rather than at just the technicality of the Bill. However, over time and for a variety of reasons, such as the change of personnel, that was never pursued. However, it had been thought by many people in Queensland that the Commonwealth could use its external affairs powers under the Constitution to legislate against State malapportionment and gerrymandering. That would be based on one of the international covenants to which we are signatories. If the definition in those covenants is for universal suffrage, it would not necessarily translate, I would think, in a High Court case to mean one vote one value. One has to go back to the travois explanataire-the explanatory notes-of that international convention to see whether it meant one vote one value.

ANSWER.PARA: A variety of legal opinions have crossed my desk-none of which have been commissioned by the Government, I might add-from people seeking those views. The overwhelming majority of those views came down on the side that a challenge to any Commonwealth legislation would succeed in the High Court. I saw only one opinion to the contrary, which was a well-written opinion by Mr Fitzgerald, QC, from Queensland, which contained one false assumption, but the rest of it argued very cogently that the Commonwealth did have the power. There is no doubt that, at the end of the day, the Government decided that it did not have the power under the external affairs provision, that it would be wrong to proceed in that way and that the more appropriate method of proceeding would be to take it as a referendum.

It is a great pity that, through an accident of birth, we will not have the persuasive powers of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate supporting us on this occasion. Apparently, that historical accident is accounted for by only about 3,000 miles. I am disappointed that some Western Australian Liberals will not support the referendum proposal. They have had ample opportunity in the last three or four years to solve the malapportionment issue in Western Australia. Electoral reform Bills have been sent to the malapportioned and gerrymandered Legislative Council, which is dominated by the Liberal and National parties, and been rejected. Those Bills would have fixed up the problem. The same opportunity applied when the Liberals were in government in Queensland. If they had had any spine or intestinal fortitude, those issues could have been solved and it would not have been necessary to take the action which the Government is now taking to hold a referendum. However, I live in hope that those opposite will see the light. As I have said, I did note Senator Chaney's comments last night that if he were a member of the Queensland Liberal Party he would be arguing for a fairer system. We all know that Senator Chaney would like to be Prime Minister. We all know that he is looking for a lower House seat. Maybe we will be lucky in the next four or five months; he may finally end his search in Queensland and be endorsed for a Queensland Federal seat. If that happens, I will say, `Welcome, comrade. Come to our side and we will argue the case together'. Obviously, if that search fails and he has to end up in New South Wales or Victoria, Senator Chaney will remain an unremitting enemy of one vote one value.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the articles in Monday's and yesterday's Australian Financial Review concerning an audit being undertaken into Aussat Pty Ltd and the tendering procedures for the second generation of Aussat satellites. Has the Minister in fact ordered such an audit and how extensive will it be? Will the audit be examining the tendering and administration procedures for the first generation of Aussat satellites? If not, why not? Was the decision to undertake an audit of Aussat made only on the basis of the internal investigations which are being conducted into the Hughes Aircraft Corporation regarding allegations about improper payments being made to Intelsat or its officials in relation to the awarding of satellite contracts? Further, is the Government considering any change to the timing of its decision on the contract award for the second generation of Aussat satellites?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case, as we have all seen, that there has been widespread speculation that the resignation of the Chairman of the Hughes Aircraft Corporation, Dr Albert Wheelon, may be related to an examination of whether improper payments were made to Intelsat or its officials in connection with the winning of contracts in past years by Hughes. It is also the case that Hughes was the successful tenderer for the first generation of Aussat satellites and is one of the tenderers for the second generation now being considered.

ANSWER.PARA: While there has been absolutely no suggestion of any improper dealing in the Aussat tendering process, either on the present occasion or for the first generation satellites, Aussat itself suggested to me, through its Chairman, that in order to avoid delays in awarding tenders for its second generation satellite system, an immediate independent review of tendering procedures be conducted to provide the necessary assurances that the United States investigations have no relevance to Australia. The Auditor-General, as part of his normal planned program, will this week be beginning an audit of Aussat and this will include a review of contract administration that will in turn include Aussat's tender processes. This seemed to me, the Government and Aussat itself to be an appropriate form of independent review. A copy of the Auditor-General's report will be made available to me as soon as it is completed. There is no change proposed to the timing of the consideration of the tender process at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In asking the question, I would thank the Minister for the answer yesterday to my question on notice concerning domestic air travel per head of population in three large countries-Australia, Canada and the United States of America. Does the 1986 figure of 0.8 domestic air trips per head of population per annum in Australia compared with 1.7 trips in the United States, indicate that the domestic airline industry in Australia is relatively underdeveloped? What factors could explain the fact that United States air trips per capita are more than double Australian trips? Do the lower per capita figures for Australia confirm claims in the Australian community that domestic air fares are too high and choke off air travel by many potential travellers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a whole variety of reasons which could account for the apparent differences in the number of domestic air trips on a per capita basis as between the United States and Australia. There is the different geographic distribution of the two populations; questions about propensity to travel by car or bus; frequency of service; income levels; purpose of air travel such as business, holiday or visiting friends and relatives; and, of course, the levels and conditions attached to discount air fares. There is no question but that the level of air fares and the conditions associated with those fares are two of the key determinants in tapping the potential market for air travel.

ANSWER.PARA: The May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation noted that the current regulatory arrangements do appear to encourage the major airlines to concentrate on a relatively small proportion of the market, particularly the high yield full fare business traveller. In the absence of prices competition and with tight capacity controls, as there are under the present two-airline policy, it is hardly surprising that the airlines tend currently to place great emphasis on competing really only through standards of service.

Coming to the question of specific comparisons with the United States, obviously any comparison with overseas air fares should be viewed with extreme caution. Typically, Australian fares compare more favourably against United States fares that are offered by major and former local service carriers in markets where these carriers encounter little or no competition. Where competition in the United States is strong, on the other hand, Australian airline prices tend to be higher than those fares that are offered in those kinds of competitive markets.

On the basis of overseas experience, the major impact on services in the deregulated airline environment that will exist after 1990 in this country seems likely to be on the availability and use of discount fares and, hence, on the level of average fare that is paid. The simple truth of the matter is that discounts in Australia are not as widely used as they are in the United States where over 90 per cent of all passengers use some form of discount fare. In Australia, less than 50 per cent of all air travellers use discount fares, suggesting that many Australian consumers either see the conditions imposed on discount fares as being too restrictive or, alternatively, are unaware that discount fares are available because they are not promoted as vigorously as is the case in countries such as the United States. There has been some greater disposition in recent times for the airlines to recognise that absence of awareness and do some greater promotion. But we cannot expect, I suspect, that phenomenon really to emerge in the marketplace until deregulation comes about in 1990.

As I have said on many occasions, the objectives of bringing the two-airline policy to a close are to ensure not only increased competition and pricing flexibility, leading to greater economic efficiency in the industry, but also increased responsiveness by airlines to consumer needs and, particularly in the context of this question, a wider range of fares and types of services to provide enhanced travel opportunity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask whether the Minister, on behalf of the Government, will re-affirm the Prime Minister's promise of 7 July 1987, namely:

QUESTION.PARA: You have my undertaking we will not introduce a gold tax during the next three-year term of the Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is one of those questions where I say I neither confirm nor deny. Certainly I cannot deny the Prime Minister's letter of a particular date which has been published on numerous occasions in the Australian Financial Review and in other newspapers. But I think it would be advisable for honourable senators to wait and see. If the Government reaches a decision on this matter, they should wait and see what the decision is.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to reports in the media about a shift in the Opposition's policy on immigration. In those reports the Opposition appears to have broken with the bipartisan approach on immigration policy and opted for a vast increase in wealthy migrants at the expense of family reunions. Does the Minister agree that such a step would be heartless as well as leading to a less effective immigration policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly agree that the step taken by the Leader of the Opposition at the weekend to turn back the clock by some considerable time in regard to a bipartisan approach to immigration is of very grave concern. Not only has he substantially upset and confused many people in the community but he patently is not well aware of his facts in relation to immigration policy and procedures. I suppose, as the Minister responsible in the other place, the Hon. Clyde Holding, said yesterday, the kindest thing that could be said of the Leader of the Opposition is that he has an ongoing numeracy problem-a problem that was raised in the context of the last election. This time the Leader of the Opposition claimed in his statement that in the five years to 1986-87 family reunion had risen from 17 per cent to 50 per cent of the migrant intake while skilled and business migrant intake fell from 46 per cent to 17 per cent. Mr Holding responded when he was first confronted with these figures by expressing some considerable doubts about their accuracy. He asked his Department to find the correct figures. The Department has informed him that the Opposition figures for family reunion in 1981-82 exclude brothers and sisters and more distant relations-over 20 per cent of the intake in that year-but that they were included in the figures for 1986-87. As has been raised in debate in the other place, obviously there is a great deal of confusion in the mind of the Leader of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that it is very unfortunate that the bipartisan approach to immigration appears to have broken down. I maintained only a month or so ago that I was confident that it would not break down because of the very fair, equitable and sensible approach of Opposition members in relation to immigration. I cited Senator Jim Short and Senator the Hon. Fred Chaney in this regard. I really believed that we could maintain a bipartisan approach to immigration. We had heard Senator Stone and others raising some doubts about their commitment. But, on balance, we believed-I genuinely believed-that the bipartisan policy would be maintained. After the last 24 hours, one seriously has to doubt whether this is possible. However, given that the Opposition changes its mind on many occasions and that it could be prepared to sit down and sensibly rethink its policies in relation to their impact on the community at large, I suppose that there is still some chance for the more informed members of the Opposition to influence its policy in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Has the Minister read the article in the June edition of Australian Investment entitled `Defence Forces Super-It's Scandal'? Is it the case that, unlike contributions to the Commonwealth Public Service superannuation scheme, which go into an investment trust, Defence Force superannuation payments are absorbed directly into Consolidated Revenue, and if members of the Defence Force decide to leave before completing 20 years service, their contributions are returned to them with no interest, meaning that they are, in effect, giving the Government a subsidised loan through their superannuation contributions? If this is the case, has the Government considered that this grossly unfair treatment of Defence Force personnel, coupled with the continuing 2 per cent discount penalty on defence pensions, may be one strong contributing factor to the current low level of Defence Force and veteran community morale? Will the Government change the way these funds are handled to give our Defence Force personnel a more equitable superannuation deal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the article referred to by Senator McLean. It is the case that contributions to the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme are paid to Consolidated Revenue and are not invested. This arrangement is in accordance with the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Legislation, known otherwise as the Jess Committee, an all-party committee of the Parliament which in 1970 to 1972 inquired into the retirement benefits for the Defence Force. The reasons given by the Committee for not supporting the payment of interest included that a substantial increase in overall costs would result, interest might lead to increased withdrawals, further adding to the drain on the scheme, and, finally, the member leaving without pension received ample consideration for his or her contributions in the form of insurance type protection in the event of death in service and a pension in case of invalidity retirement. The present arrangements reflect the recommendations of that Joint Select Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: If interest on contributions were introduced, it would impact on both pensionable and non-pensionable personnel. It would add to the cost of the scheme, which in 1986-87 cost $319m in net terms, after deducting contributions paid to Consolidated Revenue. The reduction of 2 per cent in updating pensions in 1986-87 applied to both that scheme and the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. It was based on the principle that all sectors of the community should share in the economic restraint that the Government had called for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: In view of the fact that 78 per cent of those people serving in the forces leave the forces before completing their 20-year term of service, does it not follow that those personnel in fact suffer under this program in that they get a refund only of their contributions, without any interest whatsoever, and that the program constitutes a $75m per annum interest-free loan to the Government?

—I think what was in the mind of the Joint Select Committee at the time it made those recommendations-I think unanimously-which were adopted by the Government, was that the whole area had to be looked at as a compact and not as individual areas. In some ways the ultimate retirement pension benefit for service people is far in excess of the Commonwealth Public Service schemes. Therefore, when looking at the thing in totality, that was regarded as a balance at the time. I will draw the Minister's attention to the implied views put here today. I will see whether she wants to add anything further to the answer.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. The Minister would perhaps know that Senator Vanstone was reported recently as saying that she and the Opposition do not place much store on the Government's commitment to women's health and its draft health policy in view of its taking genital warts from the medical benefits schedule. Will the Minister explain, firstly, that women's health encompasses more than genital warts and, secondly, what the Government has done regarding the provision of treatment for genital warts for women? Thirdly, will the Minister also remind the Senate of the Government's commitment to women's health and its health policy for all women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to that part of the question which referred to women's health encompassing more than genital warts, the need for a national women's health policy is clearly demonstrated by the types of comments made by Senator Vanstone. It comes from a recognition that we need to move towards prevention in the provision of health care services and away from a narrow focus on health care as being solely about the provision of treatment for illness. Women's health is not a matter of concentrating on treating illnesses experienced by women. It is about a holistic approach to health care with the emphasis on prevention.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of Senator Crowley's question asked what the Government was doing about the provision of treatment for women who have genital warts. Senator Vanstone was referring to the removal from the medical benefits schedule of items relating to the removal of warts generally. There has never been an item specific to the removal of genital warts. Although the items relating to the removal of warts have been deleted, the procedure still attracts a benefit on an attendance basis. In addition, there is an item in the schedule to cover circumstances when a more complex procedure is undertaken. Item No. 3004 is described as:
Operative procedure on tissue, organ or region not covered by any other item in this part, including any consultation on the same occasion.

To make a claim under this item, practitioners must make application through the Health Insurance Commission to the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee-the MBAC-seeking an increased fee. The MBAC has considered a number of applications relating to the removal of genital warts and approved payment of benefits based on those applications under section 11 of the Health Insurance Act. Consideration has been given to creating a specific item for treatment of warts where the complexity of a procedure is such that the benefit on an attendance basis is inadequate, for example, where general or regional anaesthesia and admission to hospital are required.

As to the third part of the question about women's health, let me elaborate on the Government's policy. In June 1987 a special consultant on women's health was appointed by the Minister for Community Services and Health to coordinate the development of a national policy. The consultant has recently released a discussion paper which is the first stage in the development of the national policy. This paper sets out preliminary thinking on the principles of a national policy and possible strategies which will address women's express concerns. The recently released report on health targets for Australia has drawn attention to the link between socioeconomic status and health. As the majority of adult poor in Australia are women there is a need to focus on the health of women as a disadvantaged group if we are going to address the inequities in health status in our society. As part of the Government's commitment to prevention in health care for women it has committed $5.1m over three years to pilot projects for screening for breast and cervical cancer.
