These projects will improve the uptake of pap smear screening for cervical cancer and assist in the development of mammographic screening for breast cancer. This initiative in prevention of cervical cancer is particularly significant in relation to the treatment of genital warts. Some types of human papilloma virus, the same virus that causes genital warts, has a strong association with cervical cancer. The Government is particularly interested in the prevention of cervical cancer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the Minister confirm that the existing wage guidelines laid down by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the March 1987 decision will continue in force until such time as the Commission completes its review of the wage fixing principles? Is it a fact that the review is only about to begin and there is no certainty about how long it will take until any new wages package is decided? Is it also a fact that an important part of the existing package is a requirement that unions do not pursue any extra claims? Does the Minister agree that the industry by industry pay push orchestrated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) which has seen claims in the order of 6 per cent lodged in a wide range of vital industries, often accompanied by the threat of industrial action, is in breach of the no extra claims commitment? I ask what the Government is doing to counter that strategy, which is so clearly aimed at undermining the forthcoming wages review.

—I am not able to answer all the question but the answer to the first part is yes, the March 1987 guidelines apply, as Senator Chaney suggested in his question. Secondly, it is true that the review by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of the new wages system is about to begin. Thirdly, it is correct that unions in some industries have lodged claims which I suppose might be said to be technically in breach of the provisions in the current guidelines to which Senator Chaney referred at the start of his question. I would query whether the union claims that Senator Chaney mentioned are designed to influence the course of the review. I think they are designed-perhaps it is not for me to say what they are designed for-to ensure that the unions in question after the review has been completed have a claim in position which can be dealt with as expeditiously as possible. But there may be other aspects of the question which I should direct to the Minister and I will do that.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer but it is a bit puzzling. I remind him that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, said just a few days ago that the Government did not want any deals struck that might pre-empt the outcome of the review which is properly the responsibility of the Arbitration Commission to determine. I remind the Minister that the employers have in fact threatened to quit the system as a result of the campaign currently being waged. In the light of those two facts I ask the Minister whether he agrees that what is being done by the unions in specific industry sectors is in fact an attempt to pre-empt the review and present the Arbitration Commission with concluded agreements between the trade unions involved and the employers for wage rises in the order of 6 per cent, and is he alleging that could be achieved without imposing any distortion on the wage fixing principles which are to be considered and determined in the May hearing?

—I am not able to say whether it is an attempt to pre-empt. I honestly cannot answer that part of the question. I think the 6 per cent claims have probably been lodged in the context of believing that the position of the Government and of the ACTU would be that the claims should be dealt with next year on the basis of movements and anticipated movements in the consumer price index. That is probably the basis of the 6 per cent figure but I cannot say with any certainty.
—But the unions have actually made an agreement with the building construction contractors on a productivity contract.
—The way Senator Chaney puts it is interesting: `the unions have actually made an agreement with the building construction contractors'. It can be put around the other way.
—They have obtained an agreement.

—No, not in the building industry. I do not agree with the honourable senator's terminology `obtained an agreement'. An agreement has been made, as I understand it, in the building industry but I am not familiar with the details of that agreement and it would seem to be somewhat premature. That is the only comment I can make.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Can she say how extensive was the water damage to the contents of the Australian War Memorial after the accident last night? Which exhibits sustained the most damage? Will the Government give priority to funding for the restoration of these irreplaceable pieces of Australia's history?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is believed that a plumbing malfunction in the Memorial tower caused a fire protection sprinkler head to activate and this resulted in the building being flooded, as Senator Childs has indicated. The Memorial's counter-disaster plan was put into action immediately and the flooding was contained by staff, the fire brigade and the Australian Capital Territory Emergency Service. I am advised that the major area of concern is the collection of First World War and Second World War diaries. There has been some slight water damage to parts of the collection but no material has been lost. The same can be said for all of the Memorial's irreplaceable records. Carpets and storage units also suffered damage but this will not cause any major disruption to the Memorial's activities. The research centre is closed until the end of this week but the galleries remain open.

ANSWER.PARA: While there have been other incidents of flooding in the past it should be stressed that this situation is unrelated to those incidents. One, for example, was as a result of heavy rain, and additional guttering was installed to overcome that problem. On another occasion there was a burst water pipe, caused by an outside contractor. The current incident is not the result of insufficient funding for the Memorial. The first stage of an air-conditioning system which will replace the current water-operated system and its associated pipe work has been installed, and stages 2 and 3 are planned for 1988-89 and 1989-90. On completion of this project the risk of a similar incident occurring will be minimal.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Does the Minister recall that some weeks ago I asked him a general question concerning the links between organised crime, corruption and vice? Does he also recall that in his answer he indicated that he could not grasp the particularity of what I was seeking? I now ask the Minister whether, during the term of the Hawke Government and prior to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, any Federal Minister having relevant portfolio responsibility for the Australian Federal Police and policing generally as it relates to the States was alerted in writing by a senior officer to the need for an inquiry into the links between organised crime, corruption and vice? If so, what action has been taken in response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the question and I recall seeking to divine what exactly might be sought by the honourable senator in that question. I must say that her second question is almost as vague as that which was asked some weeks ago. I will undertake a further review of the files available to me to see whether such an alerting in writing, as the honourable senator puts it, was made by some senior officer to a responsible Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: I think I indicated at the time that the matters which Senator Newman was concerned about, namely, the links between organised crime, gambling and vice, generally speaking fall within the jurisdiction of States and the Northern Territory. In that situation, the scope for action by the Federal Government is somewhat limited, and I think I indicated would probably be most appropriately dealt with, because of the State connections, by the National Crime Authority. Its charter, as set out in the statute passed by this Parliament enables it to examine questions of organised crime to do with vice.

It was my recollection that, for example, in the latest round of deliberations and consultations by the National Crime Authority to ascertain what reference might be undertaken-this was the subject of discussions in Hobart late last year-the particular question of vice and gambling and the relationship with organised crime was not put very strongly by any of the State jurisdictions as something which should take priority. In fact, I cannot remember it being put at all. I will have another look at the files and see whether, with the slightly more particular question put by Senator Newman, we can discover what she is after.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HELSHAM COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE LEMONTHYME AND SOUTHERN FORESTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is it a fact that consultants to the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests included Mr John Quick, a former Commissioner of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission, who has publicly stated that `we cannot afford to lock up a single hectare of forest'? Is it also a fact that another paid consultant was Evan Shield, Deputy Logging Manager of Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd until 1981, who was later hired by the National Party of Australia and the Queensland timber industry to campaign politically against World Heritage listings in the wet tropics? Was another consultant a Mr David Trebeck, a former rural affairs adviser to the Liberal Party of Australia and an officer of the National Farmers Federation, an organisation which is spending large sums of money in opposing World Heritage listings? If so, who hired these men and why was there no public cross-examination of their input or public examination of the secret meeting between the Commission of Inquiry and counsel for the Tasmanian Forestry Commission in early December 1987? Given the suspicious circumstances surrounding evaluation of evidence, does the Minister agree that the findings of the Helsham inquiry are fatally flawed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Helsham inquiry employed quite a number of consultants, about 17 in all. I note with interest Senator Sanders's comments about a number of them. However, I do not believe that it would be appropriate for me to comment on the Helsham report at this stage. It was tabled only yesterday. It was tabled for the purpose of enabling public debate and comment upon it, and after a reasonable period for that debate and comment the Government will make its decision. When it has made its decision, I will be more than happy to comment. I do not believe that anything beyond that that I say in the interim would be helpful

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, follows his statement to the Senate today that the priority for the Government's national health policy is disease prevention. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statements by Dr Ditta Bartels, a Sydney molecular biologist, to the Australia and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference, that quality controlled babies produced through genetic engineering may soon become the norm and that a new technique would allow genetically defective embryos or those of the wrong sex to be discarded before they were implanted in the uterus? What taxpayers' funds are going towards the diagnostic techniques and proposals for the establishment of genetic registers of persons and families with histories of genetic disorders which would be essential in the establishment of such a filtering system for humans? If tax- payers' money is going towards this, in the case of genetic diseases does the Government's policy of disease prevention really mean prevention of individuals with genetic diseases from being born?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted three parts to the question from Senator Harradine. The last one was about the Government's general approach to health care and disease prevention. Of course, on that front the Government has, as I said in an answer earlier today, a holistic approach and an approach which emphasises preventive practices rather than treatment of diseases after the event. In particular, I draw attention to answers to questions that I have given earlier in the Senate about campaigns to encourage people to reduce alcohol intake and to disengage from other health damaging practices.

ANSWER.PARA: But that, I understand, is not the thrust of this question. Senator Harradine is once again pursuing a series of questions which he takes extremely seriously and which of themselves are important. I do not wish to diminish that importance but they are a standard set of questions from Senator Harradine. I do not have answers to all three parts of the question that I can give Senator Harradine now. I will put those matters on notice. But I should say in respect of the second part of the question, as to the amount of taxpayers' money that is going into setting up a register of genetic disorders, that I think underlying that question is an imputation which I do not accept on behalf of the Government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HELSHAM COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE LEMONTHYME AND SOUTHERN FORESTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In view of the despicable attempts at character assassination of two members of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests, can the Minister advise whether the capabilities and integrity of all members of the Commission were investigated prior to their appointment? Can he confirm that the members had and have retained the support of the Government and that the Government totally dissociates itself from the scurrilous attacks that have come from both inside and outside the Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall that in giving an answer in the Senate last year I said that I believed that we had in the three commissioners a competent and capable team. There is no reason for me to resile from what I said then. I am not sure what sort of lengthy investigation was carried out into their integrity, but I have no doubt as to their integrity and I think the Government is of the same view. I hope that we do not confuse in a democracy the right to disagree with the right to challenge integrity. There is no doubt that over the coming weeks some of the majority findings of that Commission and, indeed, the minority report, will come under considerable attack from both sides of the argument. I hope that at no stage will anyone criticise the commissioners' integrity, but we are, of course, all entitled to query whether we agree with the reports that they have brought down.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister's answer also cover the commissioners' competence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of competence is one that will always be up for debate. While everyone in the Senate is no doubt a person of integrity, I have heard at times the competence of a number of us brought into question. I would have thought that in a democracy it would be very difficult to prevent that from going on.

—I ask the Minister for Finance: Has he seen a media release put out by the National Priorities Project 1988 proposing a $10 billion per annum privatisation program? What is the value of the Commonwealth's investment in its government enterprises? For how many years could a $10 billion per annum privatisation program run? Will the Government consider pursuing such a program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Press release put out by the National Priorities Project (NPP). It might make more sense to those people who are not already aware of this if I identify some of the people associated with that group. There are Professors Porter, Cliff Walsh, and Freebairn as well as one or two others that I cannot remember at this point, but they are well known names. The Press release does indeed say that tax cuts can be financed by `a $10 billion per annum privatisation program'. That is either a misprint or Professors Freebairn, Porter and Walsh are off with the fairies-like the Liberals were in the run-up to the last election campaign and, to a substantial extent, still are. If it is not a misprint, what the NPP group is advocating is a big boost in the short term in personal consumption levels, financed by big tax cuts, relying on the sale of assets, which at that rate could not last for very much longer than one year. It would be a great final binge or splurge, I suppose, similar to what the Liberal Party of Australia was proposing six or eight months ago which, substantially, it is still doing.

ANSWER.PARA: The full valuation of Commonwealth Government owned enterprises of course does entail elements of judgment. In the guidelines for statutory authorities and business enterprises which I tabled towards the end of last year it was noted that at the end of June 1986 the book value of the Commonwealth's holdings of loans and equity capital in its 16 largest enterprises was just over $12 billion. It is probably true that those book values somewhat understate the actual value, but by no stretch of the imagination or by no defensible means could that figure of $12 billion be stretched out as far as $20 billion, in my judgment. Therefore, unless it is a misprint, at the most this consumption binge which is being proposed by Freebairn, Walsh and Porter could be financed for only two years through asset sales and, of course, it would also rather heroically assume that the market could absorb asset sales of that size, namely, $10 billion per year.

I look forward to reading the book or in some other way finding out whether the valuation flaw is confined to a misprint in the Press release. Finally, I will also look with some care at the book in total to see whether it, too, is riddled with conceptual errors as Taxing and Spending Mark I was riddled with conceptual errors last year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer the Minister to my question to her on 21 April 1988 in relation to bipartisanship in status of women matters, to the launch of the rural women's survey and to the additional information that she provided to this chamber on 26 April 1988. Does the Minister believe that she can continue to say one thing in this chamber and do the opposite in practice? I also ask the Minister whether she made the following statement on 26 April:

QUESTION.PARA: I will ensure that on the next occasion we work on such local events, their names-
that is, the names of parliamentarians other than Labor parliamentarians-

Having said that, did the Minister not speak at a Tasmanian launch of the National Agenda for Women this week to which Tasmanian Liberal senators were not invited? Are there to be local launches by the Minister in each State? Did she allege that I had been sent guest lists for three events, namely, the National Agenda for Women, the Women's Suffrage Banner and the rural women's survey launch, and that I had failed to be completely frank with the chamber? As I have not received these three lists under my freedom of information application or elsewhere-indeed I have received only one-what occasioned the Minister to make this allegation? Did it seem like a good idea at the time or was she misled by her officers? What standard of care does the Minister exercise over supplementary answers, and what steps did she take to ascertain the veracity of her comments before she made them?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Vanstone for her question. I can assure her personally that I am really a very hospitable person and that I am very sorry to hear, if it is indeed true, that Tasmanian members-women and men-were not invited.
—You failed to ensure that they were.
—Senator Vanstone, I have many responsibilities and--
—You promised they would.
—This is bigger than Watergate!

—Yes, it certainly is. I will certainly find out why invitations were not sent to Opposition women members, or indeed to some of my own colleagues. I am pleased that the honourable senator is so interested in the National Agenda for Women and, indeed, in the rural women's survey that she has asked I think now two questions relating to invitations. I concede that obviously there needs to be some tightening up in relation to the issuing of invitations. I would merely remind Senator Vanstone-and I am sure that her colleagues would support me in this regard-that personally I am a hospitable person. I invited Senator Vanstone to participate in bipartisan photographs in King's Hall in front of the women's suffrage banner, which I think was a very pleasant occasion. I will certainly find out why my particular assurances have not been carried out, and we will try to do better in future.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Do I understand by the Minister's answer that she is admitting that she in fact failed to ensure that on the next occasion a local event was undertaken Liberal senators would be invited? Also, I invite the Minister to address the second part of my question, which is why she chose to come into this chamber and say something that had no basis in fact and why, when she is given the opportunity to address her incapacity in this respect, she chooses to ignore it.

—I have given an apology to those honourable senators who were disappointed not to receive an invitation. I have indicated that we will have to further tighten up the issuing of invitations. If Senator Vanstone is so concerned about this matter, perhaps she would like to draft a reprimand for me to actually issue to staff involved. I will certainly ensure that Senator Vanstone is not disappointed again in the future.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the discomfort and discord that the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives is causing within the Opposition ranks by insisting that all members of the coalition place unity in front of principle over the Government's proposed referendums? Is the Leader's position at odds with the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and will this discord be likely to affect the rights of Queenslanders to achieve equal value for each vote cast?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the matter goes further than disquiet amongst members of the Opposition. It undoubtedly causes community concern as well, because I think the community likes to believe that there is a viable Opposition in this country and that there is some possibility of enlightened debate about these issues. I am aware that several of the more forward looking, enlightened and more highly principled members of the coalition-and there are one or two-do feel a great deal of discomfort with the Opposition's cynical and shortsighted decision to oppose the referenda. For example, on the question of electoral justice in Australia-one vote one value-the President of the Queensland Liberal Party admitted on 6 May, on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio, that:

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland State Parliamentary members are taking the view that they will support the Federal redistribution principle.

That is, one vote one value, with a few per cent tolerance. I congratulate the Queensland Liberals who decide to support this principle, which only in Queensland could be regarded as anything other than a basic tenet of a truly democratic political system.

The Press has also reported that the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, Mr Spender, considers his Party's decision to urge a no vote to the extension of trial by jury and the right to compensation contradicts the existing law and order policy of the Liberal Party. The Sydney Morning Herald reports that, when he was asked why the joint parties had decided to oppose the extension of these rights, Mr Spender could only reply, `I'm damned if I know'. Mr Howard was obviously upset with Mr Spender's forthright and reasonable remarks, and he said on ABC radio on 17 May about Mr Spender:
He won't be speaking out again. He, like every other member of the front bench, will totally support the campaign for the decision.
So much for democracy in the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is absolutely sickening.

—Senator Chaney says that this is sickening. That is the sort of remark one gets by way of interjection, when people say, `You are trying to play politics in this place'. Of course it is sickening; but there is more to come. On the same interview program as that on which Mr Howard appeared, Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, admitted that were he a member of the Queensland Liberal Party, he would be arguing very hard for a fairer State electoral system. That is very proper, and Senator Chaney has the delightful fallback that he is not a member of the Queensland Liberal Party and does not have to do what he says he would do. The need for a fairer political system in Queensland is characterised by the Australian comedian Brian Doyle, who says, `I want to be buried in Queensland because that is the way I will get to vote after death'. That is true.
—That was said about New South Wales.

—No, that is not the case with New South Wales. Honourable senators opposite have tried that one. Today we read in the South Australian Advertiser that the honourable member for Sturt will be voting in favour of two of the Government's referenda Bills. I am sure that the people of Australia will see through the Opposition's shoddy tactics and support all four constitutional amendments. The dissent and discomfort of many members of the coalition reflects not just their own dissatisfaction with Mr Howard's ham-fisted attempt to hold up sensible reform, but also their conviction that the people of Australia really want these reforms. These people in the Opposition of relatively high principle know that the great majority of people believe in one vote one value, want to go to the polls less frequently, want to see basic principles such as trial by jury recognised in the Constitution, and want proper recognition for local government. Those are the issues, Mr President. In return, the Liberal Party is offering the 1965 show all over again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This personal explanation relates to the report on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation last night which involved the misleading use of my comments at a Press conference, and which I hope was the result of sloppy reporting rather than an intention to misrepresent. I therefore wish to outline the views that I gave, and I will quote from a transcript of the Press conference to explain why Senator Collins was led into asking a question which amounted to a continuation of that misrepresentation, and there was a further continuation of it by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button).

SPEECH.PARA: I made the point at the Press conference that no member of the Liberal Party of Australia favours the sort of redistribution that we have had in Queensland. I said that I was making it clear that that was not a situation which I was defending. I then said:
The question is whether you decide that you are going to try to remedy that by putting in an overriding central constitutional principle.
I then went on to outline why that should not be done. I again quote from exactly what I said at the Press conference:

The first thing is-the Government is not proposing to apply the one vote one value principle to the Australian Constitution. One vote one value will not apply in the House of Representatives-and it will not apply in the Senate. It will not apply in the House of Representatives because the Government is not intending to interfere with the weighting of electorates which has provided for Tasmania. So that in applying that requirement on the States, the Labor Party is not proposing that it should be applied to the House of Representatives.
I went on to say:

There would be a total outrage if the Government proposed to apply it to the Senate and destroy the representation of States like Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania, which is equal with that of the more populous States.
Later, I said:
I think that there is an enormous element of hypocrisy in what is being put forward.
Slightly later in the Press conference, I said:

My own position on one vote one value is that it is an important principle but it is not the sole principle which is to be examined when you are drawing up an electoral system. It is not the sole principle, it is not some total absolute, and I happen to think that the arrangements with respect to Tasmania and the arrangements with respect to the Senate are an illustration of an aberration from the one vote one value which are two illustrations which are totally acceptable. I do not believe they breach democratic principle and I do not believe they provide a particular advantage for the Liberal Party, the National Party or the Labor Party. I think they provide an advantage to areas of the country which would otherwise be underrepresented in a democratic sense.
With reference to the Western Australian situation, which has been referred to in Question Time, I said:

In Western Australia, I have consistently argued . . . for a different approach to State electoral matters, which is essentially a matter for the State Government. But I have always said that in a State as big as Western Australia representation of the regions in the upper House makes eminent sense . . . To look at the State, its geography, its communications, its population, and to deny that some Senate-type imbalance of representation in the upper House is undemocratic-I think it is crazy. I see it as not very undemocratic at all.
Then the matter of Queensland was raised with me, and this is the point at which the misunderstanding arises. I was asked:
How would you address the problem in Queensland?
I replied:

I think that has to be handled by Queensland politicians who have got to make up their minds what they want to do. If there is a majority of members of parliament in Queensland who want a change-and that is what we are being told by the Liberal Party and the Labor Party-then it is over to them . . . They can't just hand all their responsibilities to us, or to the Constitution.

I could read more extracts, but the point is that I made it quite clear that in my view the position being adopted by the Opposition is correct in principle, and that there is a high degree of hypocrisy in the arguments being put forward by the Government, because, in fact, one vote one value will not apply to this Commonwealth Parliament if the constitutional amendment involved is passed. It will be forced on every State legislature, but it will not apply to this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: Senator Chaney asked for the indulgence of the Senate in order to make a personal explanation. That indulgence was granted, but I think Senator Chaney is now debating the issue and not addressing himself to the matter about which he rose to make a personal explanation. He is widening the debate out from the personal explanation.

—Senator Chaney received leave to make a personal explanation. He is entitled to do so. He is not entitled to debate the issue; he must confine himself to his personal explanation. That he is doing at the moment.

—I thank you for that ruling, Mr Deputy President. I have almost completed my remarks. I have already said that at the Press conference I said that this matter had to be handled by Queensland politicians, who have to make up their minds what they want to do. To that, I should add `in Queensland'. I have made the point about the regionalisation aspect and the weighting of votes in Queensland and Western Australia. It was then that I said in the final part of an answer to a question:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't, in any sense, belittle that and were I a member of the Queensland Liberal Party I would be arguing very hard with them for a State electoral system that was fairer.

That has always been my public and private position, and it remains my position today. It also remains my position today that that is not a matter to be determined by an amendment to the Constitution that would impose on the States an electoral straitjacket that we are not prepared to impose on the Commonwealth Parliament. I believe that it is rank hypocrisy to apply one set of rules to the State parliaments and a totally different set of rules to the Federal Parliament. I would not support such a proposal.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY GAMING AND LIQUOR AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority annual report 1986-87 contains a number of startling facts and figures, especially in the light of the current debate in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) about a possible casino. Under the heading `Highlights for the period 1 July 1986 to 29 June 1987' we read that the ACT Totalisator Agency Board turnover for the financial year was $49,850,144 and that poker machine turnover for the same period was $220,948,146. That works out to the expenditure of something like $1,000 per man, woman and child in the ACT just on poker machines, let alone horse racing, lotteries and the various forms of so-called sport gambling. One would think that that is enough and with that amount of money being spent already a casino would not really be necessary.

It is also interesting to note that Mr Connor, in the report of the Board of Enquiry into Casinos in the State of Victoria, which recommended against having a casino in that State, after very wide-ranging inquiries argued that a casino would have the net effect of increasing the total level of gambling in that State. Incidentally, he also noted that, despite the promises of politicians, casinos are acknowledged targets of organised crime. I refer to page 2 of the report under the heading `Corporate statement' which states that the objective of the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority is:
To provide cost effective wagering and other services that will create maximum financial returns to the community, the racing industry and the Government.

This statement begs a number of questions, not least the ethical argument of using gambling as a form of concealed taxation. Also interesting is the use of the term `racing industry' for an occupation which does little for the community except provide a form of entertainment; and it is certainly not an industry in that it certainly does not create anything.

Another matter of interest in this report which I draw to the attention of honourable senators is the coy use of words such as `sport' and `gaming' instead of `betting' and `gambling'. Although the Australian Democrats have no wish to further regulate something which is demonstrably part of Australian culture, we prefer to call a spade a spade. I refer now to page 12 of the report under the heading `Sports betting' and the statement:

Sports betting was offered on the Sydney Rugby League and Victorian Football League competitions, the America's Cup defence, the James Hardie 1000 motor race, Australian Grand Prix and the World Series Cricket. ACT/TAB turnover on these events was $57,011.

I guess that these events are sports for those taking part and they are certainly spectator sports for those watching, either actually present or watching on television but, as the Australian Democrats' spokesperson for both sport and the ACT, I place on record that the Democrats strongly believe in Government support for participatory sports in the interests of community health and fitness, and they are quite unrelated to the gambling industry. I note the ACT Gaming and Liquor Authority Report. I regret the confusion of terms in the report between `sport' and `gambling'. I place on record the opposition of the Australian Democrats to the widening of gambling opportunities in the ACT by the opening of a casino in Canberra.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 April, on motion by Senator Collins:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I wish to place on record several comments on the Committee's eighty-third report. In relation to regulations and ordinances, there seem to be too many of them, they are too hard to acquire and they are too hard to interpret. The report contains an appendix which lists over 100 legislative sources for different kinds of delegated legislative instruments other than-and I stress that it is other than-regulations and ordinances. It refers to over 20 generically different types of delegated legislative instruments other than regulations and ordinances. In relation to generic types of delegated legislation there are orders, declarations, determinations, directions, notices, principles, guidelines and standards. They are not statutory rules and as such they are not printed, not numbered, not indexed, not digested, not consolidated and as a result are not easily accessible. If a lawyer or member of the public wants to find a statutory rule there are indexes but, if one wants to find subordinate legislation in one of the categories that I have mentioned, one is faced with the unenviable task of searching for a needle in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette haystack.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most striking features of modern government, not only in Australia but throughout the world of Westminster type parliamentary democracy, is the dislocation of powers between Parliament and the Executive. Ideally there is a constructive tension in the relationship between law makers and law executors. Parliamentary government has two components-Parliament and government-and we, the representatives of the people in Parliament, need the Executive to administer our laws, just as the Executive needs us to give it power and authority to administer them. The complexity and sophistication of modern society makes it essential that we delegate to Ministers and officials rule making powers to deal with the details and contingencies of large administrative, social, legal and economic schemes.

The sheer mass and momentum of these laws passes us by, perhaps given tacit parliamentary approval with all the confidence of parliamentary ignorance because in many cases we are quite simply ignorant of what executive law making is doing and why. I believe that the fault lies with successive governments, particularly the bureaucracy, for their failure to supply Parliament with adequate information on the reasons for new subordinate laws and their predicted effects. Quite simply there is now so much secondary law and it is so detailed and complex and so incomplete in the sense that it is part of an evolving sequence of administrative responses to the needs of administration. These laws are made by highly skilled and very professional public servants who know intimately what they are doing and why they are advising the Ministers to do what they do when they make new rules and regulations. But why can we not, in Parliament, be told in greater detail the whys and wherefores of new regulatory laws?

In its report, the Committee has again expressed its dissatisfaction with the quality of explanatory statements which are attached to instruments tabled in this place. So little effort is needed by the experts in the bureaucracy to make those statements informative and truly explanatory of the impact of delegated legislation that I have to wonder why statements are so uninformative. It is undoubtedly part of our role on the Committee to criticise this aspect of the presentation of rules because we act as a watchdog for the rights not only of the citizen but also of the Parliament and individual parliamentarians. Parliament has a right to know why secondary laws are necessary and what their expected effects, monetary and otherwise, will be.

I am currently in the unique position of being a member of both the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. In that capacity I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the concern expressed, on this very same issue, by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in its 1986-87 report which is reiterated at the beginning of chapter 3 of the report currently under discussion:

The Committee has been concerned . . . at the proliferation of instruments . . . in a form other than regulations. The main reason for this would . . . appear to be . . . a belief in the Departments administering the relevant legislation that the regulation-making process has become cumbersome and lacks . . . flexibility . . . It considers the proliferation of substitutes for regulations to be undesirable . . . it is much more difficult to ascertain whether a power to determine some matter by notice has been exercised and, if so, to find a copy of the relevant notice. The proliferation of such notices thus makes it more difficult for the public at large to ascertain what the law is in relation to a particular matter . . . such notices, although they have legislative effect, are not prepared by the professional drafters in the Attorney-General's Department, but by departmental officers. They may thus lack the precision required in legislative instruments and, if found defective in subsequent litigation, may result in significant additional costs for the Commonwealth.

It seems obvious since both committees are commenting on this issue that it would behove the Government to address this issue of subordinate legislation. It is obvious that both committees agree that more serious attempts need to be made by officials, preferably on the basis of standing directions from their Ministers, to furnish Parliament, as a matter of course, with statements that explain and offer some detailed guidelines as to the nature of the problem that the new laws address and the cost and impact of their enforcement.

If this is to be a modern Parliament, served by a modern bureaucracy, then it is time that steps were taken to recognise properly the dimensions of this shift in law-making authority from Parliament to the Executive and respond to it as parliamentarians by requiring fuller explanations and impact statements. Almost equally important is the need to pay greater attention to the width of those clauses in Bills which delegate law-making power and, where necessary, require that the scope and purpose of delegations of authority be more clearly set out in the Bills that come before us.

I would like to make it clear that I recognise the need for delegated legislation. I accept the likelihood that under governments of any hue there will be a need for a relatively large, if fluctuating, volume of such legislation. I also recognise that, for reasons of inertia and administrative convenience, there is probably more legislation on the delegated statute book than there needs to be. A requirement to assess more carefully and express more clearly to Parliament the impact of new departmental laws will inevitably sharpen departmental and ministerial perceptions of the justifications for proposed laws. The Committee believes that that will inevitably improve the overall quality of such laws. I have no doubt that improvement in quality which arises from the need publicly to justify laws and publicly to predict their impact will eventually flow through to those other issues of particular interest to the Committee concerning personal rights and civil liberties. I think there would be less likelihood of creating the unjustifiable strict liability offences, unreviewable discretions, subdelegated powers and the other technical flaws that the Committee encounters if there existed in the minds of lawmakers this keener sensitivity to the presence of a supervising parliament which has the right to know more about the way its own parliamentary authority is being used by its delegates.

In its report, the Committee has urged Ministers to give consideration to this question of the process of making law outside Parliament and the need to justify properly the laws that are made. I would strongly argue that all subordinate legislation be referenced in such a way that both parliamentarians and public are able to access it with relative ease. I would like to quote Peter O'Keefe, Secretary to the Committee, who says:
A strange breed of men and women, of both right and left, still gravitate to serve on these committees-
he is referring to subordinate legislation committees-

with a willingness and motivation that is becoming rare in Australian politics. Their concern is to protect ordinary people's rights and to use one of the last politically unsullied parliamentary forums to engage in a genuinely parliamentary activity.

I consider it a great privilege to be a member of that strange breed. As a new member of this Committee, I have been impressed with my colleagues' willingness to take off their party political hats and don their parliamentary hats to participate in a non-partisan and united way to achieve the aims of that Committee. The Committee is served by a very able staff, totally dedicated to the important task of the Committee. I acknowledge their contributions, in particular that of the Secretary to the Committee, Mr Peter O'Keefe.
I commend this report to all honourable senators, to Ministers and especially to professional public servants involved in the development of subordinate legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.

—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Since Senator Coates questioned why this is being done, I am quite happy to provide an explanation. He is quite right. When you, Mr Acting Deputy President, called this item no senator rose in his place. Quite correctly, you put the motion and it was carried. However, there are a number of honourable senators in this place with a long term interest in this matter who have not yet had a chance to speak and who, to my knowledge, wish to. Indeed, since that occurred one has spoken to me about it and I know of at least one other. For that reason, I am following this procedure simply to ensure that the matter is preserved on the Notice Paper and that honourable senators will at some later time get a chance to make a contribution.

I have nothing further to say on the motion at this stage except that, in my view, the question of access to video material is very important; one in which there is a good deal of public interest. That public interest relates particularly to the protection of young people, which is an extremely difficult thing to do because of modern technology. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Second Report of the Sixty-third Session

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 February, on motion by Senator Cook:
That the following Sessional Order, as contained in the attachment to the Report, be adopted:

That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, in a debate on a motion for the suspension of any Standing or Sessional Order a senator shall not speak for more than 5 minutes, and if the debate is not concluded at the expiration of 30 minutes after the moving of the motion the question on the motion shall then be put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion that we are debating today is:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Sessional Order, as contained in the attachment to the Report-
that is, the second report of the sixty-third session of the Standing Committee on Procedure-
be adopted:

That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, in a debate on a motion for the suspension of any Standing or Sessional Order a senator shall not speak for more than 5 minutes, and if the debate is not concluded at the expiration of 30 minutes after the moving of the motion the question on the motion shall then be put.

The first point to be made about this motion is that it is indeed a sessional order that we are discussing, not a standing order. It is a temporary procedure put in place to see whether the change will work in the best interests of the Senate and in the best interests of each senator, rather than simply going for the double whammy, if you like, of changing the standing order outright. What the motion proposes is that for a trial period, which is all a sessional order provides for, we see whether or not there should be a limited time for each speaker and a set time for the debate on a suspension of Standing or Sessional Orders motion.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would well know, we do have limits on other forms of debate in this place. I think that you were a member of the Senate in the days when a one-hour debating period was set aside for normal debates-debates on Bills and so on. I am sure that you will remember colleagues of ours who, if given 10 minutes to debate something, would do so quite competently but, if given an hour, would stretch it out to that as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember some speeches that took an hour.
—I am sure that you do. None of us were any more edified at the end of such speeches than we would have been if the speaker had been limited to 10 minutes.
—And some went on to ask for an extension of time.

—That is quite true. Senator Colston has pointed out that it was not unknown, at the end of that hour's debate, for somebody to seek an extension and no doubt, from time to time, be granted it because people were numb after sitting there for an hour listening to whatever it was that was up for debate.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past we have put back time limits in order to get through the business more appropriately, to make speeches more precise and more on the topic, to stop honourable senators from falling asleep and one thing and another, and that was all to the good of the Senate. Over the years we have frequently changed debating times so that now we speak for a maximum of only 30 minutes in a debate on a Bill, instead of 60 minutes. Prior to the setting of the 60-minute time limit, we were able to speak for an unlimited amount of time. That is still the case in the United States, which allows people to filibuster on their own.

The Senate has a five-minute time limit per speaker in debates on committee reports and a 10-minute limit, as we have just noted in the last two batches of debates here today, for debates when some papers are tabled. During Thursday lunchtimes when matters of public interest are dealt with by the chamber we put a 15-minute time limit on the speakers. In debates on urgency motions or matters of public importance that come before the chamber after Question Time, the first two speakers are given 20 minutes and the remaining speakers have a 15-minute time limit. To argue that limiting a speech-whether it is a limit of five minutes, 10 minutes, 30 minutes, an hour, or whatever the standing or sessional order provides-somehow gags debate is quite ridiculous and flies in the face of what we have done in this place to control the debates, to make the procedures more orderly and to get through the enormous amount of business that this chamber deals with on an annual basis.

It is especially ridiculous to argue that somehow a gag is being applied when the motion seeks to limit not the debate on the substantive motion for which a suspension is being sought but the time for debate on whether or not the Standing or Sessional Orders ought to be suspended-the time during which the speakers should be putting their arguments about the urgency of a matter. That is why from time to time in this place we move to suspend Standing or Sessional Orders. Sometimes a matter is drawn to our attention that is so urgent that it cannot wait until the afternoon, later in the evening or the following day: we cannot go through the normal processes of putting down a notice of motion, dealing with it at a later hour of the day or, as would normally happen, having it put on the Notice Paper for the following day and following normal procedures.

When a senator moves for the suspension of Standing Orders to debate a matter immediately, rather than at some subsequent time, that senator is saying, `This matter is of such importance, such urgency, that it simply cannot wait for a later time'. Therefore, I would have thought that it was in that senator's interests, or in the interests of the party which that senator represents and on whose behalf the senator is moving the motion, to get the matter dealt with as expeditiously as possible, to get the suspension motion dealt with as quickly as possible, so that we can move on to the substantive motion.

I know that it is a time-honoured tradition in this place that sorely tries the patience of people such as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and me who take the President's chair from time to time that when a senator, or the party of that senator, who knows that he does not have a majority to enable him to get the suspension motion approved, uses the debate to canvass the substantive issue. The senator then hopes that either nobody will take a point of order on the matter of relevance or, if somebody does so, the person occupying the chair will be moved not to uphold it. Mr Acting Deputy President, you and I know how difficult it is sometimes to rule on the question of relevance.

We use these little tricks in this place. A 30-minute time limit, as applies currently, certainly gives people plenty of rope with which to hang themselves, or indeed anybody else, by taking the substantive matters into the debate on whether or not a matter is so urgent that Standing Orders or Sessional Orders should be suspended. I say that, having done it myself. Knowing that for some reason a suspension motion we are moving will not be accepted, we have dragged in by the ears, or any other part of the matter's anatomy, any detail that we have wanted to bring in, in the hope that we will get away with it. So, I acknowledge that from time to time we ourselves have, shall I say, abused the system or fudged the issue slightly.

However, that is not the point. The point is that a debate on a motion to suspend Standing or Sessional Orders is a quite specific one. The argument should be whether or not the matter is so urgent that we should deal with it at that time and not at some other time; indeed, whether we should interrupt other business to deal with it. A matter ought not to be brought before the Senate at a particular and inappropriate moment simply because it is politically expedient to do so-because one cannot wait until Question Time, because Question Time has passed, because there is no time to get an urgency motion to the President or because one does not want to wait until the next day to use the normal notice of motion process. That is not the purpose, or ought not to be the purpose, of a debate on the suspension of Standing Orders.

We ought to be arguing that a failure to raise a matter at that point in time will cause some problem to someone-not a problem to the political party that would like it brought forward in that it would have to wait for a while, but some specific problem-or that there is, in fact, a time element that renders it particularly urgent. I would have thought that the very fact that we were debating the urgency of a matter would be a reason for keeping the time limit down. As has been indicated, it is always possible to seek an extension of time, if one is necessary, and we did that this morning for Senator Stone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a motion which proposes to limit, by way of either Sessional Orders or Standing Orders, debate on a motion for the suspension of any standing or sessional order to five minutes or less. As a matter of fundamental principle, I have always opposed any further reduction, by way of either Standing Orders or Sessional Orders, of the time available for honourable senators to speak in this chamber. Slowly but, I suspect, inexorably we are finding that through various mechanisms and means this Government is moving this place towards the system that operates in the House of Representatives-that is, that the time of senators to speak is being reduced to the point where they are no longer able in any detail to put a comprehensive explanation and persuasive argument.

SPEECH.PARA: I find absolutely no reasonable justification for reducing from 30 minutes to five minutes the period allowed for debate on the question of whether Standing Orders should be suspended. One can reasonably argue that a senator would move for the suspension of Standing Orders in regard to a matter of great moment, urgency and priority. He would do so in respect of an issue which cannot wait for the normal processes of Senate procedures. In that case the reasons why Standing Orders should be suspended not only ought to be justified but also ought to be compelling. On that basis alone, an excellent argument can be made out that senators ought properly to argue and debate the merits of suspending Standing Orders so that an issue can be brought forward. It is not unreasonable to allow senators from either side of the chamber a full and proper opportunity to debate why Standing Orders or Sessional Orders ought to be suspended.

I am of the view that to continue, as we have, to reduce the time available for senators to speak on all sorts of occasions is simply another form of gag. The motion before us is a surreptitious, insidious attempt by this Government to gag senators and to prevent them from making a proper and detailed contribution to whatever the subject of the day is. We are told by Senator Haines that it is possible for senators to get an extension of time. Of course, that request has to be granted by leave and without dissent. Leave is refused if only one senator dissents. The right to debate ought not to rest in the capricious hands of an agitated senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would always give you leave, Noel.
—I thank the honourable senator very much. In that case, I speak for my colleagues. It seems to me that the right to 30 minutes ought to be enshrined in the Sessional and Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Over recent years we have witnessed more and more legislation being introduced into the Parliament and into this chamber. Parallel with that, we have also witnessed the incompetence of this Government in managing its business. Almost without exception, we have no legislation before us in the first two or three weeks of any session. During these periods we have filibusters. We have lengthy debates on matters that could easily be dealt with more quickly. During the middle and end of a session we find that there is a stockpile of legislation which causes the Government to seek to guillotine Bills through the Senate-either on the floor of the Senate or by surreptitious methods outside the chamber.

I argue now, and I will always argue, that all senators have a fundamental right to stand and speak for as long as they like. For my part, I am opposed to the 30-minute rule on speeches made during a second reading debate. I am totally opposed to the 30-minute rule on adjournment speeches. There may well be occasions when the subject with which a senator is dealing cannot properly and comprehensively be addressed in 30 minutes. It might so happen that a senator requires an hour to speak on a piece of legislation. But we find ourselves now restricted because of the management of the chamber and because of the amount of legislation that is before us.

The Government has foreshadowed a number of steps and measures which are designed to restrict debate in this chamber. I do not suggest for a moment that the Government seeks to restrict debate because Government senators are unable, incompetent or do not have the capacity to compete with us in terms of the force of their arguments. I suspect, rather, it is because of mismanagement that the Government is unable to organise its program so that there can be orderly, proper and comprehensive debate. There is no justification for arguing that any issue which comes to this chamber can be comprehensively and fully debated by an honourable senator in five minutes. Next, we will find ourselves with the American system which has been introduced into the House of Representatives whereby members have 90-second bites. They stand up, identify themselves, refer to the subject and sit down.

What can be said in five minutes that is likely to persuade anybody? I submit, very little. This is not a sensible time limit. Such a limit is not imposed on any speaker in any other forum. I would have thought that the one place in which there ought to be no retardation, inhibition, limitations or frustrations in regard to the length of time in which a person is given to attempt to persuade, would be the Senate chamber. The Senate is the very last place where the capacity to put an argument ought to be restricted.

I rather suspect that it is a reflection of this Government's attitude towards the parliamentary system that it would want legislation to be introduced and put through the chamber without debate. The truth of the matter is that on the Government's side of politics the argument is decided before a Bill is ever introduced. From time to time I still think about poor old ex-Senator Georgie Georges who dared but once in 60 years as a member of the Australian Labor Party to disagree publicly with his own Party. He paid the ultimate price. The ultimate sanction was placed upon him and he was expelled from his Party. After his expulsion he was subject to abuse and intimidation from those on his own side for the balance of his period in this place. It was bad enough that he was sent to Coventry. But to be described by his own colleagues, his bosom friends, his lifelong friends as a scab is symptomatic of the straitjacketing that is practised by those on the other side of the chamber in terms of freedom of speech, freedom of thought and freedom of debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh attacked him viciously.

—That is right. Senator Walsh bitterly and viciously, as only he can do, with the skill and capacity that he has learnt from his own twisted and warped approach to life, attacked the honourable senator because that man--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am all in favour of short, to the point speeches in this place and I am all against this motion. I think it is important for us to understand the difference between those two points. The motion that is now before us is an attempt to cut down the right of senators to speak properly to a very important motion, that is, the motion to suspend Standing Orders. First of all, the issue must be quite important to the mind of that senator and, presumably, to other senators for that senator to hope to get the support of the chamber for the moving of a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. Therefore, the issue must be very important. Secondly, under the Standing Orders, the mover of a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders and any senator speaking to that motion must stick directly to the point. They would be asked to do so by the presiding officer at the request of any senator if that speaker were straying from the point.
—And then would continue to ignore the request.

—No, that senator would not continue. Honourable senators have not continued to ignore such requests. I have heard a number of speeches on motions for the suspension of Standing Orders which have attracted points of order from honourable senators. The presiding officer has then instructed the speaker to stick to the point and has made sure that the speaker has stuck to it. The debate on a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders is not just an ordinary debate. When speaking time in ordinary debates was almost unlimited-and that is going back some years now-I heard honourable senators straying on to various irrelevant points. Even with the present half-hour time limit honourable senators stray on to various irrelevant points. However, in regard to debate on the suspension of Standing Orders, this is a narrowly defined area. Let us take such an example. Senator Coates was interjecting a moment ago, so let us take the most recent example, provided by Senator Chaney. The report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material appeared as a Government paper in the Notice Paper today. In the past a period of 30 minutes has been set aside for the discussion of Government Papers. I ask honourable senators: When was the last time on a broadcast day that discussion of Government Papers has been less than 30 minutes?
—Today.

—Today-for the first time in my memory, this has occurred on a broadcast day. We were therefore caught short. Those honourable senators who were interested in speaking to the report of the Committee on Video Material of course considered that, naturally, the debate on Government papers on a broadcast day would go for 30 minutes-instead of which, it went for only five minutes. In those circumstances the motion was put and adopted without debate. Senator Chaney, quite rightly, on behalf of the Opposition, sought to have that matter returned to the Notice Paper. Because it is a matter of major public policy, it was quite a justifiable action for him to take. Senator Coates initially refused leave.
—He queried it, I think.

—I am sorry. Okay, he queried it. However, had any honourable senator refused leave, it would have been possible for Senator Chaney to do one of two things. Firstly, he could have given notice of motion for tomorrow or, secondly, if he thought the matter was very important, he could have sought to suspend Standing Orders today. I guarantee that it would have been important for Senator Chaney to do so because of the misrepresentations of the majority report of the Committee on Video Material. There has been a Press conference about that today. Because of those misrepresentations Senator Chaney had a great deal to say to the Senate in order to ensure that it was aware of the importance of the matter and the need to suspend Standing Orders. However, it would not have been possible to do that with any form of justice in a period of five minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my concern also that this represents the thin end of the wedge. To that extent I agree with what Senator Crichton-Browne said when he asked why we should, unless evidence is placed before us of honourable senators taking advantage of the suspension of Standing Orders provisions, change the Standing Orders. That is what we are actually doing. Although we say that it is a change to the Sessional Orders, it is actually a change to the Standing Orders.

While I am on the subject, let me state that there is too much of this business of governing our procedures simply by the use of Sessional Orders. If the change is important enough, why is not the Senate Standing Orders Committee game enough to say, `Let us change the Standing Orders'? I know that Senator Haines has put forward the argument that we should give it a trial. We could give it a trial in this instance. But let us reflect. Where is the evidence before us to show that this standing order has been abused? Where is the evidence? It is not in the report. If there is evidence, let us have it so that we can consider it. Otherwise, it looks to me as though this is the thin end of the wedge and an attempt to deny the rights of individual honourable senators to represent the people who elected them to this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the good things about debates on Sessional Orders or Standing Orders is that there is no party line and one can take an attitude of one's own on this. I would take the opportunity to disagree with my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne and with Senator Harradine on this very important matter.
—I defend your right to be wrong.

—Senator Crichton-Browne may defend my right to be wrong; he can also defend my right to be right. It is an issue which is of great concern to all honourable senators and one which I am sure we have to tackle very seriously. It is important that we should be able to suspend Standing Orders to discuss matters of great and immediate importance. We have Standing Orders which provide proper procedures for the protection of all senators, of due processes in our procedures. We should suspend Standing Orders only when a very important case is being made out. In general, Standing Orders are suspended with the agreement of all parties. There is no problem there. There is virtually no debate involved. The motion is moved. It is known that all parties agree and the debate on the important matter goes on with no interruptions and no waste of time debating motions to suspend Standing Orders because the matter is acknowledged, by a majority of senators anyway, to be one that should be discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are dealing with here is the situation in which a majority of senators do not think the matter should be discussed on that day. Using the ordinary Standing Orders the matter can be discussed the next day. However, I am talking about when it is believed to be a matter of such immediate importance that other matters should be set aside so that it can be discussed. The majority of senators do not agree-if they did the debate would not take place.

The motives for such a debate are threefold. First of all, it is to publicise a matter which is very important-usually to the Opposition, occasionally to the Australian Democrats and occasionally to the Independents. They take the opportunity to get maximum publicity on a matter which is of importance to them. I think that I could say without being unfair that the majority of these sorts of protests tend to take place on a day on which the Senate proceedings are being broadcast. That is very natural. The purpose of those senators is to get publicity for a point of view which the majority of the Senate does not think needs to be discussed urgently. It is essentially a protest or a publicity device-a perfectly proper one. The question we have to consider is how much time it is appropriate to allow the Senate to spend on that protest or that publicity device.

The second technique used in these debates on the suspension of Standing Orders-I have heard this when I have been sitting in the chair and have had problems with it; it is almost inescapable-is that a great deal of the substance of the matter will be debated during debate on the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders to enable the matter to be discussed. It is a very simple technique, and it is used with admirable skill by many honourable senators, some of whom are now in the chamber. They say it is only by suspending Standing Orders that they can discuss a matter, and they develop the matter that could be discussed were Standing Orders suspended. It is perfectly proper. What they are doing is getting in the material on the matter which the majority of the Senate presumably does not wish debated.

Senator Harradine raised another point. Where is the evidence of the necessity for this measure? I must confess it is a difficult point to raise because one does not know what the alternatives are. It has always struck me as odd that, on the whole, the Senate has I think a good set of Standing Orders yet we give an extraordinary amount of leave to people to do things contrary to Standing Orders. When an honourable senator seeks leave it is almost automatically granted. I believe the reason is a very simple one. Everyone knows that an honourable senator refused leave would immediately move for the suspension of so much of the Standing Orders as would prevent him doing what he sought leave to do. Everyone in a position of authority in the Senate knows it is much less time consuming to allow leave to do a thing, even though one believes that thing should not really be done, rather than go through a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. That is a distortion of our proper processes.

I know and accept there are strong arguments on both sides of this issue. We should try it out and see how it goes. It is a sessional order, it is under trial and if it does not work or is felt to impact unfairly on minority parties in the Senate, or on the Opposition for that matter, after a due trial we could certainly wipe it out of the sessional orders. I do think it is an area of our procedure which is subject to abuse. It has caused what I think is an excessive amount of leave being given to do things which are not strictly urgent, which should be done by the proper processes of the Senate without seeking leave to avoid those proper and standard processes. I think we should try out a sessional order to see whether it would make the Senate work more smoothly and more efficiently and enable it to devote more of its time to the proper processes, and allow a reasonable amount of time for protests but not an excessive amount. I fear that is the danger of continuing with our present arrangements for the suspension of Standing Orders. I therefore support, as a trial-it must be considered as a trial only-the adoption of a sessional order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak against the proposal before the chair that the motion to suspend Standing Orders be not debatable or that a time limit be placed on such a motion.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think that Senator MacGibbon has spoken in this debate.

—I understand that although Senator MacGibbon did speak earlier in the debate, and in fact adjourned the debate, it is the first time this matter has been listed on the Notice Paper. I am advised by the Clerk that Senator MacGibbon is able to speak under a special sessional order relating to committee reports. So it is in order for Senator MacGibbon to speak.

—I was in no doubt about my entitlement to speak and I am surprised that Senator Colston had some uncertainty about it. I am opposed to this motion. It is no accident, of course, that the origins of the motion come from the Australian Democrats because anything relating to freedom of expression, freedom of speech and the ability of a senator to put his point of view is always censored and if possible denied by the Democrats, once they have had their say. The motion provides in essence that when Standing Orders are suspended a total of 30 minutes be allocated for debate. At the present time there is no time limit on the debate when the suspension of Standing Orders is moved.

SPEECH.PARA: When are Standing Orders suspended? Standing Orders are suspended only in a matter of emergency. The business of the day is set by the Government, the Government decides on how it wants the affairs of the chamber to run for that day, it is published in the business sheet and the Minister on duty is asked by the President quite early on whether there is any proposal to alter the arrangements for business. The answer to that is usually no, but at any time it is possible for the Government through a Minister, to alter the sequence of business. So the suspension of Standing Orders in essence is an essential safety valve, a procedure available to the Opposition in this chamber to move that something be debated urgently.

In the time I have been here I have learned one truth, that is, every party in the Senate is destined to serve some time in opposition. It is not true that everyone is destined to be in government; certainly some of the minor parties, such as the Nuclear Disarmament Party, will not ever be in power. But we all face the certainty of being in opposition. On a higher plane it is very much part of the institution of the Parliament that senators be allowed and have the opportunity to challenge the views and the position of the government of the day, whether it is executive government or the government en masse represented by senators and members. What we are seeing here is a denial of the right to challenge. In my time here-Senator Harradine said the same thing-I have never seen the Standing Orders as they exist at the present time abused. It is very rare, in fact, that moves are made to suspend Standing Orders and they are suspended only when a matter of great urgency is raised. I am surprised that Senator Hamer took the view he did in his speech, which preceded mine. I thought it was extraordinarily benign of him to say that somehow or other Standing Orders are suspended generally with the consensus of most senators in the chamber. My experience is that Standing Orders have an air of urgency and emotion about them, to put it mildly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Standing Orders cannot be suspended unless there is a majority.

—I am glad that Senator Hamer has brought this point up. It is true that unless there is an absolute majority of senators Standing Orders cannot be suspended but we are talking about the motion to suspend. The desire to move that Standing Orders be suspended often arises as a result of a matter of urgency, and emotions are involved. Therefore it is quite incorrect for Senator Hamer to suggest that there was some sort of benign tolerance of that in the chamber. There is usually quite a large number of senators who wish to speak both for and against the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I found difficulty in understanding was Senator Hamer's claim that this presents almost insuperable problems in the chair. I have had some experience in the chair and I have found no difficulty in interpreting Standing Orders at all. Standing Orders simply require that in speaking in the debate on the motion to suspend Standing Orders relevance must be shown.
