I suggest that there is no difficulty in knowing what relevance the speaker's argument has to the motion proving urgency such that Standing Orders be suspended. This really gets back to the ethos of the Senate. We have a degree of tolerance in this chamber. We do have an age old belief that senators are entitled to be heard on an issue. The fundamental issue here is the motion to suspend Standing Orders. I hold very strongly that senators have the right to express themselves on this issue without any censure at all with respect to time. As I have said I have never seen our present right abused.

I am not surprised that the Australian Democrats have moved this motion. If it is accepted and carried I believe that in six or 12 months time there will be another motion from the Democrats, that the motion to suspend Standing Orders be put without debate. I am very mindful of the fact that over the years the Australian Labor Party has been in power it has always been the Democrats who have moved either the gag or the guillotine to deny to the Opposition the opportunity to debate matters and Bills that are before the chamber. We have to go back only a few weeks to the environmental legislation on the northern rainforests when the Labor Party in collusion with the Democrats moved the guillotine and prevented this chamber debating a very important issue. It is not surprising that they do this because, as I have said before, the Democrats are allergic to the expression of any points of view other than their own.

In the time that the Democrats have been in this chamber, which is now 10 years, not one of them has ever had any respect at all for the institution of Parliament. For them the Parliament is merely a platform for pushing minority points of view that have 2 to 4 per cent support in the community.

I have a different point of view from that of Senator Crichton-Browne in respect of general speaking in general debate. I think that there is a case for limitation of time for general debate on Bills. I have long held the view that it is pointless for the Senate to re-run second reading debates on Bills that have been introduced in the House of Representatives. I think our time would be spent far more profitably if our efforts were directed towards taking a Bill apart in the committee stage to find out precisely what the clauses of the Bill mean and what the defects might be. Personally I am in favour of reducing the time allowable for speaking from 30 minutes to 20 minutes, with a reduction from 15 minutes to either five or 10 minutes in the committee stage.

A fundamental principle is involved in this motion before the Senate today, one which is quite distinct from the normal rules of debate for the Senate. This is the opportunity for the Opposition to challenge the rule of government. If this is limited it amounts, in effect, to denial. What we are looking at in that respect is total dominance of this chamber by the government of the day. If that happens, democracy and the institution of Parliament suffer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I also oppose this proposal which has come from the minds of Senator Haines and her advisers. I have been in this place for almost 12 years, and in that time I can recall only one occasion when this procedure to move to suspend Standing Orders was what might be called misused in that the debate extended over a very lengthy time. In relation to debate that has occurred in recent times on a motion to suspend Standing Orders, I think on every occasion no more than three speakers on our side of the chamber have spoken for some 10 to 20 minutes, and there has not been a continuation of that debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that one of the speakers has been Senator Puplick, and during those debates he has literally torn to shreds not only the Government but Senator Haines and her cohorts. Senator Haines has been angered by the fact that Senator Puplick is such a masterful debater and so able to destroy Senator Haines and her puny views on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is fairytale time, is it? Is this flights of fancy time?

—She has become angered, as she is now becoming angered. Her voice starts to rise and she starts to yell at people. She became angered about this and she then put forward a proposal that there ought to be no debate on this matter. She wanted to gag Senator Puplick and the only way that she could think of doing that was to say that, in relation to the suspension of Standing Orders-which has for centuries been a privilege of all parliaments under the Westminster tradition-in this House of Parliament, the Senate of Australia, there ought to be no debate on such a motion for suspension. That would certainly have gagged Senator Puplick from that point of view, but I am sure that we would find other ways around that.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Government has taken up this proposition; governments always take up propositions which limit the time for debate for Opposition senators, because they do not like people like Senator Puplick tearing into them. Thus the Government is taking up this proposal of Senator Haines-and Senator Haines is sitting there; she is not denying that it is her proposal, that she is the one who brought it forward. What will happen is that this House of Parliament, this marvellous Senate of Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for debate on Committee reports has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I present the seventh report of 1988 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, concerning the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987, the Civil Aviation Bill 1988, and the Honey Marketing Bill 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 7, dated 18 May 1988.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE EDUCATION OF GIFTED AND TALENTED CHILDREN REPORT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children, together with the transcripts of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Senate's interest in the education of gifted and talented children was demonstrated when, on 17 October 1985, it referred to the then Standing Committee on Education and the Arts this particular matter for inquiry and report. After the inquiry was advertised, the Committee received a significant response from a variety of sources, including individuals, organisations, associations and State and Commonwealth authorities.

This response enabled an extensive inquiry to be conducted. Hearings were held in all State capitals and in Canberra. The Committee inspected a number of programs for gifted and talented children in schools and visited a number of centres which specialised in the education of gifted and talented children.

The Committee's task of reporting to the Senate was greatly assisted by the high standard of the evidence which is received. Many eminent people such as Dr Eddie Braggett, Mr Ken Imison, Professor Brian Start and Dr David Mossenson gave the Committee the benefit of their expertise at public hearings.

National and State associations for the gifted and talented made significant contributions, as did State and Commonwealth education authorities. The assistance received from numerous concerned teachers, parents and others involved in this particular area of education is also highly appreciated.

Following the 1987 Federal election, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts was not re-formed. The Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children was therefore established on 22 September to complete the inquiry and report to the Senate.

From the evidence that was received, it is obvious that there is dedicated and constructive work being conducted to further the development of gifted children in Australia. There is a general recognition that gifted children exist, that their talents are varied, and that to neglect this resource would not be in the best interests of this nation. While this recognition is not as widespread as would be desirable, it is nevertheless growing.

In the report which I have just presented, the Committee notes that the Commonwealth Government has a major involvement with tertiary education, while education at the primary and secondary levels is the responsibility of individual States. It is not the Committee's role to address specific recommendations to State governments. Therefore, the recommendations in the report are directed to the Commonwealth Government's responsibilities with education.

Overall, the Committee's findings are that the Commonwealth's commitment to the education of gifted children should be increased. The areas involved include formulating strategies, upgrading information networks and providing financial support for initiatives in advancing educational provisions for the gifted. A positive response from the Government to the recommendations for increased support for the education of gifted children is essential.

As the previous Chairman of the former Education and the Arts Committee, I express my appreciation to the members of that Committee for their cooperation and diligence on the reference. As Chairman of the Select Committee, I extend my thanks to the members of the Committee for their help and for the spirit in which they undertook the task of completing the inquiry and finalising the report that I have presented today. To all those who contributed to the inquiry I also extend my gratitude. Mr Acting Deputy President, I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the previous Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts and as a present member of the Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children, I wish to speak briefly to the motion and to the Committee's report. I personally found the work of the Committee absorbing. The evidence given and the visits around the States were particularly valuable in obtaining an understanding of the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the report of this Select Committee is most important because it concerns Australia's most vital resource-our talented people. The gifted and talented have been sadly neglected in our education system in the past. While those with learning difficulties have been greatly assisted to achieve their full potential, the same attention has been denied those at the other end of the scale, who need it just as much. The stated aims of the Federal Government will not be served unless gifted and talented children are looked after. The December 1987 Green Paper on higher education stated that Australia requires a better educated and more highly skilled population to deal more effectively with change. Gifted and talented children have a potential, as yet untapped, to contribute enormously to the better educated and more competent and highly skilled work force that we need.

When we talk about gifted children, we are not just talking about children who are clever. We are talking about children with the ability and potential to perform at a level considerably superior to that of children at the same age. We are talking about academically gifted children but not only academically gifted children. It is important to refute the suggestion that the talented will automatically fulfil their own potential. This is certainly not the case, as evidence that we received made quite clear.

By way of example, Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw to your attention a report that was given to the Committee. The Centre for Education at the University of Tasmania, in my home State, conducted a rigorous study to identify intellectually able students and to analyse how far their ability is developed in the education system. To do this, it examined the entire grade 10 cohort in Tasmania in 1981 and continued to monitor its progress in subsequent years. The researchers found that of those students in the `high' and `very high' potential categories-and 23 per cent of the grade 10 school population in Tasmania in 1981 were in those categories-23.7 per cent did not progress beyond grade 10 to any type of further study. Further, in the `most able' category, twice as many girls as boys dropped out after year 10. In other words, an unacceptably high percentage of the brightest students often drop out at an early stage of their education relative to their potential, and this was confirmed by a number of witnesses; it was not just the case with Tasmanian students.

Maximising the potential of gifted and talented children should not be seen as elitist. Nor should it be done at the expense of other children. The cake should be of sufficient size to give a fair go to everyone, including the gifted. I draw attention to the fact that the Soviet Union has programs to look after the gifted and talented which are not considered elitist by any means, but are regarded as a sensible and desirable way to maximise the potential of its people, and consequently the nation.

Not only the children themselves, but also our nation will benefit from encouraging our most able to reach their full potential. At present, the opposite is tending to happen. The gifted and talented tend to the under-achievers and have behavioural problems owing to a lack of stimulation and extension. At an early stage of their schooling they start being treated as disruptive, problem students. They then develop an aversion to school and continue to behave in the way they are expected to behave. Eventually they drop out.

Frequently they are not recognised as being gifted. Even when they are recognised, they are often a nuisance and a threat to class teachers. There is an imbalance in the way resources and attention are given to those who are talented on the sportsfield, compared with those who are gifted in other ways. I quote from the Committee's report:

The Committee noted with concern the comparisons drawn between the situation of the talented sportsperson and that of children with other talents. It finds the situation quite anomalous that gifted young athletes, for example, can receive intensive coaching in special institutions and can engage in international competition at public expense while this treatment is generally denied those with academic, artistic or other talents.

Parents, teachers and communities all rally to raise funds to help these young sportspeople along their way, but we do not see that same rallying of support for the academically or artistically gifted and talented to extend their experience and learning.

State system programs have a variety of ways of providing for the gifted, and we received evidence about a number of programs in the States. The Committee visited all States, and it is clear that all, to a greater or lesser extent, can demonstrate programs for the gifted. However, I believe that what they are in fact giving is really educational enrichment, which is the right of all children. The States rarely have programs which are effectively targeted just especially for exceptional children. In my view, a notable exception was the University High School in Melbourne.

Innovative programming in the field of gifted education was encouraged between 1981 and 1985 by small grants under the Commonwealth Schools Commission's projects of national significance. That has now ended and the gifted and talented are totally dependent on what the States provide. While this recognises the constitutional reality of the States' responsibility for education, it does nothing to further the national need for the expansion of our skilled and educated work force. For isolated children in particular, the amount available from State governments is very little. It is clear that isolated children are not given sufficient opportunities to develop to their full potential.

In the light of the limit to Commonwealth responsibility for education, the Committee did not make recommendations which were outside the Commonwealth's ability to implement. Consequently, we have concluded that there needs to be a clear Commonwealth statement of the need to provide special educational strategies for gifted children in this country for the sake of the children and of the nation.

Teacher training institutions, although State run, use Commonwealth money and we recommend that, in the use of that Federal funding, student teachers should learn more about the needs of gifted children, special techniques for identifying them-an area that is often not well understood-and strategies for teaching them, because often teachers feel threatened by the prospect of teaching such children.

The Commonwealth has also given priority to the education of girls, Aborigines and disadvantaged children. There are obviously numbers of gifted children in these special populations, and the professional development of all teachers engaged in educating these children should include attention to the needs and teaching of gifted children from these populations.

Some interesting experiments are being carried out around the country in an effort to improve the opportunities for educationally disadvantaged children. For example, the Committee received evidence that Aboriginal children in Western Australia who were slow to respond to `pen and ink' teaching responded much better to learning on computer. It is a salutary thought that we are not well equipped to identify the talents of children, like these Aboriginal children, who may not shine in the standard classroom situation.

The Committee has also recommended that the professional development of all teachers in the education of gifted children be supported by the Commonwealth. There are a number of very positive actions which the Commonwealth could take which would help in the education of these children. They are set out in recommendations 5 to 9, and include the development of videos and associated materials for isolated gifted children, and the establishment of a national centre for research into the education of these children and its financial support by the Commonwealth during its establishment phase. They also include priority to be given to expanding the information on the education of gifted children within the Australian curriculum information network, and we recommend that this information be made accessible not only to educational institutions but also to the special interest groups concerned with this sort of education.

The Committee received a great deal of evidence of the work being done by dedicated individuals and voluntary organisations such as the State associations for gifted and talented children in the provision of vacation schools for children, seminars and workshops for parents and teachers. These together with national competitions for science and maths are at the forefront of efforts to encourage our most gifted children. I personally believe that the dedicated people who give their time in these ways tend to put the State education systems to shame. While I appreciate the value of volunteerism, these people cannot be expected to do the whole job, and to provide these educational opportunities totally out of their own pockets and time.

The Committee has recommended that the Government expand the small amount of financial support that is currently given to these volunteers in providing opportunities for children which are not being provided by their schools and which are of great importance to the long term well-being of the children and to the advancement of Australia. I strongly commend the report to the Senate because of its national significance, and I urge the Government to speedily adopt and implement the recommendations which are responsible and achievable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my fellow Committee members who have already spoken-the Chairman, Senator Colston, and Senator Newman. Indeed, I recognise that the Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children, of which we were three of the four members, succeeded in this inquiry as a result of the work done by the former Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, of which we were three of its eight members. The inquiry was conducted over the past 2 1/2 years and we have now presented the report of this rather long-ranging inquiry which extended over parts of two parliaments. I add my own thanks to those expressed by the Chairman to the staff who assisted the Committee. I thank not only Mr Magi, who is present in the precincts of the Senate this afternoon, but also Ms Barbara Allan, who helped us very much in the final preparation of the report; and I also thank Mr Brown, Mr Bessell and others who assisted us during the deliberations of the former Standing Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the remarks of the Chairman with regard to expert witnesses and I also commend the excellent material presented to us by specialists in this field, and I refer to Dr Braggett, Mr Imison, Professor Start, Dr Mossenson and others. I not only note their specialised expertise, which is too little known in Australia even in educational circles, but also by commending them in a special way support the finding of the report that their experience and conclusions should be more available in education departments and schools.

I also commend the associations that appeared before the Committee because after these specialist educationists the most commitment expressed came from parents and teachers who were members of various State associations for gifted and talented children. Two such groups especially spring to mind: the Peninsula Association for Gifted and Talented Children in the north-eastern suburbs of Brisbane, and the Association for Gifted and Talented Children in my own State of South Australia. They expressed enormous enthusiasm and reported to us on a wide range of activities that are now being conducted largely without any kind of government recognition, let alone support. The work of these very concerned people is to be thoroughly commended. Certainly nothing that we recommend seeks to undermine or replace the special work that is being done by these volunteer parents and teachers.

I will now refer briefly to a couple of matters in the report. The terms of reference of the Committee are set out in the preface to the report, and during the conduct of the inquiry I took special interest in terms of reference (b) and (g). Term of reference (b) states:
consider the extent to which schools generally have the objective of pursuing excellence.
Term of reference (g) states:
Consider whether the pursuit of excellence in mainstream education is consistent with providing for the educational needs of all children.

I highlight these two terms of reference because the majority concentration in the report naturally was on programs for minority groups of children with gifts in particular areas and on how to assist those children to reach their full potential. However, these broader matters of interest were by no means neglected by the Committee and we considered the old furphy that too many teachers of the 1970s and their disciples who still linger would say that it is not possible to concentrate on the pursuit of excellence in schools because the priority must be to help every child achieve the basics. I reject that distorted argument and I believe that it is entirely consistent for teachers in a particular classroom or for those responsible for a whole school program or, indeed, any educational program, to equally pursue the achievement of basics by all children and the pursuit of excellence by those children.

One notorious example that has been put to me on many occasions is the deplorable activity in some schools-schools that are too much losing the confidence of many parents-where teachers are not setting homework for able students because they would otherwise excel and disrupt the task of teaching the remaining students by creating too wide a range of knowledge or achievement. That kind of `lopping off' of the tall poppies is inexcusable and it receives no support in the report. As I say, the concentration of our inquiry and our conclusions is on the particular programs for gifted and talented children. As Senator Newman said so admirably before me, we have identified particular groups of children for the provision of special education, but why should we neglect the minority who in different fields, different academic and artistic areas, should also receive special treatment so that they reach their full potential. I refer to page 173 of the report where there is something of a definition of `gifted children', as follows:

Gifted children are those with the potential to perform at a level considerably superior to that of their age peers. Giftedness is not a fixed, unvarying concept. It can be found in all social and ethnic groups and amongst the disabled. In some instances in announces itself through remarkable achievement, while in other cases it remains undetected and unfulfilled.

This description of giftedness is not elitist. It says-and I have yet to hear anyone sensibly deny this-that every one of us has a gift in one area of activity or another and that if we truly encourage our colleagues, peers or children, we will help them to become aware of their own gift or gifts and that will encourage them to pursue their gift or gifts so that their full potential is achieved.

This is not to say that when there may be a multiplicity of programs to encourage that giftedness each one of them is an elitist activity. I think that the lie has been put to that. So some of the old phoney arguments of the 1970s for not pursuing gifted and talented programs and not pursuing excellence in all educational programs are put to rest by this report. Secondly, I wish to refer to the important educational goal of achieving potential. I quote from page 174 of the report:
The Committee refutes the suggestion that talented students will automatically fulfil their potential, unaided.

That was another furphy of the last decade-that one can give special assistance to lowest achievers but of course one cannot give assistance to the most able to enable them to fulfil their potential; they are so able that they will do it without any kind of special program or assistance. That is just not true. The examples of sport and music are two very good areas to focus on to put to rest this false argument. It is right that in our schools, indeed beyond our schools, we in Australia encourage participation by all in sport and music but that does not deter us from identifying those particular individuals with a special aptitude in a particular sport or with a particular musical instrument and encouraging them, with great enthusiasm, to achieve their full potential. I put it to honourable senators that our best musicians and best teenage sportsmen would not have achieved that potential even though they had the gift, talent and aptitude to so achieve, had they not been given a special program and special encouragement in that sport or in that music. The report continues:
Studies of high achievers nearly always point to the influence of supportive individuals or institutions. Research indicates that there are many gifted children who under-achieve.

Few would deny the right of children to develop to their full potential. In practice, however, this right is tempered by a consideration as to whether, by advancing the chances of some, we are adversely affecting the chances of others. Many are fearful that by furthering the talents of the most able, we are neglecting our egalitarian ideals and are guilty of elitism. The Committee is convinced this is not the case.

The Chairman has already referred to the Select Committee restraining itself in its recommendations, of which there are only nine, to the national focus-that is, to programs which can be facilitated and initiated by the Commonwealth Government. There is much in this report that I believe will be of stimulus to State governments and to local schools and associations. I also believe that it will be a real fillip to the existing voluntary associations of parents and teachers in assisting gifted and talented children. Therefore, there will be many in the States and in the individual institutions who will refer to the report and take their own action as a result. But the focus is upon those matters which we believe the Commonwealth can initiate and act upon.

I conclude by drawing a parallel with the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on programs to assist isolated children and also on providing better television programs for children. Over the last decade or more-indeed, over the last 15 years-throughout the existence of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, no better examples can be found than those two areas where the Senate Committee conducted inquiries about the nation and brought down reports in this matter that led to Commonwealth action. These reports have been of great assistance to many Australians. One flowed from the Senate inquiry into the needs of isolated children and the other into ways to improve the television provision for Australian children. I do not need to outline the particular existing programs that are now in place that were not there 15, or even 10, years ago. I believe that this good report of the Select Committee is a benchmark. It makes a call for the Commonwealth Government to initiate a program that has a similar dimension to these two precedents-that is, through Commonwealth initiative and in concert with the States, individual institutions and many parents and teachers, to see that such programs will be of genuine assistance for gifted and talented children and that they will encourage everyone involved in education in Australia to pursue excellence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few very brief comments as a former member of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. I am very pleased that this report of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children has now been put down in the Senate. I am even more pleased to note that the Committee has unanimously agreed that the provision of facilities for gifted and talented children is not elitist. That gives me great heart, considering that that was not the belief of the former Minister for Education, Susan Ryan. She said that the pursuit of excellence was elitist. That was the matter that was uppermost in my mind when hearing evidence that was put before the Committee because it concerned me that in various areas it appeared that the gifted basket weaver was in fact more important in some schools than the gifted academic. We must all remember that the gifted academic is a very important resource for Australia in the years to come. If we are not going to encourage the academic as much as we encourage other gifted or talented children, then we are sacrificing a very important resource.

SPEECH.PARA: I also felt, as has been detailed in the report, that some of the teachers really did appear to feel threatened by some of those gifted children. They felt inadequate in some areas to deal with them. That is why it is particularly important that teachers become better equipped and they are provided with the facility to become better equipped so as to feel less threatened by those particular students. It is through the ability of those teachers to encourage, nurture and educate those children that they will be that resource to which I referred earlier.

My belief is that education is largely for States and that there should be minimal, if any, input from the Commonwealth in the lower years of education. I think that this is recognised to a degree by the Committee report. I hope that the Committee can keep the Government to the commitment of minimal input in terms of costing and factual, while making sure that there are those provisions. Those children who need special attention at the less fortunate end of the scale-and particularly the academic scale-need and should receive special attention. But by no means should the gifted or talented children not be encouraged or provided for. That is where I think Australia had a real hang-up not so long ago-that if one were to provide for gifted and talented children, that would be seen as elitist. It was a great tragedy that some teachers felt that way also. Many gifted and talented children were not given maximum opportunity because some teachers believed that they should be given more work of the same kind in preference to more work of a more difficult or taxing nature. That was very sad to see. Some children were suffering as a result of an attitude whereby, if they finished a maths class in double quick time, the teacher would simply say, `Go away and do another 20 sums' in preference to saying, `Let's sit down, go through it and give you some more difficult ones', thereby pushing those children further ahead. That situation needs to be corrected very quickly.

Recommendation 6 recommends the establishment in a tertiary institution of a centre for research into gifted and talented children which would be funded by the Commonwealth. Within the bounds of my feeling that education is a State responsibility, I think that that recommendation is probably the most desirable. Probably it needs to be a Commonwealth responsibility to get some unanimity in the approach taken in this area. I hope that the States will learn what is needed and desirable and will actually implement the recommendations that are put forward as a result of such research.

As I said before, this is a very important report for the future of many young Australians. I sincerely hope that gifted children will receive more attention and recognition as the vital resource to Australia that they are. I congratulate the Committee on bringing down this report. I am only sorry that I was not a member of the Committee in this Parliament and could not see it to its finalisation. However, I am absolutely delighted to see the recommendations which the Committee has put down.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled Non-statutory Bodies-Further report, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report I have just tabled contains the Committee's consideration of the Government's response to our previous report on this subject. The Committee recommended the establishment of a central register for non-statutory bodies which would include key data on their establishment, functions, membership, financing and staffing. The Government has agreed that such information should be available but in the annual reports of departments and other, unspecified parent bodies. The Committee reaffirms its recommendation. A central register should be required for management as well as accountability reasons. It is surprising, indeed, that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet does not have such information anyway so as to be able to provide informed advice to the Government on machinery of government matters.

The annual reports option upon which the Government relies cannot be regarded as adequate. Little more than half the departments comply with previous government guidelines or freedom of information requirements to publish information on non-statutory bodies clearly, if at all. It is a method which converts accountability into an obstacle course. For these reasons the Government should proceed without delay to establish a central register as previously recommended by the Committee. Not to do so is rather like having a library without a catalogue.
I seek leave to have the remainder of my speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-

The Committee's previous report, tabled in August 1986, recommended that, for each non-statutory body and each non-statutory body sub-body, a document be prepared briefly outlining essential data and that the relevant Minister be responsible for lodging the document with a co-ordinating department such as the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, to form a central NSB register.

The Government response, tabled in December 1987, rejected this recommendation in favour of a proposal that the relevant information should be incorporated in annual reports of departments and unspecified parent bodies in the interests of devolving and streamlining administration.

In its further consideration of the matter the Committee invited Professor Christopher Hood of the University of Sydney to give evidence on the issues involved. Professor Hood pointed out significantly that even in an environment in which administration was being devolved and streamlined it was still necessary for central authorities to have some strategic information available to them, at least to fulfil the central part of government's traditional responsibility `to make sure that one part of the bureaucracy does not undo or duplicate what another part of the bureaucracy does'.
He continued:

The decentralised management model in government does not necessarily remove the need for that traditional machinery of government function at the centre of government. It is just as important that the centre of government performs that function in relation to non-statutory bodies as it does for departments.

The Committee also examined departmental annual reports to assess compliance with an earlier Government decision, announced in the Senate by Senator Grimes on 20 March 1985, that details about non-statutory bodies, their principal activities, membership and staffing, should be included in departmental annual reports.

In each of the three years involved, little more than half the departments complied. Nor did performance improve after the Freedom of Information Act was amended to require inclusion in annual reports of information on the organisation and functions of agencies which did not report separately to responsible Ministers. There were even more departments whose reports did not include either information on NSBs or statements required under the Freedom of Information Act.

Indifferent performance of this order gives no grounds for confidence in the Government's December 1987 response. It, moreover, calls into question the policy of recourse to departmental annual reports for the discharge of important government-wide accountabilities. The Committee accordingly believes that a central register of non-statutory bodies should be established and maintained because information of this type is integral to the proper management and accountability of the machinery of government. It is, moreover, puzzled to find that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet does not, as a matter of course, hold such information in order to meet its own responsibilities as the central department of government and the department responsible for advising the Prime Minister in the discharge of his duties.

A central register is necessary so that current information is at all times readily available. Annual reports, by contrast, can provide information current only at the time of preparation. A central, continuously updated register is required for accountability as well as management reasons. Convenience and simplicity of access are important characteristics of proper accountability. The Government's approach, as set out in the response, would be practicable only for individuals or organisations already well acquainted with the non-statutory bodies sector. For the rest it would convert accountability in the field into something of an obstacle course.

It should be stressed, in conclusion, that in reaffirming its earlier recommendation the Committee has had full regard for current objectives of streamlining administration, devolution to departments and elimination of unnecessary costs. It is simply not clear to the Committee that these objectives are well served by the Government's approach to this particular matter. It is important that governments should have key management data of a strategic nature readily available in current form.

It is equally of concern that the accountability structure of Commonwealth administration should be clear, open, simple and easily accessible. The costs of meeting these objectives by establishment and maintenance of a central, continuous register are slight; the benefits, on the other hand, will be much more easily realised than if the thus far ineffectual annual reports method is followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is a very significant report. The useful simile that Senator Coates used is quite apposite because it is indeed like having a library without a catalogue if one does not have a form of central register. What is significant about the way in which the report came to be compiled is that it had a long and tortuous history which culminated in correspondence between the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Coates, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I congratulate Senator Coates on his determination in pursuing the matter with the Prime Minister. The ultimate outcome of that was that the Prime Minister provided reasons which I would have thought verged on sophistry for not accepting the Committee's recommendation that a central register be accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister said that the decisions announced in the response to the report were decisions of the Government and it would not be appropriate for officials to appear before the Committee to give reasons for them. I would have thought that that was the first alarm bell in looking to see whether there were any valid objections. It was then said that the reason a central register should not be set up was that information about non-statutory bodies was to be provided in a more efficient manner in annual reports. That is a completely self-serving statement because it did not go on to explain why it would be more efficient. If the object of the exercise was truly to allow ready access to this type of material, one would have thought that it would not be efficient in any sense of the term-certainly not cost efficient, but work efficient even less so. One has to ask why the Prime Minister was prepared to try to justify his failure to cooperate and, in my judgment, to defend the indefensible. He went on to say that there were a number of wider contexts within which the Government's decision should be seen. Those included the Government's ongoing efforts to streamline the public sector, remove duplication and simplify administrative processes.

Those are mere words. What we are talking about here is an amorphous mass of non-statutory bodies. There has been very little comprehension of their extent. Despite the valiant efforts of this Committee, chaired by Senator Coates, the reality is that any one-off investigation that the Committee might undertake can quickly get out of date and there needs to be a constant updating, even if it is done on an annual basis, in order to bring together the various unique characteristics of the bodies. They number in their hundreds and vary enormously. The Committee has recommended that a whole set of information and data be compiled. The Government's response was, `That is all very well. We accept the thrust of the recommendation to that extent. We would like to see the various departments responsible for collating that material'. By making that strategic concession, it has blown the ultimate basis of the defence out of the water.

The Committee was very fortunate in having before it an expert on the subject-Professor Christopher Hood, who has studied the system in the United Kingdom, where there is a limited form of central register. We all recall his appearance before the Committee because, in a very cogent manner, he demolished each and every argument against the retention of a central register. He began by elaborating the arguments that are traditionally put forward to justify not having a central register. Having demolished those, he addressed himself to the particular proposals. I think that, at the end of the day, we were all very much of the view that the position adopted by the Government was little more than mere subterfuge.

Professor Hood said that the first traditional reason given is that it is not feasible to establish a central register. The most cogent demonstration of the fact that it is feasible is that the Finance and Public Administration Committee, in its earlier life, did just that. Pointing to the register maintained in the United Kingdom, Professor Hood was able to give first hand evidence of the effectiveness of that, as far as it went. The fact that the Government had asked departments to provide that very information in their annual reports again is a demonstration of the manifest feasibility of such a register.

Confidentiality is the second traditional objection raised. Again, the fact that the departments are going to have to provide this information and have it available on the public record simply pulls the rug out from under that defence. The third objection was cost. What Professor Hood said here was particularly devastating because, given the fact that departments are going to be responsible for collating and retaining this information, the great bulk of the cost will have been incurred in that very process. Professor Hood said that the only additional cost of the information then being centrally collated would be of the order of $3,000 a year if it were done on an annual basis. He pointed out that it would involve about two weeks work by a person at graduate level and that the process of extracting the data, having already been collected by other departments, would be a very simple and mechanical process. So, again, the third traditional reason is simply out the window.

The fourth objection is relevance. Professor Hood went on to make some very telling arguments in favour of relevance. He argued that the public does have a great interest in this sort of information. He pointed out that not just the Parliament but the public and public officials should be aware of the total dimensions of the system. I think it is certainly very true that it is impossible to make sensible judgments about the size of government, about the necessity for a whole range of non-statutory bodies, unless one has the broad picture at some stage. One simply cannot consider a matter on a case by case basis because there are so many cases and they all vary tremendously. One has to stand back at some stage and ask what the effectiveness is of having a plethora of such agencies and what the cost is in terms of efficiency and otherwise. Professor Hood made it very clear that he thought there was a substantial public interest in having the information collected centrally.
Professor Hood also made the point that there is a tendency in political debate to exaggerate the number of bodies. He said:
. . . a central, governmentally maintained register which demystified this subject and that produced some basic information would, I think, perform a valuable demythologising function.
Again, I think that is something that we should all be aspiring to. There is always a tendency to use figures for one's own defeat and argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not do that, Richard!

—I point out to Senator Haines that if one does not even know what the figures are, one can have a field day. That is the problem here. An Opposition may want to argue that the size of government should be reduced. It might say there are thousands of public servants, that they are everywhere and one cannot keep track of them. The government will say, `Well, that is your mere assertion. The reality is that there are only a small number and they are in only a certain number of areas'. One simply cannot get down to having a concrete discussion on factual data. That is where Professor Hood made a very valuable point. He was trying to take the politics out of the argument and address the facts.
—That is a bit of a radical move!

—I know. It is unusual. Over the last five years we have grown accustomed to the opposite. Nonetheless, it is never too late to be converted. I think Professor Hood was conscious of the fact that these principles should be adopted irrespective of which government is in power. Undoubtedly they will contribute to better management. Professor Hood said that some strategic information available to government would assist it to fulfil the central part of its traditional responsibility to make sure that one part of the bureaucracy does not undo or duplicate what another part of the bureaucracy does. I think those words should ring bells with anyone who has had even the most tangential dealings with government. Again, a very valuable service would be performed if this information were centrally available.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the end conclusion by Professor Hood was a fairly devastating indictment of the Prime Minister's feeble defences on the matter. Therefore, I think we are entitled to ask why it is that governments resist the obvious. I think the only reason can be that information is power. If one is in control of the system, one can make it very difficult for the ordinary citizen who wants an answer to these sorts of questions: What is the cost of operating a whole series of non-statutory bodies; how many of them are there; what work do they do; do they have central requirements; who appoints them; and do they have finite life- times? The answers to all of those questions by a government that does not believe in a central register would be, `Well, you go off and work it out for yourself. You go to all those departments. You collate the figures. If you are really that interested, you will come up with an answer. Of course, we will then presumably question your methodology. We will say that you were not very professional and that is just your view of the world'.

TALK.START.PARA: —A cynical view, Senator Alston.
—Perhaps it is. But the way to destroy that cynicism is to have that information collected on an objective basis and to ensure that one does not get into those endless and fruitless arguments.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I think one has to come to the conclusion that the Government is really cynical in terms of the public interest, that it is putting secrecy ahead of information, that it is wanting to keep control of the material and deny access to the ordinary citizen. Those are the very sorts of principles that I would have thought the Finance and Public Administration Committee should be very anxious to preserve. That is why I pay tribute to Senator Coates for pursuing the matter as vigorously as he has. No doubt one could quite easily have said, `Well, we have a response from the Prime Minister which details a number of pseudo arguments and there is not much further that we can take the matter'.

Ultimately, I think all members of the Committee took the view that the response was inadequate and that the arguments put forward by Professor Hood and others were overwhelming. Accordingly, we have made a series of what I believe to be very sensible recommendations that will hopefully lead to the maintenance of a central register in a current form-in other words, regularly updated. The register would include all bodies except departments and statutory authorities. It would contain information across-the-board that would be of great assistance in making decisions on government administration. It would lead to a systematic assessment of the need and continuing justification for non-statutory bodies.

In conclusion, I welcome the report of the Committee. I share the Committee's puzzlement that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet does not, as a matter of course, hold such information in order to meet its own responsibilities as the central department of government and the department responsible for advising the Prime Minister in the discharge of his duties. I express my own surprise that the arguments that were advanced did not meet favour with the Prime Minister and the Government. I can only hope that now that this report has been tabled and now that the logic of it is apparent to the public, we will ultimately see some change of heart and that logic, for once, will rule the day.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to table, for discussion purposes, a draft Bill covering the transitional provisions necessary for the introduction of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory, together with notes on the draft, and to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the draft Bill and the notes. As can be seen by the front page, the tabling of this Bill was scheduled for yesterday, 17 May. Unfortunately the debate on papers was lengthy and time ran out.

SPEECH.PARA: The draft Bill that I have tabled complements the Australian Capital Territory (Constitutional Provisions) Bill which I tabled in draft form on 18 April. That Bill, as I stated then, provides a framework for self-government. I tabled the Constitutional Provisions Bill, and presented it, through the media and various community associations and groups, to the people of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) to try to achieve the maximum possible discussion within the community as well as in the Parliament of this very important transfer of power. As the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) stated in a Press release dated 13 April, it will be `the most significant transfer of power on a population basis by the Federal Government since independence was granted to Papua New Guinea by the Whitlam Government in 1972'.

Obviously, the transitional period will be of crucial importance in the orderly establishment of the new body politic, the self-governing Australian Capital Territory. This draft Bill, the Transitional Provisions Bill, provides legislative machinery for the transition. Most importantly it provides for the transfer of power to the ACT Legislative Assembly from the Commonwealth, the transfer of land and land management from the Commonwealth to the ACT, while recognising certain specific Commonwealth rights and the transfer with full protection and entitlement of Commonwealth public servants to the ACT service. The Bill also requires the Commonwealth to meet the cost of overcoming the backlog in the revision of ACT laws which the Commonwealth has allowed to develop.

The Australian Democrats support the fundamental principles of self-government and democracy. There have been some popular expressions of opinion which might indicate that some citizens of the ACT feel that self-government will incur increased costs, increased bureaucracy and increased complexity. All the parties in this place are agreed on the necessity for self-government. Precisely because the governing body is representative and accountable, self-government gives every citizen the means to direct and limit expenditure. Further, living in a democracy is not meant to be easy. Not only do we enjoy the rights of free citizens in directing our own affairs but also we are placed under the democratic obligation to participate in public matters. The people of the ACT have been deprived not only of this right but also of this obligation. I commend this Bill which is the second in a series of three self-government Bills.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1987-88[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1987-88APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1987-88SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1988-89SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1988-89SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1988-89]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A moment ago when Senator Alston was speaking to the report tabled by the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration he made a plea for logic, for facts to be brought into at least the occasional argument in this place and for people to stop acting in self-interest. Indeed, when I was cut off in my prime when speaking before lunch, halfway through an impassioned speech on the Appropriation Bills-if one can make an impassioned speech on the Appropriation Bills-I was making precisely that point. I was saying that here we are dealing today and, it would seem, for the rest of this week with Bills which seek to appropriate money for the Government through its departments to spend on various services to the community. We do this twice a year. These Bills being debated now are the supplementary appropriations to the major legislation that went through the Parliament in the Budget session last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I made the point that it is this expenditure which is the target for many groups in the community-groups such as the Business Council of Australia, the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Council of Social Service and a variety of other interest groups which want various changes made to this spending-an increase in it for their particular group, a decrease in it for some reason or other or a variation in spending patterns. I made the point that in particular when groups such as the Business Council of Australia are arguing for government cuts in expenditure they rarely call for extensive cuts in the area of corporate welfare; they limit their cuts to the areas of health, social security and education. Furthermore, having called for those cuts they very rarely then take the next necessary step and argue where those cuts should be made and who is to be deprived of services as a result of the Government's being deprived of its capacity to spend. The third argument that is often put by these groups is that if we have spending cuts in areas of health, social security and education we can then finance cuts in the corporate tax area in particular-a tax area which many of these people and organisations claim, quite inappropriately, is too high, arguing that many other countries have much more benign tax systems-particularly more generous corporate tax systems than does Australia.

I pointed out just prior to lunch that indeed if one believes everything one reads in the Australian Business magazine-who does not?-its list of the top 500 companies printed earlier this month indicates that in the top 50 companies quite a significant number are paying nowhere near the tax that the average pensioner or the family on average weekly earnings or less is paying. I cited among the examples listed Elders IXL Ltd, paying tax at 10.5c in the dollar, Ansett at 14.3c in the dollar, Bond Corporation at 8.9c in the dollar and Bell Group at 10.5c in the dollar. I particularly highlighted the example of Elders IXL because it is the chairman of that company who is constantly claiming that it would be better for most Australian companies to go offshore. He says that the tax benefits would be better and that it is high time we cut expenditure.

I issued a challenge in my speech before lunch to people such as Mr Elliott and to organisations such as the Business Council of Australia and to the various chambers of commerce and industry around the country to say who is going to be the target; who is going to be on their hit list for losing out if we cut expenditure in the areas of social security, education and health. I asked whether they were not satisfied with the areas that had already been cut. I asked whether they were going to require that we no longer perform hip replacements on elderly people, that we not provide expensive cancer treatment, that we not supply life support for very premature babies-all in aid of cutting Government expenditure so that the corporate tax rate and the top tax rates for the very well off could be instituted. The same lack of detail and the same lack of specifics is very evident in their calls for cuts to social security expenditure. We have already seen the Government heavily cut back in these areas so that widows who received the class B pension have now been forced on to unemployment benefits, ex-service personnel have had a 2 per cent cut in their post-retirement income, family allowances are means tested and age pensioners are further behind the economic eight ball than ever because of the delay in consumer price index increases granted to them. All of those things are passed through this Parliament with the support of Opposition senators.

As far as education is concerned, one wonders too how much further we can cut this very vulnerable area. We have already seen $30m cut from technical and further education (TAFE) funding-the very area which provides the main training and re-training programs for ordinary Australians who need to upgrade, update or redirect their skills. Is this reduction in expenditure going to be picked up by the private sector which is currently arguing, for example, that we do not have enough skilled people in this country and need to increase immigration programs in this area? Are they, in the interests of having a highly skilled, relevantly skilled, work force, going to make bequests and donations to TAFE colleges in order to pick up the expenditure that the Government has withdrawn under pressure from these people who want to see public expenditure cut back? Of course, the answer is that they will not.

By and large business and industry in Australia have an appalling record when it comes to their contribution to education. For example, Australia has one of the worst post-war records for research and development funding, from both the private and public sectors, of any comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country. Almost every other advanced, civilised country in the world recognises that a country's future development depends on a skilled and educated population and on appropriately funded universities, research programs and various organisations such as TAFE colleges.

We have to face the fact that if we do not have a well-educated population in this country we are never going to be in the race with the big technology leaders. We have already suffered because of our blinkered attitude to the manufacturing sector, relying as we have for decades on our export market from the rural sector. That has all changed. It has changed dramatically. We have to recognise these facts. The end user of the education system in this country is not the student who graduates or improves his or her knowledge; the end user of the education system is the community at large and business and industry form a significant part of that community. They should therefore be prepared if not to offer funding directly to tertiary institutions to at least accept the fact that consolidated revenue funds the future education of our students and hence provides the necessary skills and training.

It is about time that groups such as the Business Council of Australia and people such as John Elliott came clean. If they are going to call for expenditure cuts, they ought to say who will no longer be a beneficiary of the expenditure-little old ladies, small children, youngsters at school, the education system, the health care of the nation. We cannot have limited spending in these areas and then expect unlimited access to facilities. As I said earlier today, it is an enormous irony that many of the executives who are calling for cuts in health care funding are the very ones whose lifestyles and the highly stressed nature of their occupation mean that they finish up on the operating table for a bypass operation or they finish up having to have treatment for lung cancer because they smoke themselves into an appalling physical condition, or they over-indulge in alcohol, which produces physical problems as a consequence.

We cannot have it both ways. As Senator Alston said earlier on a different matter, it is time we got some logic and some facts into these arguments, got rid of the rhetoric and started talking a bit of common sense. They should either call for funding cuts and then say who is going to be hurt as a result or leave things as they are. To justify a demand for expenditure cuts on the ground that Australian companies are over-taxed in comparison to those in other countries when we have companies such as Elders IXL Ltd paying less than 11c in the dollar in tax and News Corporation Ltd paying less than 20c in the dollar in tax is quite outrageous.

I turn now to the second reading amendment which has been foreshadowed by the Opposition. This, too, is strong on indignation but short on elementary facts. The amendment asks the Senate to note a couple of things. It asks us first of all to note Australia's $86.77 billion net foreign debt at the end of December 1987 and its continuing balance of payments deficit on the current account which increased by $1,185m during March 1988. Nowhere in that noting does the Opposition amendment point out that over two-thirds of that foreign debt is owed by the private business sector and that much of it has been borrowed for certain players in the big league in Australia to partake of the game of local monopoly whereby they borrow huge amounts from overseas in order to take over another company, write the interest off against their tax and have a taxpayer-subsidised little frolic in the economic sphere. Nor does the amendment point out that over half the remainder is owed by State governments, at least some of which debt has been caused by the fact that the Federal Government has been cutting grants to the States, again under pressure from the business sector which wants to see federal expenditure cut back.

Paragraph (b) of the amendment asks the Senate to note the Government's inappropriate response, which has been to increase taxation revenue collections to the highest level in post-war Australia. It does that without noting that while personal income tax has certainly formed a larger percentage of tax collected, corporate tax has fallen dramatically as a percentage of tax gathered and that this flies in the face, of course, of what has been happening overseas. It certainly does not bother to point out the sorts of tax percentages that are being paid by some of the top 50 companies, much less the top 500 companies, in Australia. Paragraph (c) of the amendment asks the Senate to note the urgent need to reduce public sector outlays as the major element of a Government policy response to our current economic difficulty.

Like the John Elliotts of this world and spokesmen for the Business Council of Australia and chambers of commerce and others, the Opposition gives no indication in these amendments of which public sector outlays it would want reduced. Does it want age pensions cut back even further? Does it want family assistance packages reduced even more? Does it want hospital funding and funding for schools removed? Does it want to take Senator Bjelke-Petersen to task for comments that she made earlier today that more money should be spent on road funding? This is something I would have thought would get the support of every South Australian senator in this place as well as the support of the Queensland and Western Australian senators, all of whom are aware of the fact that those three States have been getting a quite disproportionate share of road funding grants.

Would the people who are arguing for reduced public sector outlays want to argue that Senator Calvert was wrong this morning when, presumably speaking on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia-certainly he was speaking on his own behalf-he argued that we should not be cutting funding to people already facing serious disabilities and the disadvantages that come from that. Most certainly I am sure they do not mean that we should cut public funding of private schools for example, that we should cut public subsidies to corporate take-over merchants of the sort I mentioned earlier, or that we should not have a couple of years ago paid off to the tune of several hundred million dollars the private banking sector and the big oil companies when they threatened to increase their costs to the consumer.

I remind the Senate that when we gave something like $125m to the private banks in order to stop them from raising home mortgage interest rates it was at a time when they had made record profits for about four years in a row. We can find money for them and it is rarely criticised, but at the same time we hear continual demands from the group which benefits from those sorts of subsidies that government expenditure should not be directed at the needy, at the least well-off in the community. It is high time that the public and the Press started asking exponents of spending cuts to name the victims on their hit list. It is no good their keeping on giving front page stories to high-flying business people who say that Australia is never going to be on the road to economic recovery until we cut health, education and social security expenditure without also asking and demanding an answer to the question: What areas are going to be removed, what children are going to be hurt by cuts in health, education and social welfare funding, what elderly people are going to remain in pain because they have no access to the operations they need for a hip replacement because there is no funding?

What long term problems are we asking to have in this country if we do not fund the needy, if we do not accept our responsibilities as governments and parliaments to keep families on low incomes with their heads above water. Only when that happens, when the Press and the public start to demand answers to those sorts of questions, will the Australian people be able to assess the credibility of the Liberal-National Party coalition and their supporters in business. Only then will the Australian public be truly able to assess how they and their families will be affected in the future if governments now or later accept as accurate the argument that funding must be cut for Australia to get on its feet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to join in this debate and to support the Opposition's foreshadowed amendment in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, which notes that Australia's $86.77 billion net foreign debt at the end of December 1987 and its continuing balance of payments deficits are matters of major concern; that the Government's inappropriate response, which has been to increase taxation revenue collections to the highest levels in post-war Australia, is another matter of major concern; and noting the urgent need to reduce public sector outlays as the major element of a Government policy response to our current economic difficulties. That amendment has been belittled by Senator Haines-not surprisingly-because the Australian Democrats consistently look to all elements of government spending as if they are sacrosanct, as if there is no waste, as if all government spending is somehow magnificent and goes only to those in need.

SPEECH.PARA: As with so many things, if only what Senator Haines was saying were true. If only that were true, the problem would be extremely difficult and beyond the scope of the Government. The reality is that this Government has built up a massive pattern of government spending, particularly in grants to people with whom the Australian Democrats have curious links. The Australians Democrats love, for example, all the government grants to the greenie organisations. I have no doubt that much of that money eventually ends up one way or another supporting the Australian Democrats at election times. I am sick of taxpayers' money being diverted to people such as members of Senator Haines's Party and then hearing them say that any attempt to cut government spending is somehow disgraceful.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit hypocritical.

—Senator Messner says that it is a bit hypocritical. He is a gentleman. I would say that it is enormously hypocritical. I am sick of the disgraceful attempt which Senator Haines persists with to suggest to the people of Australia that any attempt to cut government spending must mean an attack on the poor people who are desperately seeking some kind of assistance with their health, for example, or who will need a pension because they are in desperate need. One looks at the enormous waste in the delivery of many of the Government's services, particularly in the area of health, and at the ludicrous nature of some benefits. For example, a report today has demonstrated that the way the Hawke Government goes about paying family benefits at the moment encourages divorce. The report, which quotes the National Priorities Project, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The incentive for low-income families to earn extra income has been destroyed by the interaction of the Family Allowance Supplement (FAS) and the tax system . . .
. . . the present tax regime may also encourage couples to separate and draw welfare benefits as single parents.
`Interaction of the FAS and high marginal rates of income taxation result in significant disincentives for many families to seek extra hours of work or job promotion' . . .

According to estimates . . . about 120,000 working families on incomes up to and including those on average weekly earnings are subject to very high effective marginal tax rates . . . of 80 per cent or more.

Here we have not only Government spending but also Government taxing measures working to people's specific disadvantage. Yet Senator Haines pretends that every attempt to cut government spending is somehow disgraceful.

There is no doubt about the volume of waste. My Waste Watch Committee certainly exposed disgraceful volumes of incredible waste. I was overjoyed to see in a recent report from the Australian Government's Commissioner for Employees' Compensation that he has changed the arrangements relating to the payment of workers' compensation because of some rip-offs, last year saving $35m. I believe that the Waste Watch Committee should be congratulated for having dramatised those rip-offs, just as we have dramatised the multi-millions of dollars of wastage on Government rents. The Government pays for office space which it leaves empty for periods of up to 18 months. The ludicrous time the Government takes to fit out new offices that it is moving into means that they lie idle sometimes for two years while the Government pays enormous rentals amounting to multi-millions of dollars. I give the Government notice that I will be providing some very interesting information in the near future on the extent to which this waste of public money, taxpayers' money, is going on.

We have many indications of this kind of waste. I was intrigued in this debate earlier today to hear a Government senator attempt to defend the self-indulgent spending by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of taxpayers' money on his own residences, particularly Kirribilli House in Sydney, which was supposed to be being done up, renovated and repaired so that it would be available for visiting guests of government during the Bicentennial. After the spending of three-quarters of a million dollars, not one visiting guest of government has occupied Kirribilli House. We were told in this debate that this is because it was not finished on time and there was plaster and so on around the place. The reality is that the renovations provided for in this year's Estimates, to which the Appropriation Bills before us apply, involve something like $50,000 per room in interior decorating. That is as much as an ordinary family would spend building a whole house. That is just the cost of interior decorating. The structural renovations cost about half a million dollars. The expenditure of $50,000 a room is the same sort of rate that was spent renovating the Lodge. I am not involved in the politics of envy; all I want to do is get rid of the hypocrisy on the Government side which suggests that everyone, except the Prime Minister, should pull in his belt.

Before I deal with some serious matters relating to the economy, I mention that waste is continuing enthusiastically under this Government. Annual reports by this Government's committees, departments and statutory organisations are, of course, an essential way of informing the people of Australia, through the Parliament where these reports are tabled, of what is happening in the myriad of Government organisations which in so many cases intrude on our personal activity. In so many areas they should be disposed of to private enterprise and restored to a competitive arena. Let us see what having the Government reporting actually does, apart from the fact that it means that in many instances we get our reports many months after the statutory limit and certainly many months after the date on which a public corporation would be fined for having failed to produce its report.

Let us look at the costs of these reports. I am absolutely appalled at the reckless way in which taxpayers' money is being spent by some Government organisations. The individual amounts are not enormous; the principle is.

The Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority's annual report for 1986-87 cost $14.36 a copy to produce. As another example of the Government's high capacity to make losses, they are being sold through the Commonwealth Government bookshop for $4.40 each, representing a net loss of something like $10 per copy. Why in the first place should the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority put out such an incredibly glossy and expensive annual report? I certainly have seen no justification for it. It is only one of the many, however. We can go through the list. The annual report of the Merit Protection and Review Agency costs $15.45 a copy to produce. Each report of the National Capital Development Commission costs $13.33 to produce. These are thin booklets. Each report of the Special Broadcasting Service costs $11.85 to produce, and it is being sold for $8, losing only $3.85 a copy! That is a decided reduction in the rate of loss! Each annual report of the Australian Film Commission costs $19.99-say $20-to produce. There might be some special reason why the Australian Film Commission should go to that enormous expense to produce its annual report. Maybe there is some commercial benefit and if so I would like to see evidence of it. Each annual report of the National Library of Australia costs $15.74 to produce.

In looking at other normal sorts of reports, one finds that the Department of the Treasury, for example, spends only about $3.80 per copy to produce its report. It costs the Australian Audit Office $3.12 per copy, and there is plenty of information in it. The Australian Audit Office certainly gives us a very detailed annual report.
