The Australia Council report costs $8.56 per copy. In other words, some $25,000 of Australian taxpayers' money is being spent just to produce the annual report of the Australia Council. The report of the Australian Film Commission costs, as I have said, about $20 each; the total cost of producing its annual report is about $50,000.

If other government organisations can do it at the $2 or $3 mark, why is it costing $20 for these organisations? Is there any control over the costs? Even fairly historic and significant organisations which have a message to get across, like the Australian Heritage Commission, can do it for about $3.35. The Australian National Gallery report, which is certainly a very glossy publication is produced for $7.50. But as I said, we have the National Library producing its report at about double the cost of the Australian National Gallery report. But is the Government taking any interest in this? Does the Government care that $27,000 has been spent just to put out an annual report for the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority, the reports costing some $14.36 each?

It appears that there is no restraint on these matters. There is certainly no restraint on the sorts of prices being charged and there is very little control over all those organisations in terms of their getting their annual reports out on time. The report of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority costs $8.23 to produce and it is sold for $1.60. That is another example of how this Government is expert at losing taxpayers' money. Of course, most of these reports that I have outlined were not released until the end of February this year-and they relate to a period that ended in June of the previous year. That is almost three months over the statutory time limit-something that would result in a public company being fined.

Large government organisations like the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation are respectable. It puts out some 9,000 annual reports and they cost $2.30 each. Such reports are very informative and effective. However, I believe that many of these others have gone right over the top, without any concern at all about costs. In this context, may I congratulate the Parliament House Construction Authority, which I am consistently bagging in this place: it has put out a very informative annual report, and it cost only $3.60 to present.

I believe that this situation is ludicrous, particularly in the context of the Government having put out guidelines to departments about what their annual reports should be like. Those guidelines say that reports should be concise. Well, they seem to be concisely spending up to $20 for each of those reports. Some of them are incredibly bulky; there are plenty of pictures of people but not necessarily volumes of useful information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of Ministers.

—As Senator Messner says, there are plenty of pictures of Ministers and other people who have political merit while this Government is in power, but the reality is that among the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports there is not one mention of the need for any care to be taken or restraint to be exercised in the spending of money. Is this not typical? The Government provides to its statutory bodies and departments pages and pages of guidelines about what sort of report they should produce but with not one word concerning restraint in the expenditure of money. What intrigues me is that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has, as usual, been monumentally indolent in this area. He is a man who certainly speaks at great length about the need for restraint and control of government expenditure, but in these matters over which he has direct control he has in fact done absolutely nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: I now want to deal with some more significant matters, although I must say that this lack of control of costs, as evidenced by the Government's approach to these annual reports, is simply yet another example of what I believe is a reckless indifference by this Government towards the spending of money. That is one of the reasons that the coalition considers that it is absolutely vital for government spending to be reduced, and reduced considerably-because under this Government it has, of course, soared. We keep on hearing that this Government has shown restraint, but the facts and figures simply deny that. The reality is that since this Government came to power the increase in real terms-having constant dollars with no inflation-in government spending has been enormous, averaging, in 1979-80 prices about $1 billion a year. Compare that with the rise in government spending that occurred under the previous Government of only some $700m a year.

I admit that the increase under this Government is nothing like the enormous 33 per cent increase that took place during the Whitlam years. However, there is no doubt that in the first two years of the Hawke Government this increase did represent very much a Whitlamesque approach. All restraint in the last couple of years has simply been in relation to holding down the excesses that took place during the first two disastrous years of the Hawke Government. It would be more honest if this Government, when talking about its great achievements, did not just talk about last year and the year before but revealed to the public just how appalling the total rise in government spending has been under its control.

That is why, in our view, the only way to get taxes down, the only way to resolve the sorts of excessive pressures which are now becoming evident in the Australian economy, is to cut government spending by far more than this Government has had the courage to do. We must recognise that the Government's cuts have related only to cutting its own fat, the fat that the Government itself generated. It is not cutting into any basic government services and it is certainly not cutting into much basic government waste, although the efforts of the Waste Watch Committee have generated some sort of political imperative on the Government to do so, and to an extent the Government has responded to that political imperative.

However, there is a lot more to be done. There is no denying that the evidence clearly shows that the Budget surplus that the Government will come out with this year has been directly the result of a massively increasing tax burden on Australian families-apart from some asset sales. This has been despite the so-called tax cuts of December of the year before last and of July of last year, which, in fact, were the sorts of tax cuts that result in people paying an awful lot more in tax. They are the sorts of tax cuts that are political stunts, and they are the sorts of tax cuts that no doubt the Government will repeat in the run up to the next election. They look good but they certainly do not result in any reduction of the total tax burden and, as I have said, that tax burden has massively increased.

Under this Government total taxation revenue has gone up by about 80 per cent. That is just an enormous and dreadful burden. It has increased by 80 per cent, while the inflation rate has gone up by something like 40 per cent. Taxes have just about doubled the inflation rise over this period. So now people know why this Government can appear to be restrained. It can appear to have done the right thing by having a Budget surplus, which no doubt will be discussed in the May statement very shortly, but that Budget surplus has been bought basically at the cost of the taxpayers of Australia rather than, as should have been the case, at the cost of government spending, which should have been cut much more drastically. The shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, said quite recently:

The basic message is that the Government has more margin for manoeuvre in the next Budget than has been the case in recent years. If they have the political courage-the very political courage that Senator Walsh lamented as lacking last year-to cut expenditure substantially in real terms, personal income tax can be reduced while still budgeting for a surplus. Tax cuts should be introduced without delay to provide additional incentives to work and to invest.

The essential difference between the Labor Government and the coalition is that the Labor Government believes that it solves its governmental problems by taxing Australians more and more, whereas the coalition believes that Australia's basic problems relating to working and investing can be solved by cutting taxes and giving people more incentive, by producing a people-led rather than a government-led recovery. That essential difference will be demonstrated more and more often in the run up to the next Federal election.

Some people have wrongly said-and they sought to undermine the Opposition's tax policy before the last election-that any reduction in income tax that emerged from cutting government spending would lead to a massive burst in consumer spending and thus to a huge increase in imports. It was alleged that that would destroy Australia's prospects of recovery and worsen our balance of payments problem. That is self-evident bunkum. If a government finances a tax cut by cutting government spending, it cuts the government's ability to import and spend. It replaces government spending with personal spending and spending by Australian businesses to make them more efficient and more able to compete. By allowing personal spending by Australians, people have more scope to save; so they can invest in expanding Australia's capacity to produce. Yet that was the level of the unfair and ridiculous attack on the coalition's tax policies.

May is a big month for the economy, and we have already seen some of the things that will happen this month. Next week there is the mini-Budget, and we have already had the Premiers Conference and the Loan Council meetings. There are also prospects of wage deals. At the Premiers Conference, there was another of these extraordinary changes of tack by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Quaintly, they are generally commended by the media, which appear to forget what he said the previous week. At the Premiers Conference, once again the Treasurer was saying all sorts of disastrous things about the economy, although no doubt today, with the release of some interesting balance of payments figures that show a reduction in the deficit, he will be saying that this proves that everything is going well. However, these jumps, hops and starts by the Treasurer are ludicrous. They show a lack of foresight and determined policy by this Government. There is no doubt that the May statement will not take the opportunity to do what should be and must be done to get the economy out of trouble.

Today's balance of payments figures show that the seasonally adjusted figure for imports is still up about 15 per cent on the figure for April last year. The trendline for imports has risen to a record level. What these figures hide is the fact that Australia is still in desperate trouble with its balance of payments. We have income debits, particularly the money we have to spend to pay interest on our record borrowings overseas, on our massive overseas debt, that have also reached a record level. We were helped out of the mess by a fortuitous, perhaps temporary, strong rise in commodity prices. We cannot keep living on good luck and hoping that commodity prices will get us through the problems we face. I am particularly concerned that the spate of temporarily good figures will reduce the Government's willingness to take the kinds of action that must be taken. Taxes must be cut and government spending must be reduced so that Australians can get on with the job rather than having the Government dominate our economy, stifling incentive and hope.

As a result of the Australian Labor Party's disastrous performances at the New South Wales election and in recent by-elections, I believe there is a real threat that Labor backbenchers, particularly from the left wing, will be pressing the Government to take the soft option, which is not to cut back on areas of spending because some of these cuts may be difficult to explain. They will be pressing the Government not to sell off those government enterprises which are at present a drain on the Government, which involve the Government in massive borrowing for their re-equipment, and which represent a burden on the taxpayer. However, the left wing of the Labor Party has already recently denied the right of the Government to make sales of such enterprises, thus denying what is in fact economic reality.

Thus, all around we will see this Government getting weaker and less able to cope with the pressures it faces. There is no doubt that the Government's readiness to accede to union demands for a return to inflation-linked wages is a disaster. The only wage increases that should be granted are those accounted for by productivity improvement, because otherwise there will be no improvement in our living standard. The only improvements we can achieve in living standards are through tax cuts and productivity gains. Inflation-linked wage rises have been shown over and over again to be not only a waste of money but also illusory, because they push up the cost of producing goods in Australia and make us less competitive. They push us down the Argentinean road about which the Treasurer was talking a couple of years ago. He then decided we were doing well and that success was just around the corner. At the Loan Council meeting, he said that things were bad. Now things are good again. It makes one wonder just what the Government has in mind.

Cuts in government spending undoubtedly release resources to the private sector. I am proud to be a member of a party that is keen indeed to see that lower taxes should be introduced as an incentive both to work and invest, thus increasing the productivity that we need. Instead of providing tax cuts by reducing government spending, the Treasurer has now said earlier this month that there will be no tax cuts this year. The Government is prepared to forgo sensible and necessary spending cuts that would benefit the economy and improve the financial position of Australian families. The Treasurer is missing this opportunity only as a result of the panic that has gripped the Labor Party following its loss of electoral support among traditional Labor Party voters.

I am not making out this case simply because it is what the coalition believes. There is a wide and impressive collection of views about the disastrous impact of excessive government spending and particularly about excessive government taxes, such taxes largely being raised by an enormous increase of about $4 billion in consumption taxes under this Government. We have heard all this debate about whether a consumption tax should be introduced. This Government has introduced it already, and to a large degree it is now the fastest rising tax in Australia. The National Australia Bank Ltd, Westpac Banking Corporation, and the Australian business conditions section of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd have all spoken about the risks now existing in the economy if the Government does not make a severe cut in its spending. Much of that spending is wasted and misdirected and must be cut if we are to have any real cuts in taxation.

These warnings from the private sector all over the place are most important and must be taken seriously in the May statement. I will be concerned as, indeed, should all Australians, if the inflationary pressures now building up are not acted upon. We have already seen the inflation forecast blow out this year, since in nine months we have almost reached the inflation level that the Government predicted would occur in a full year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak to the Appropriation Bills and cognate Bills, and I express my grave concern about what is happening to the health of the people of this country and the position that they are being placed in thanks to the Hawke Government. Thanks to this Government we have an absolutely unprecedented list of crises hanging over our heads. We have strikes by doctors and nurses resulting from more than shabby treatment by governments, queues and waiting lists for surgery which were never experienced in Australia until Dr-non-medical-Blewett started fiddling with the system, and costs to the individual which are now totally out of proportion. I remind the Senate that it is meant to be a free health system whereby all people are universally covered by the Government, and it is meant to contain an insurance package to ensure that they receive medical and hospital treatment if and when they need it.

SPEECH.PARA: A fake levy has been set at 1 1/4 per cent of income yet we all know that, if the Government were honest, the levy would have to be nearly 4 per cent to provide the total costs associated with health cover. Will the Government be honest? The answer is no. Will the Government increase the levy? Who knows. Will the Government reduce the benefit? Who knows. All these things have been talked about. If the Government gives an undertaking that it will not increase the levy, it is not much of an undertaking anyway because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Dr-non-medical-Blewett gave such an undertaking prior to the 1984 election. What happened? They upped the levy. So any undertaking along those lines means little or nothing.

People now have to borrow huge sums of money to obtain urgently required surgery because their Medicare coverage means absolutely nothing when they are in real need. Families are having to go into endless debt to look after their loved ones, the aged and the infirm. Individuals no longer have the right to cover themselves totally for health. It does not matter whether one pays twice-paying the Medicare levy and the private health insurance contributions. Under this Government one cannot insure for the gap. Somehow or other the Australian public has let the Government get away with this. Imagine if this Government or any government said that one could insure one's home for only 85 per cent of its value and not the rest-there would be absolute war in the streets. However, that is what this Government has done in respect of the health of this nation, which is probably more important than most property.

Government expenditure has been growing at a phenomenal rate-in fact, it is 9 1/2 per cent this year over the 1986-87 figure-yet the Government still cannot cure the ills in the health system. More money is being given to the States to assist in reducing waiting lists, but the lists just keep on growing. It is an absolute joke that the Government actually spends more money trying to reduce waiting lists, yet the lists continue to grow. At the moment, at a conservative estimate, there are over 100,000 people on those lists across the country. It is a sick and sorry story, but Australians need to be aware that a vote for this Government is a vote that in the end can place their lives at risk. That may sound dramatic but, sadly, it is true. One need only talk to the families of some of those who have suffered, who have not been able to obtain treatment and who have died while waiting at the bottom of the list. Those families know that it is true. It is not hearsay; it is fact. Only yesterday many newspapers in Australia carried a stark warning about how bad things are. An article in yesterday's Daily Telegraph was headed `Patients wait 70 weeks for surgery'. Having just spoken to my colleague Senator Newman from Tasmania, I believe that that figure is a gross understatement with respect to how long patients must wait in that State, but I believe that she will cover that matter later. Even if 70 weeks is an accurate statement, how can we possibly sit back and say that that is satisfactory? The article in the Daily Telegraph states:

Patients are being forced to wait up to 70 weeks for surgery because of the crisis in the State's public hospital system. An audit of the hospital network revealed yesterday at least 40,000 patients are waiting for surgery. And in some hospitals patients face the prospect of waiting until 2,000 others in front of them are treated.
So 40,000 patients are waiting for surgery in just one State. The article continues:

In the 10 main teaching hospitals alone, about 12,000 people need surgery. And there are even hundreds of youngsters who cannot get immediate treatment at the big children's hospitals. The worst delays are in the western suburbs.

That is, the western suburbs, in New South Wales. This Government also purports to look after those in need, those who are less fortunate; but this is the area where most people are being affected, What does the Government do about it? Absolutely nothing. The article continues:

At Westmead Hospital, at least 2,100 people are waiting for admission. People requiring orthopaedic surgery face delays of up to 70 weeks; those wanting ear, nose or throat operations can expect to wait 40 weeks; and even neurosurgery patients can't be admitted for up to six months.

That does not include those who are waiting for bypass surgery who, as I have said, drop right off the bottom of the waiting list and into a grave. It is tragic and it is about time that this Government did something constructive to ease these problems.

We are talking about many people who, in the first instance, may not suffer from life-threatening complaints but, nonetheless, thanks to this Government, suffer many months of pain and discomfort and a deterioration in their lifestyle. I do not believe that it is right for any government to impose a deterioration of lifestyle on any individual, let alone 100,000. The Government opts to put people on invalid pensions in preference to providing a health system that can effectively and efficiently cure people. So if you become too sick to work you should not worry about it because you will be put on an invalid pension. That is enormously clever logic! The Government simply pensions them off. However, make no mistake about it: most of these people would far prefer to be out there working and enjoying a healthy lifestyle. The Government policy of the day is not to provide that facility but to deny these people their jobs and put them through pain and discomfort.

The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has been ducking and diving all over the place in recent weeks while attempting to establish exactly what money he will give the States next year. On the one hand, he says that he proposes to increase the Medicare compensation grants yet, on the other hand, when the sums are done at the end of the day it is found that no money has been allocated whatsoever to cater for any increase. More alarming is the suggestion that the States actually cut back accepting Medicare patients because the States do not have sufficient funds to care for them. It has been advocated in some States that they need more private patients, who pay up to $150 a day, so that the hospitals can obtain some hard cash.

Earlier today we heard Senator Haines bleating away as she normally does about the need for more money for this and more money for that. There is little that I can ever agree with her on, thank heavens, but today she spoke about people who are not receiving treatment when they need it. I think the problem is that there is no flexibility whatsoever and one is locked into a government operation whether or not one likes it. As I said before, if people take the option of insuring with the private sector, they must still pay into the Government's coffers for a system that does not work. It is a pity that Senator Haines and some of her cohorts have not looked at some of the other options available to replace this bureaucratic monster whose tentacles are going out all over the place and strangling the Australian health system.

Let me remind the Senate that this is supposed to be a health system that is not only free but also looks after everyone. That claim is simply dishonest. If anyone is inclined to think that the enormous problem with waiting lists is an accident, and that it is even more of an accident that those waiting lists keep growing, then he should stop thinking that right here and now. It has been clearly demonstrated in New Zealand that the waiting list phenomenon is an excellent way for governments to ration the provision of health services. The following quotation from Dame Dorothy Fraser, a most respected health administrator from New Zealand, could well apply to Australia. However, she was referring to New Zealand when she said:

The public will identify access as the greatest failing of the present system . . . Unless you are an accident victim, covered by Accident Compensation, or develop an acute condition such has cancer, you join the 50,000 people on waiting lists who need hospitalisation . . . The New Zealand public hospital system uses waiting lists to ration its services and encounters great difficulty in determining patients' priorities . . . Uncomplaining, less articulate and poorer members of society tend to gravitate to the end of queues.

The New Zealand system, like ours, is of course promoted by a socialist government pretending to look after the less well-off and the poor. Yet these are the very people who are being more seriously affected. The big difference between what Dame Dorothy Fraser said about New Zealand and the situation in Australia is that New Zealand only has half the number of people on waiting lists. There is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that this Hawke Government has failed dismally to provide an effective health system that is meant to be free to all Australians.

This Government cannot even treat seriously or take appropriate measures to prevent the spread of the dreadful disease, acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). This Government hides behind an advertising campaign-or two, or three-and says that it has fulfilled its public responsibility. I do not believe that it has even gone part way to fulfilling its public responsibility. Once this epidemic gets out of hand, and probably when it is too late, the Government may sit up and do something serious. As of today-and these are the latest figures available today-441 Australians have died of AIDS. This figure is growing month by month. It was only 426 last month; it is now 441. What does this Government do? It does nothing. it runs public awareness campaigns alerting people in various categories.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rot.
—Very interestingly, the Minister for Local Government has just woken up. She has just come out of deep slumber and said that that is rot. Is that not wonderful?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. That is a personal reflection on a member of this place and it quite obviously transgresses standing order 418. I ask that it be withdrawn.

—I rise on that point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. It would be a quite extraordinary ruling if you were to proceed precipitately on that basis. There is no standing order which forbids an honourable senator from being asleep in the chamber. Therefore, as being asleep is not an offence against Standing Orders, to have somebody say that one is asleep can hardly be an offence against Standing Orders. Frankly, it is only if the honourable senator actually starts to snore and thereby becomes disorderly that any offence arises. I submit to you that under those circumstances to simply draw attention to the fact that somebody was asleep, which is not a breach of Standing Orders, can hardly be something which should be the subject of a request that it be withdrawn.
—It seems that Senator Reynolds has not taken any personal offence.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I find it hard to take this seriously. Anyone who is in the chamber can see that I have far too much work to sleep either now or much later into the evening. I interjected when some of the claims that were being made by the honourable senator were just too much for me to ignore. For Senator Knowles to say that this Government has done nothing in relation to-
—That is fair enough, Senator Reynolds. I do not think you should go any further.
—I will not go any further but I can assure Senator Knowles that I am noting what she is saying and I find it very difficult to believe that she believes her comments are accurate.

—What an absolutely amazing set of circumstances. I am sorry that it is has caused Senator Reynolds such absolute trauma to be woken up at this stage-after all, it is only quarter past six at night. When this great awareness and awakening occurred I was really just trying to alert the Senate to the fact that the Government has done little about the treatment of patients who are suffering from AIDS. But at that stage the Minister--
—Rubbish.

—She has just said again that it is rubbish. If the Minister or any other member of the Government is able to answer the question honestly, he or she will be groping for weeks and months. Did they run a public awareness campaign alerting all people in high risk categories? The answer is unequivocally no. They ran a series of expensive advertisements that scared the wits out of half the population of Australia. It made a whole heap of people rush off and have blood tests. What was proven as a result of that? The overwhelming majority of those people were not in the high risk categories. This is the Government's fantastic advertising campaign. These people proved to be the least at risk. The great tragedy of this is that the Minister can sit there and condone what the Government has done. What has this Hawke Government done to alert those in the high risk group such as the drug users, the homosexuals, the bisexuals, the males who occasionally have sex with other males and do not consider themselves bisexuals, male and female prostitutes, the Aborigines, the teenagers, the prisoners and, of course, the sexual partners of all of those people? What has it done to alert them? Nothing; absolutely nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing the Government has ever done is tell all those people to wear a condom. I am at a loss to figure out where a drug user will wear a condom to prevent his getting AIDS. But that is the Government's advertising campaign which it thinks is absolutely top notch. So if this is where its campaign is headed, good luck to it, but I think it is a great tragedy for the people of Australia. It is appalling that this Government has, in real terms, increased recurrent grants for combating AIDS only marginally. While it may say that it has increased funding by $4m, that sum has to cover an absolutely toothless education campaign, medical research and contributions to blood screening. Also, within that $4m there will be $1m for the supply of the drug AZT which prolongs the life of sufferers. It claims to have increased funding. That $4m is not even a drop in the ocean.

We are not talking about the common old cold or tinea in this situation. We are talking about a disease that is now in epidemic proportions worldwide-in case the Government does not know. It is incurable and is 90 per cent fatal among those who are HIV positive. The way that the disease is heading it will have a higher mortality rate than most forms of cancer or heart disease. Health professionals have repeatedly advised testing for all people in high risk groups, but unfortunately this bright Government considers that a sop to particular interest groups is more important than the health of the community including, I might add, the unborn. It will continue to sop to particular interest groups.

The Government's cop-out is that there is not sufficient money to take the hard decisions. Yet it is prepared to spend more money on treating the disease. Surely prevention is better than treatment, particularly when there is no cure. Treating an AIDS patient is also more expensive than treating a person with cancer or cardiovascular disease. Why will the Government not take action? Heaven only knows. Last year, Dr Reanny, the Vice-President of the International Interdisciplinary AIDS Foundation, concluded that the cost to Australia of AIDS-related, hospital-based care will be about $680m by 1990, just over $1 billion by the year 2000 and about $1.7 billion by the year 2017.

It may sound rather prudish-if it does, so be it-to say that it is not good enough for governments to be spending public money on risk minimisation advertising-which is all we have seen to date-such as `Wear a condom' and wanting to put a whole bus in a condom. Has anyone heard of anything more ridiculous than trying to solve an epidemic that has a 90 per cent mortality rate in that way? Why are governments not utilising some of the resources that have been put in place and encouraging people to change their lifestyles to prevent risk? As I have said, that may sound prudish. If it does, I am quite prepared to live with it. I think that governments should be encouraging people to change their lifestyles in preference to just saying, `Wear a condom and you'll be okay'. I do not believe for one moment that any government can legislate for social attitudes; but I do believe that, faced with a fatal epidemic, they could encourage people to be more responsible.

Governments did not blink one jot in the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s when they required immigrants and residents to be tested for tuberculosis. They did not even blink when they brought in the practice of tracing partners of patients with sexually transmitted diseases. Yet there is no way they will take those types of measures to reduce the spread of AIDS. It is too expensive and too hard because they may offend some people. Once again, this Government has to consider whether it will sop to those interest groups or whether it will be responsible. I am afraid that there will be a continuation of the former in preference to the latter.

I, too, feel very sorry indeed for AIDS patients, but I have to confess that I feel even more sorry for those who do not participate in any high-risk practices but contract the disease quite unknowingly. What consideration does this Government give to those in the medical profession whose responsibility it is to look after and care for AIDS patients? None. The Government is hell-bent on doctor bashing and nurse bashing, as we have seen for years now. We have only to go back through Hansard from time immemorial to see what the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has said about the medical profession. We can see how much he cares about the medical profession. Of course, this is simply a further extension of that exercise. The attitude is, `If they get AIDS, that's their problem'. Once again, it is all too hard and all too expensive. That is the excuse. It is an absolute disgrace.

With the cost of treating an AIDS patient being estimated at $43,000, according to the Executive Director of the Fairfield Hospital in Melbourne, it is absolutely mystifying why the Government refuses to acknowledge the seriousness and on-going cost blow-out associated with the disease. Many AIDS patients, like so many other ill people, cannot afford to pay out huge sums of money for their care. Medicare is wrongly named; it should be `Medicareless', because that is the effect it is having on people who are ill from a whole range of diseases, not the least of which is AIDS.

The health of this nation is now out of control. The chaos is spreading like wildfire. The way in which the Government is spending the health dollar does not give anywhere near the best return and the Government refuses point blank to accept the responsibility for a serious, well-informed and effective campaign to reduce the risk of the epidemic disease AIDS. The Government is treating the health of Australians with what I believe is absolute and utter contempt. How many people need to die waiting for surgery? How many more children need to suffer unnecessarily? How much longer do the queues need to go beyond 100,000 people? How many more weeks than 70 will people have to wait?

Probably more importantly, by how much will the Government reduce the Medicare rebate or increase the levy in either the May statement next week or the second annual Budget-we now have two Budgets a year-in August? The Government is likely to adopt either of those measures, which will only further exacerbate the existing situation. Health is not a disposable commodity and it should not be treated as such by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knowles has talked tonight about the mess that has been caused by this Government to the hospital system and the medical system generally. Tonight I want to talk about the mean-spirited way in which this Government is whittling away the rights of our veterans. My husband is a former Minister for Repatriation and a returned serviceman. Therefore, I suppose I have always had a particular interest in veterans' affairs matters. I have very strong views about how this country should recognise the service that our veterans gave to it when they were needed desperately. We were very ready to send them away to war to defend us.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether we are prepared to continue turning a blind eye to their needs now that they are getting older and frailer and need more assistance. It seems to me that this Government is prepared to do that. In a very mean way, their benefits are being whittled back gradually bit by bit. The Government is never game enough to do it by way of a big cut, thus demonstrating what big fellows its members are; but it is prepared, in every Budget or mini-Budget, to make just a small adjustment here and a small adjustment there so that benefits to which veterans are rightfully entitled as compensation for their war service, not as welfare, are gradually disappearing.

I draw your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President, to the fact that in Australia there are 574,300 surviving veterans and 70,870 war widows. Obviously, the bulk of those people gave their service during the Second World War, although clearly many served in subsequent wars. But that means that they are mostly in their middle-sixties, late-sixties and seventies. They are ageing and are starting to suffer from conditions from which elderly people suffer. Frequently those conditions are exacerbated by their war service.

I draw the Senate's attention to what has been happening over the last couple of years to the entitlements of veterans and war widows. There have been changes to the totally and permanently incapacitated entitlements; there have been limits as to dental treatment; there have been reductions in the amount payable to them for travel allowance; access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme has been terminated for war widows and some service pensioners; a statutory patient contribution has been introduced for those who need nursing home care; there have been changes to the veterans' home health program; and there have been many changes to the defence service home loans scheme, which have been debated in the Parliament in the last few months and have caused confusion. I draw the Senate's attention to the quite unacceptable delays in the implementation of the scheme which has now reached mark 3 or mark 4. I have lost count of how many times the Government has told us that it is changing the scheme. That has not helped the veterans community.

I believe that one of the most mean-spirited of the Government's actions is the 2 per cent cut in the defence force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme pension base which the Government said it would restore when economic conditions permitted. Some 107,000 veterans have been affected by that cut of 2 per cent in the pension base. The Government, over two years, has made no attempt whatsoever to restore that 2 per cent. Yet it is quite prepared to tell us what a clever manager of the economy it is and how it is going into a Budget surplus.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was describing my particular interest in veterans' affairs matters. I was referring to the way in which the Hawke Government has whittled away the benefits due to veterans during its time in office. It is a very sorry record and the over half a million surviving veterans and the 70,000-odd war widows are only too well aware of how shabbily they are being treated by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Immediately before the sitting was suspended I was discussing the 2 per cent cut in the DFRDB pension base. The Government has told us that it is doing very nicely thank you in terms of the Federal Budget. The Government is putting it around that it will be able to announce a very nice surplus in the May economic statement. Some 107,000 veterans have been affected by the 2 per cent cut in the DFRDB pension base that was made two years ago. They are very curious and indeed anxious to know just when the economic conditions are going to permit the restoration of that 2 per cent.

The Returned Services League (RSL) has told us that the cut has a perpetual and cumulative effect on the pension base. In addition, the recent national wage case and the second tier productivity increases have placed DFRDB and other Commonwealth pensions affected by the cut further behind community standards. No date has yet been set for the restoration of that 2 per cent and it would be a very appropriate time for it to be announced in the May economic statement. I call on the Government to do the right thing by the veterans, who have been made to suffer much more than the rest of the community. (Quorum formed)

I am very glad to see Senators Coates, Devlin and Devereux in the chamber. Perhaps they will learn something about the Tasmanian scene that they are supposed to be representing to their Federal Labor Government. It is a pity that they do not represent their Tasmanian veterans a bit better. But as they are obviously not interested and are leaving the chamber, I will have to send them an autographed copy of Hansard so that they know the facts. It is not just the RSL which is concerned about the failure of the Government to restore this 2 per cent cut. All the veterans' organisations, and in particular the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association, have expressed great concern at the Government's failure to restore this earned and deserved benefit.

Tonight I want particularly to draw the Senate's attention to the very serious delays in medical and surgical care for veterans. This is something which has been gradually building up. The situation is now most unsatisfactory and something will have to be done. It is not good enough for the Government to be just messing about with the issue. I have pursued this matter for some time both through the relevant Estimates committee and through representations to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). As a Tasmanian senator, obviously my concerns are particularly with the veterans in my State. But the picture is reflected in other States. Therefore, honourable senators should be very concerned to see what is happening to the men and women who were prepared to go away and defend this country in time of war.

This is what is happening. In Tasmania it is currently taking at least 12 weeks for veterans to get hearing aids-that is, once they actually get to the National Acoustics Laboratory; it takes quite a while even to get to that stage. It is taking 12 weeks because the National Acoustics Laboratory cannot cope with the numbers. I recognise that this is not something that is governed by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, but it is a responsibility of Dr Blewett. My opinion of Dr Blewett's administration of his Department is none too high-no higher than that expressed by my colleague Senator Knowles earlier in the debate. I fail to see why veterans have to suffer as a result of the lack of resources in the National Acoustics Laboratory. It is well known that a much larger percentage of servicemen who were subject to gunfire in a war-time situation have impaired hearing than is the case in the mainstream population. It is quite unfair that they have to wait so long before they can be seen to be fitted with hearing aids.

However, this is not the main problem. I think a much more serious problem is that of waiting times for the various categories of elective surgery for veterans in Tasmania. It is intriguing to note what the Department of Veterans' Affairs calls `elective surgery'. According to the Department, surgery which is elective is treatment which is not required as an emergency to deal with life threatening situations. Well, I thank God that they are not life threatening situations. You will too, Mr Acting Deputy President, when you realise that orthopaedic surgery for veterans in Tasmania takes between 50 and 112 weeks-that is, one to two years-at the Repatriation General Hospital in Hobart. This compares with one year at the State-run Royal Hobart Hospital and 36 to 90 weeks at the State-run Launceston General Hospital. Urology delays are 26 weeks at the Repat, 10 to 20 weeks at Royal Hobart and 4 to 30 weeks in Launceston.

These delays are far too long for anybody with a urological or orthopaedic condition who is waiting for surgery. We are talking about people who are in pain and real discomfort and whose quality of life is very adversely affected. For the life of me, I cannot see why we have to put veterans at the bottom of the list when it comes to eligibility for surgery. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs and his Department tell us that the conditions are not life threatening, that they are elective operations and therefore people can wait. I tell him that it is not good enough. Clearly, this Government has to do better.

The Minister said that he could tell me what the factors were that led to these delays. I would like the Senate to know what the Minister gave as an explanation. In his letter to me of 10 May, the Minister said:

. . . a number of factors contribute to these waiting times, including insufficient orthopaedic surgeons in the State and competing demands for the limited operating theatre time and support services available.
He also said:

There are also the significant advances in medical technology which have made surgery a viable alternative for a higher proportion of people with orthopaedic problems. Aged patients now constitute a very considerable proportion of the total orthopaedic workload.

I am glad that the Minister recognises that. I hope he recognises that his whole constituency, his responsibilities, are almost exclusively veterans or very advanced years. So of course he should be exercising the utmost care and concern for aged people who need orthopaedic or urological treatment. The Minister seems to think those explanations are good enough. I do not. One of the things that he tells me in his letter is something that I find even more concerning, that is, that the Repatriation Hospital in Hobart is handling only three hip replacement operations a fortnight. Here is the crunch: two new hip replacement patients join the waiting list for every patient actually operated on. What is this Government doing when it cannot get ahead and the numbers of people applying for surgery are growing? The Minister tells me that there are not enough resources. It is in his hands to provide the resources. The veterans are going backwards.

I would like also to quote from a letter I received this week from the wife of a veteran who lives in Tasmania and who has just had orthopaedic surgery in the Repatriation Hospital in Hobart. It was a very gentle letter, not really complaining but asking me for help as to whom she should go to for advice and to make a proper complaint about the treatment that her husband has received. She had no complaint whatsoever about the medical care that he received. She stated that she was concerned:
He had had surgery and traction for approximately 6 days and despite feeling weak and unwell, he was requested to go home as the bed was needed.
She continued:
My husband is a TPI (1939-45 service) Middle East, Syria, Greece, Crete and New Guinea-
he certainly fought for this country-

and his related injury is war caused, so I feel at 74+ he is deserving of more consideration, especially as I have a dystrophy complaint, and having no family, find it difficult to cope with a sick husband just out of his hospital bed.

That is the service that the Veterans Affairs' administration and the Minister are prepared to countenance. They are not prepared to put in the resources to see that veterans get the bed care to which they are entitled and to ensure that there are enough surgeons and facilities to provide for their orthopaedic and urological needs. However, there are ways around it-that is, to make better use of the private hospital facilities that are available in the State and which do have spare capacity. The Minister did not advert to that in his letter to me, although it covered three closely typed pages.

The Estimates include an additional amount of $15m Australia-wide, $10m of which I was told at the Estimates Committee hearings was to cater for the increased demand. So at least the Department is recognising that for, say, the next decade we will have an increased demand, particularly in the areas of orthopaedics and urology. However, the Department is not providing enough. I was told that the revised target for Tasmania will go from 45 occupied bed days in the public and private sector up to 50. That may have some impact on the waiting lists but with increased demand it is clearly not enough, especially when we consider the quantity of people joining the lists all the time. As I said, that will continue for quite a while to come.

There is a diminishing population of these veterans. As I said earlier this evening the veterans are in the 65 years to 77 years group. Life expectancy for men in Australia is roughly 77 years. I ask honourable senators to consider that when one has a life expectancy of a maximum of 12 years, what does one or two years on a hospital waiting list waiting in great pain for a hip operation do to one? What is the quality of one's life? In the Minister's letter he criticised doctors who he said were not making it clear enough when their patients were urgent cases. He said that if the doctors were to reassess their patients more accurately, their patients would be able to jump to the top of the queue. I do not know whether the Minister is stupid or whether he thinks I am, but clearly if people at the bottom of the queue are pushed to the top that would not do much for the waiting times of those people who have thereby been pushed towards the bottom of the queue. What does the Minister think he will achieve simply by refining the process of declaring people to be urgent cases? It sounds to me as if somebody in the bureaucracy has fed the Minister a lot of bumf. Resources are needed, not bureaucratic refinements. If we really believe in compensation for war service then the veterans deserve some sort of special treatment, not lesser treatment than the rest of the community.

I was interested that the Minister in his letter compared the hospital waiting times in Tasmania with those of other States. He told me that Tasmania, New South Wales and Western Australia are similar in waiting times, that Victoria is marginally better, that in South Australia one must wait 24 to 28 weeks for orthopaedics and that in Queensland the wait is 5 to 16 weeks for orthopaedic surgery. However, as Senator Knowles mentioned in her speech earlier this evening, the New South Wales Minister for Health was reported in yesterday's Australian newspaper as saying:
In some Sydney hospitals it would take more than 70 weeks to clear waiting lists, which were longest for orthopaedic surgery, general surgery and urological services.

In other words, if one were in New South Wales one might have to wait a whole 70 weeks-something which I find quite unacceptable and clearly a result of the Government's mess-up of Medicare. However, if one is a Tasmanian veteran one will have to wait up to 112 weeks. I think the Minister does not even know how to read his own figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having disposed of that-

—I am glad that Senator Aulich has come into the chamber to learn about the Tasmanian situation because it is very important that we try to get him to speak in the confines of his party room; he is clearly not prepared to say anything publicly. Perhaps he might do something about his Government's attempt to palm off the repatriation hospitals on to the States. This Government has been trying to do that for some time now. Back on 18 February last year, in response to a question which I asked of the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, I was told:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the view of the Government and the view of the veteran community that we should maintain a separate repatriation hospital system.
He went on to say:

So I can give Senator Newman and in fact the whole Senate a complete assurance that, rather than closing down the hospitals, the hospitals will continue to be improved. At some time in the future-perhaps by the year 2000-the government of the day will decide the processes by which the Government's current intentions will be realised.

So there we have Senator Gietzelt, the then Minister, on record in the Parliament telling us that the Government was going to maintain a separate repatriation hospital system and that it would not be until about the year 2000 that maybe the Government would look at whether there would be any change. He said that in the meantime, while there were so many people going through, the Government would improve the hospitals. That is what Senator Gietzelt, the then Federal Minister, said. I do not know whether he was telling the whole truth to the Senate or whether there was a hidden agenda for the Australian Labor Party. I rather suspect that that is what it was all about. Only a couple of months later, on 30 April last year, we find a report in the Mercury about the Tasmanian Labor spokesman on health, Mrs Judy Jackson:

The Opposition spokesman on health, Mrs Judy Jackson, said the delay over transferring the Repatriation Hospital from the Federal Government to the State Government was for political reasons and there was no logical reason for the duplication of services in State and federal health systems.
Here is the very interesting bit, I think-
She said the hospital was a modern facility not being used to capacity-
can one believe it?-
and could be used for elective orthopaedic surgery as a way of decreasing long waiting lists at public hospitals.

It says something about Mrs Jackson's inability to cope with her shadow portfolio responsibilities that she seemed to think that the Repatriation Hospital was underutilised and that using it would be a good way of decreasing the public hospital waiting lists. In fact, the boot was on the other foot and it is the Repatriation Hospital which has longer waiting lists than the Royal Hobart Hospital. Clearly it was the intention, and remains the intention, of the Federal Labor Government to try to palm off the repatriation hospitals to the States. Of course, the RSL has different views about that. I will quote from an RSL document:
. . . on no account-
should the Federal Government-
hand over repatriation hospitals to the states until the demand from veterans reaches such a low level that the independent operation of each hospital is no longer economically sound.

Of course, we in the Opposition agree with that. However, clearly the Government has some secret agenda. Now at least we have on record what the Government is up to. However, in the meantime we have the problem of an overutilised facility, not enough funds being provided to allow more operations to take place and, clearly, an unwillingness by the Federal Government to make use of the underutilised private hospitals which are available for the sort of surgery that veterans need. I might add that although my State is relatively small, people visiting Tasmania are always surprised at how long it takes to get from one place to another because of the winding roads and hilly terrain. Therefore, it is helpful for elderly people to be treated near their homes. It would be much fairer for those veterans and war widows who live on the north-west coast, the west coast or in the Launceston and north-east districts, if they could be treated in a hospital nearer to their home. The Government has obviously decreed that it will not spend money on these people, who have given so much already to their country.

The day has not yet come for the Federal Government to pass this responsibility off to the States. The States are already unable to find sufficient funds to keep their hospitals running, and for that we have to blame the Federal Government's mishandling of Medicare and the blow-out in costs that we all recognise only too well. The Commonwealth has to find funds to enable veterans to be cared for in private hospitals so as to end these completely unacceptable and cruel delays. The Australian Labor Party should be ashamed of the pain its Government is inflicting on our old diggers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support these Appropriation and Supply Bills and oppose the amendment proposed by the Opposition. The amendment to which Senator Stone referred in his comments seems to point up the inherent contradiction in the Opposition's economic policy. It demonstrates that members of the Opposition do not seem to understand that in matters of government finance the whole has to equal the sum of the parts, and therefore we cannot increase each part and still have a smaller whole. Senator Stone spoke today of reducing government expenditure-he said this has to be the top priority in the Government's economic policy-and yet over recent days, and several times today, we have had examples of Opposition senators supporting the amendment and yet then going on to speak about the need to increase expenditure in their own areas of particular concern. Senator Hamer spoke recently of the need to increase expenditure on defence, which I understand is a view that has Senator Stone's support. Today Senator Bjelke-Petersen talked about increasing expenditure on roads. I do not know whether Senator Stone supports that or not, but I do know that Senator Bjelke-Petersen did say we have to spend a lot more money on roads. Senator Newman has just been talking, if I heard her correctly, about increasing expenditure on repatriation provisions. I am not saying any of those proposals are bad; I am simply saying that we cannot increase each bit and have the total somehow magically reduce.
—Don't waste it.

—The oldest argument in the book is that we should cut out waste. People who do not have the courage to make decent cuts just wave their wand about. The Opposition is heading exactly in the direction of the 1987 economic black hole. Those opposite want to cut taxes but increase expenditure to appeal to every little interest group that comes up. They are like the girl in Oklahoma who sang, `I'm just a girl who can't say no'.
—Don't be sexist.

—She sang the song; I did not write the words. Members of the Opposition cannot agree to have a consumption tax to fill this awesome gap in their economic policy. Yesterday Senator Peter Baume correctly pointed out some of the social consequences of reducing expenditure. When every interest group that knocks on their door says `Please give us more money' they say yes-but they are still going to cut government expenditure. It is wonderful to hear them putting this beautiful illogical economic argument, because it means that at the next election there will be a yawning black hole again. I can see their campaign now. Their arithmetic still does not add up, and they cannot and will not be a credible alternative government until it does.
—Why don't you give us a try?

—Fortunately the Australian people are much too sensible to give the Opposition a try. They proved it last July. I actually came here tonight to speak about something entirely different. I chose to speak tonight on an important initiative in the 1988-89 Supply Bills, and in particular in Supply Bill (No. 2), because they mark a very important first step in introducing State-type funding arrangements in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). It is a key element of the legislation, and Supply Bill (No. 2), in particular clause 6, establishes for the first time the Australian Capital Territory Trust Account, which is in effect the consolidated revenue fund of a self-governing Capital Territory. It is a very important step on the road to self-government and it is an important initiative by the Government, announced recently by the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) in a Press release and implemented in the Supply Bills coming into effect on 1 July for the 1988-89 financial year. For the first time there is a clear distinction in the Government accounts between national and territorial and municipal functions and expenditure accordingly, as determined previously by the Government in 1985 and adopted and reported on by the Commonwealth Grants Commission in its second report on ACT finances in 1986. The State-type payments to be made to the ACT are reflected in Supply Bill (No. 2). In relation to, for example, the Attorney-General's portfolio, and in the portfolios covering the Department of Community Services and Health, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Transport and Communications, we are starting to see for the first time in these Supply Bills important direct State-type payments to the ACT, starting to establish a proper financial basis for a self-governing ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: All the relevant ACT moneys which would otherwise be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund will be credited to that ACT Trust Account. In particular, sub-clause 6 (1) provides for moneys paid pursuant to the territorial administration of the ACT to be credited to the Trust Account. These receipts will include State-type taxes, stamp duties, rates, fees, charges, fines and penalties. Some of these, of course, arise pursuant to legislation and some result from the provision of goods and services. The Commonwealth is also to pay for services of a territorial and municipal nature provided to it by the ACT Administration. These payments will also be received in the ACT Trust Account. This is an important point in the debate that is going on within the ACT at the moment, because there are some fundamental misconceptions about self-government. Supply Bill (No. 2), if properly studied, will hopefully put to rest the concern that somehow or other, after self-government, the citizens of Canberra will have to pay more for the administration of their government. It will put to rest the argument that somehow or other services that are now provided magically and do not have to be paid for will have to start being paid for after self-government.

This Supply Bill illustrates absolutely and clearly what will happen to the Territory's financing after self-government. There will be simply a change of nomenclature, a change in the method of recording expenditure. It makes the current situation explicit-that is, the people of Canberra are paying for self-government to the same extent as people in other States, for example Tasmania. They are paying the same rates, taxes, stamp duties and legislative and service fees that arise in all the States. They are already paying for self-government. All the people of the ACT are missing out on is having a say in determining how that money is spent. The priorities being set at the moment are being set by people properly accountable for that money to the people of Australia as a whole rather than accountable to the people of the ACT in particular.

I welcome the fact that Supply Bill (No. 2) introduces this initiative because it does provide some possibility for identifying expenditure and it enables local people to start having a proper input into the determination of priorities. Until self-government such decisions can and must be made by the Minister for the Arts and Territories, who is accountable in the end to the citizens of Barton rather than the citizens of the electorates of Canberra or Fraser. They will therefore not properly reflect the priorities of the people of Canberra, and the Minister cannot be democratically accountable to the people of Canberra.

It has been fairly well established by my article-and what more reputable source could there be-in the Canberra Times-and somewhat more objectively by representatives of the ACT treasury that the extra cost of self-government could be 0.1 of one per cent. The figures supplied by the ACT Administration during the recent public debate concerning the ACT budget indicate that the ACT budget in its current state involves something like $900m.

The total extra costs of the provision of self-government to the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory has been assessed at possibly $1m-that is an extra 0.1 of one per cent of the Budget. So, the Supply Bills mark a very important stage in the progress of the Australian Capital Territory towards self-government. They mark a very important stage in the development of proper administration of the funds of the Australian Capital Territory and, in fact, despite this separate trust account, parliamentary accountability for this expenditure will continue. These expenditures will continue to be assessed by the relevant Senate committees, unless and until self-government is delivered to the people of the Australian Capital Territory and hopefully, this year, with the concurrence of the other parties in this Senate, that will be forthcoming.

Therefore, I regard this initiative as being very important. I welcome the fact that the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) has taken this initiative. On 28 April he announced these further reforms to the Australian Capital Territory financial arrangements and in referring to these Supply Bills he said:

. . . the Supply Bills . . . have been prepared on the basis of the ACT operating like a State as from 1 July this year . . . Major ACT territorial and municipal funding has been separated from Canberra's national functions and will form a stand-alone ACT budget operating through a separate Trust Account . . .

The ACT will receive Commonwealth Grants, determined in a similar way as payments to the States and the Northern Territory . . . The level of payments will allow for the additional costs of the national capital influences on the provision of the normal territorial and municipal services.

Concern has often been expressed that it will be much more expensive to administer Canberra than the other States and Territories because of extra costs imposed by the Commonwealth influences, the national capital influences here in Canberra, but the Grants Commission and the Cabinet consideration properly distinguishes those costs and responsibilities, and appropriate payments will be forthcoming. The first indication of that is reflected in the payments provided for in Supply Bill (No. 2). The Minister further stated:

The ACT's State-type taxes and duties, rates, fees, charges and payments for services provided to Commonwealth departments will be kept in the Territory. This will allow the ACT's budget priorities to be considered on their merits.

I welcome that initiative from the Minister, and it is an important move towards self-government. The debate here in Canberra is developing and moving ahead on this very important issue. People are starting to realise that the concerns of ten years ago that self-government would cost more-and I think it could be argued that ten years ago it would have-are no longer relevant. As they assess the information that is being made available by the ACT Administration they are becoming aware that these extra costs are already being met, that the preferential treatment that the Australian Capital Territory received in relation to funding for so many years, for almost 60 years, no longer exists.

In fact, payroll taxes in the ACT are higher than those in the States. We find now that the leaders of community groups, with whom I have regular consultation, and the leaders of business and unions are conscious of the difficulties that the lack of self-government makes for their respective interests. The issues that need to be resolved are starting to be turned around in the debate. One finds that nearly all the community group leaders, nearly all the leaders of business and, as far as I know, nearly all the leaders of trade unions, support self-government, because they understand that it is through that mechanism that they will achieve the opportunity to have their preferences and priorities reflected in the decisions of a self-governing territory, in the decisions made by properly elected ACT representatives, answerable and accountable, as should be the case in a democracy, to the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory.

Some 200 years after European settlement and, more importantly, 88 years after Federation, it is absolutely unacceptable that a quarter of a million people should be denied effective democratic representation in the determination of their own expenditure priorities in the matters that affect their daily lives. Nowhere else in Australia would people allow education funding to be determined by people not answerable to them. Nowhere else in Australia would the people tolerate decisions about the health system being made by the people not accountable to them. Nowhere else in Australia would people accept that the operation of the public transport system is not a matter to be determined by their locally elected representatives, those people not having a chance to do anything about it if they do not like the system.

Given the awesome list of speakers that are to follow in this debate-awesome not only in number but also in quality-I do not want to prolong this debate unnecessarily. I have risen to indicate my support for the Bills that are before the Senate and I particularly wanted the opportunity to welcome the initiative taken by the Government, particularly by the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Gary Punch, in submitting the Supply Bills in this manner, and in taking a major step forward for my constituents, for the people of the Australian Capital Territory. (Quorum formed) This could be the longest peroration in history, because I was actually just concluding by saying that I supported the Bills and that I welcomed in particular the initiatives taken in the Supply Bills for and on behalf of the Australian Capital Territory. In conclusion, I reiterate the point that I made at the outset, namely, that I reject the amendment as proposed by Senator Stone. It adds nothing to these Bills, except to shed light on the inadequacies and inconsistencies of the Opposition's economic policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88, the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 this evening I will direct my remarks towards the Government's record in relation to road funding, following which I will make some remarks about the inadequacies of the present system concerning the threshold level for provisional tax. However, before Senator McMullan leaves the chamber I want to refer to a couple of comments that he made on road funding and on other points raised by Senator Newman. He said that our side of politics wanted to spend more on this and more on that while at the same time wanting to have cuts in spending. He can say what he likes and I am sure that Senator Newman can reply when it comes to the medical and hospital aspects. Perhaps Senator McMullan is not well versed with the road funding system around Australia and the need for upkeep. Having lived in Canberra as long as he has, he probably has not seen country roads, country arterial roads or main highways for a year or two. I suggest to him that, if the Government does not want to spend more money on roads, it should not raise money in the name of roads. That is the point I make to him.
—You have obviously misunderstood. It is your economics.

—I have not misunderstood. I am telling the honourable senator that the money I am talking about has been raised in the name of roads, and it is on roads that we want at least most of it spent. It is no secret that this Government has held Commonwealth funding for roads to $1.245 billion for the last four years. In effect, that is a reduction in real terms of about 40 per cent. Moreover, there is a fear that the Government will incorporate the local government portion of that $1.245 billion into general purpose grants. Of course, country councils will then be at the mercy of each State government. If a State government is not sympathetic to country areas, those areas will feel it.

SPEECH.PARA: The case can arise where the State government will not allocate funds to areas where the roads are the worst. Such cases are certainly well known on my side of the continent, in Western Australia, where the Government has given funds to areas that will be more advantageous to it when it comes to the ballot box. I am sure that Senator Cook will agree with what I am about to say, as would Senator McKiernan if he were here. The State Government in Western Australia has pushed far too much money into the city of Bunbury. Of course, this is a delicate seat and with Bunbury 2000 the Government hopes to hold it at the next State election, and I think that there is a slim chance that it might do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Decentralisation.

—I thought that word had disappeared since the 1960s. I am glad that Senator Cook's side of politics has mentioned it. I thank him for doing so and hope that he will think of it in time to come. There are other examples of the point I am making besides Bunbury. Since the last State election, the money has started pouring into Geraldton. Many honourable senators know that Geraldton is held by the Minister for Local Government, Jeff Carr, who survived at the last election by 50 votes, so now the money is going there. A couple of years ago the America's Cup was held in Western Australia, and certainly it was a worthwhile event because of the great win of Alan Bond's group in America. However, once again money for roads was funnelled away into areas other than country areas where it was needed, in this case to Fremantle, again a seat held by the Labor Government in Western Australia. Someone as old as I can remember the Commonwealth Games in Perth in 1962, and again the money poured into the city rather than to the bush.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation I am describing has caused a lack of funds for roads in remote areas, areas such as that in which I live and areas for which I speak. As I told Senator McMullan earlier, the Federal Government is raising more and more funds in the name of roads. As I have said, if the Government does not want to spend money in certain areas, then for God's sake let it not raise money in the name of those areas. This vast sum of money is raised by a fuel tax. In fact, it has been known at certain times over the last few years that 68 per cent of what one pays at the bowser goes to the Federal Government.

To prove that I am not talking through the top of my hat when I speak about raising money in the name of roads and spending it on something else, I have a chart from the Bureau of Transport Economics. It goes back to 1926-27, but I will not bore honourable senators by quoting figures way back in those days. Most honourable senators in this place were not born then. However, from 1926-27 to 1930-31, 70 per cent of what was raised in fuel tax went back to the roads. But let us go to more modern times. That peak of 70 per cent was not reached again until the 1959-60 to 1963-64 period, when 70 per cent was again spent on roads. There will be no prize for guessing what government was in power at that time.

It is more interesting when we come to the period from 1980 onwards. In 1980-81, 77 per cent of what was raised in the name of roads was spent on roads, in 1981-82, 79 per cent was spent on roads, and in 1982-83, 71 per cent was spent on roads. I have underlined that year, because that is the year when our side of politics lost government, unfortunately for Australia. Immediately, in 1983-84 the amount spent on roads dropped to 63 per cent. In 1984-85, it was down to 60 per cent; in 1985-86, it was down to 46 per cent; and in 1986-87, it was down to 24 per cent, as estimated by the Bureau of Transport Economics. Those figures certainly speak for themselves. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate these tables in Hansard.
Leave granted.
