TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. These figures do not include other revenue raised in the name of roads such as drivers licence fees and vehicle registration fees, sales tax on motor vehicles, parts and tyres, and so the list goes on. If those amounts were also included, the figures would certainly look even more ridiculous.

SPEECH.PARA: Local government in remote areas suffers more because of small population and the long length of roads. The future of such areas is bleak if principles enunciated in the report of the Cameron Independent Committee of Inquiry into the Distribution of Federal Road Grants are put into effect fully. As an example, I will instance a small shire in Western Australia-Trayning. It is in the eastern or central wheat belt with a shire population of 600. Its area is 1,632 square kilometres and it has three towns. It is a sheep and wheat area, and it has 827 kilometres of roads. Its present grant is $165,000-odd. The proposed grant under the Cameron report guidelines for 1994-95 will be $50,400.

That shire has these options: First, it can increase the shire rates by 50 per cent. Secondly, it can reduce outside staff by three, but the result would be even worse roads. Thirdly, it can channel funds from community facilities. The result of taking the third option is well known-the shire loses people, with the result that there are fewer ratepayers from which to collect rates. The final option, which has been tried by a few shires around Western Australia and which amounts to suicide, is to fund road maintenance and even road building by borrowing. As I have said, that is certainly the way to go down the tube in the shire and to have the State Government appoint an administrator.

I have read the Cameron report pretty well, and I believe there are four indicators of the way in which the Federal Government would allocate road funding. Of those four, three are indicators on road usage-in other words, traffic volume. Only one indicator is related to the roads themselves, and that relates to restoration. If my mathematics are correct, the end result is that two-thirds of the allocation is made according to the volume of traffic, so in those areas where the traffic is not great, but roads are still needed, the position is disastrous. In submissions to the Cameron inquiry-in fact the Cameron report mentions this-the social factor was argued. I thought that the social factor might interest Senator Cook and Senator Haines, who are always talking about disadvantaged social groups. Of course, no notice was taken of the social factor in this case. That is the same in most isolated areas; the social factor is not considered. The social factor is considered only in cities such as Perth, Adelaide, Sydney and Melbourne, where there are far more votes-only about 4 per cent-for the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you support our Bill to take the freight component out of sales tax?

—When we have a good discussion about that matter I will think about it. Of course, the interest in remote areas by the Government and many other people-not only honourable senators opposite because it can be both sides of politics-varies in inverse proportion to the square of the distances out there. If one works that out, one will realise that the interest drops away very quickly.
—I am often in the Pilbara.

—Just like me, Senator Cook would fly to the Pilbara, and once there he would probably go straight to Trades Hall and not see many of the roads. As I said before, local roads are access roads and are used by everyone from tourists to mining companies and everything in between. For example, mining companies move into a small shire holus-bolus and wreck the roads not once a year but every week. Unfortunately, local councils do not have a large rating base to allow them to do anything about it-they have a minimal rating base-and they cannot raise enough money through internal rates within a shire to repair the roads. It is all right if it occurs in a wealthy city because the ratepayers can be slugged quite a lot, and because of the land values--
—Those city roads are not being chewed up like country roads.
—And they can afford to put in the better roads--
—I am on your side.
—That is good.
—Order! There are not too many interjections but I ask Senator Panizza to address his remarks through the Chair.

—I will adhere to your ruling, sir. Of course, the improvements, as Senator Haines just told us, to the highways and byways of main roads and bridges over the past six years have come about by way of the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program which the Fraser government had the good sense to introduce some six years ago. Of course the Government has even interfered with that by indexing the ABRD levy. It has held on to any excess over the 2 cent levy and put it into Consolidated Revenue, once again raising money in the name of road funding.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald headed `Roads funding slashed by 10 per cent'. So perhaps there is another 10 per cent that I did not know about, because I prepared my notes last night. The article states:

Commonwealth funding for roads has suffered its largest cut for six years, leading to the likely postponement of major road improvement projects, including on the Hume Highway. Cabinet's Expenditure Review Committee has reduced by more than $50m the $1.249 billion allocated for roads in last year's Budget.
The interesting part of the article shows that even the Federal Government is scared of the backlash that it will suffer on funding for country roads. The article also states:

The Herald learned of the cuts on the same day that the Labor Caucus debated a motion from Mr Ted Lindsay, who represents the Queensland country seat of Herbert, seeking to avoid further cuts. His motion said:

In order to arrest the rapid decline in the relationships between the Federal Government and local government and in order to maintain employment and to restore faith in marginal rural electorates so critical for the Government, the May economic statement should provide for the maintenance of road funding in real terms in 1988/89.

The debate lapsed when the Government Whip, Mr Barry Cunningham, called for a quorum and there were insufficient members to continue the meeting. This led to what MPs described as an unprintable exchange between an angry Mr Lindsay and Mr Cunningham.
That shows that those on the other side of politics are panicking about road funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are absolutely desperate and in full flight in panic!

—Perhaps, but I had better continue before the Acting Deputy President hauls me into line again. The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill will soon be introduced to standardise interstate road transport throughout Australia. Among other things it will mainly raise and standardise the speed limit for trucks on the open road to 100 kilometres per hour, which I welcome. It will also standardise the loading limit throughout Australia at 42.5 tonnes up to a six-wheel prime mover with a single drive and triaxle trailer. As I have said, I applaud this move but what effect will it have on our roads and bridges? For example, I attended the opening of World Expo 88 in Brisbane and I wondered whether some of the bridges I saw there would be able to stand up to this increased speed and loading limit along with a reduction in road funding. Certainly road funding is hitting the headlines and there is quite a lobby around Australia. In fact, there is a large advertisement in today's Sydney Morning Herald headed `Where are the roads our petrol taxes pay for?'. The advertisement points out that $5.2 billion-money that was raised in the name of roads-will disappear into the black hole of Consolidated Revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge the Government, as I told Senator McMullan earlier, to get its priorities right. If it raises money in the name of roads, that is where it should go, although I am not stupid enough to suggest that all of that money should go into roads because I suppose, whether or not we like it, every facet in the workings of Australia has to put some money into Consolidated Revenue. However, the Government must get its priorities right and stop spending money in stupid and illogical places. I will not go on to mention surfboards and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

—It has already been well debated in this place, so I will not worry about it. I refer quickly to provisional tax on the lower end of the taxation scale. From 1963 to 1972 the threshold on provisional tax was $416; in 1972 it was raised to $999, and it has remained there ever since. In 1972 the provisional tax threshold was 20 per cent of average weekly earnings on a per annum basis, while today it is only 4 per cent of average earnings. In 1972 the provisional tax threshold for the average pensioner was 91 per cent of base pension; it is now 16.4 per cent of base pension. In other words, in 1972 a pensioner could earn an extra 91 per cent above his pension before paying provisional tax; today he can earn only 16 per cent above the pension before he is netted by provisional tax. Of course today anyone trying to save need have only $6,000 in a building society or a traditional bank to be netted by provisional tax. I have a chart here showing those exact figures, with comparisons for the years from 1963-64 to 1987-88 between the provisional tax threshold and average weekly earnings, and between the provisional tax threshold and the annual age pension. I seek leave to have these tables incorporated in Hansard.
