TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Looking at what this Government has done since 1983, I and a lot of other people have found that it is a government of self-congratulation. But there is no way in the world that this Government can claim any credit for the points about which I have spoken this evening. It may be able to congratulate itself on some very minimal points in the past four years, but certainly not on these issues I have raised here.
—We have a lot to congratulate ourselves on.

—Just a minute. The honourable senator should wait until he hears the rest of my remarks. Even if the Government takes these points on board and does something, there will still be no need for self-congratulation. People will congratulate the Government when that is justified. That was evident in the last election results.
—We got back in; it was obviously justified.
—Yes, but judging by the results the Government certainly lost favour and, irrespective of what it does now, we will be over on the Government benches the next time round.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, let me return to the subject of roads. The roads of which I spoke at length earlier are in areas that could be classified as `disadvantaged'. There are a lot of disadvantaged areas and people in Australia and I have a feeling for them. Those very same areas that are disadvantaged-and even Senator Cook cannot deny this-are those where 10.5 per cent of the population produces 84 per cent of Australia's exports. Certainly, I would like the Government to look at this issue on that basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 and cognate Bills gives me an opportunity to speak about some reading that I have done today. The first article to which I wish to refer is on page 5 of today's Australian Financial Review. The headline reads `Opposition plans probe into unions'. There is an accompanying drawing of Senator Chaney with a pleasant smile on his face, but unfortunately some of the contents of the article about him are not quite so pleasant from the unions' point of view. I wish to indicate the concern that some people on this side of the House feel about the proposition that unions should be seen in a realistic fashion and should be appreciated for their contributions to society. I want to touch on that matter in this speech. Senator Chaney is reported as making some rather ungenerous comments-or perhaps the reporting was ungenerous. The article says that he plans to move amendments to the Industrial Relations Bill which will be brought before this House shortly. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The planned amendments deal with compliance and sanctions, strike pay, union membership, and provisions in the legislation which would override State legislation such as Queensland's secondary boycott laws.
The amendments would include the right of workers not to join a trade union and tough compliance provisions to enable the proposed Industrial Relations Commission to enforce its decision.
I think it is fair to say that the thrust of those sorts of comments indicates that Senator Chaney looks upon unions with a somewhat jaundiced eye.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a sad inability to learn from history.

—And a sad inability to learn from history, if I can adopt the words of Senator Cook. I note the presence of Senator Cook in the chamber. He is an example, Mr Acting Deputy President, and so are you, of the contribution that the union movement has made to this country not only in terms of the good that it has done to the economy-and I will come to that shortly-but also in terms of the contribution made to this House. Senator Cook is a former Vice-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and now a very eminent Minister who adorns this place. He is a product of the union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: My second piece of reading matter was the economic publication The Round-up for April 1988, published by the Treasury. Perhaps I am as economically illiterate as Senator Puplick. Our abilities lie in other areas, perhaps those areas more attached to the soul and the mind than the economy. However, with the help of Senator Maguire I have been able to understand some figures in The Round-up. When one looks at those figures in terms of what Senator Chaney has purportedly said about the unions, one gathers that the two issues do not lie very happily together. These figures are very interesting. On page 9 of this volume the Treasury deals with the decline in real average earnings over the years since 1981-82. I do not think it gives any joy to this Government to know that real wages have fallen, because it is the ambition of people on this side of the chamber to see that real wages rise ultimately with the prosperity of this country and that workers obtain the just rewards for the efforts they have made over the years. But the reality is that real average earnings have fallen since 1982-83 by a factor of 4.9 per cent.

The next interesting figure is to be found on page 63 of this book which talks about international economic activity and the real gross national product (GNP). Let us look at the increase in Australia's GNP over the period from 1985-86 to 1986-87. In 1985-86 the gross national product of Australia rose by 4.3 per cent compared with 3.1 per cent for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries as a whole. In 1986-87 our GNP rose by 2.7 per cent compared with an average in the OECD of 2.4 per cent. In each of the last two years our GNP has risen by a greater factor than the average for the OECD.

Page 68 of this volume shows the labour costs for each unit of production. It appears that those labour costs per unit of production have fallen considerably since the coalition was in power. Adding those three figures together, one has a fall in real earnings, an increase in gross national product, above the average of the OECD, and a fall in the unit labour costs. The last figure to which I wish to refer is that which deals with working days lost in the period from 1980-81 to 1986-87. The number of working days lost has fallen dramatically since this Government came to power. At the same time the real wages of workers have fallen. So there is a picture of a fall in real wages, an increase in gross national product which is above the OECD average, and a fall in the number of working days lost through industrial disputes. Those figures present a picture of the Australian worker shouldering a burden and doing so in a fashion which does him great credit.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you well know, the Australian work force is organised in a number of unions. The unions have taken part in this dramatic acceptance by the worker of falling standards, increased production and a lowering of days lost through industrial disputes. Yet the organisation of unions-each union forms the organisation-apparently is to be subjected, if the coalition parties ever come back to power, to oppression, to attack and, one might think, to a fairly protracted war. I cannot quite understand why Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, should take that attitude to unions, given the economic figures set out in The Round-up for April 1988, which show that the very organisations that he would attack are the organisations that have helped this country on the road to recovery. Australian workers have had to bear the burden of the dramatic fall in Australia's competitiveness in May 1984. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will know what that has meant. They have had problems with paying their mortgages and difficulties with sending their children to school and getting decent food on the table. They have had problems with being able to go out-for instance, to football matches-and with buying proper clothing. All those pressures have been placed on the ordinary family that we are dedicated to helping. Apparently, if the article that appeared in today's Australian Financial Review is accepted, those people will be oppressed further.

A person who is often overlooked in the happy record, I suggest, of industrial relations during the life of this Government is the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Ralph Willis. He was an architect of the accord that was struck between the Australian Labor Party and the unions in 1982-83. The accord, in its several forms, has proved a harsh instrument in the sense that it has seen deprivation of living standards and of the social wage. But, as a counter to that, it has also seen an increase in employment-an increase in participation rates in the Australian work force. It is very significant to note that, under this Government, participation in this country's labour force has reached 62 per cent. There has been an increase in the number of women employed. I will return to that a little later.

Mr Willis deserves praise for his efforts in this area. He has brought forward the Industrial Relations Bill. According to the article in today's newspaper, the Opposition will seek to amend that legislation in an attempt to make it even more harsh on the labour force. There is no doubt that the industrial relations system, through the courts, is particularly harsh on unions. They have no lawful right to strike. There is no industrial action which I can think of that cannot provoke action under either the criminal law or the civil law such as actions of intimidation and conspiracy or actions under sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act. The union movement has a very harsh series of sanctions hanging over it and that must not be forgotten. Apparently, an attempt will be made to increase even further the harshness of those sanctions. In any event, the Industrial Relations Bill brought forward by Mr Willis will be discussed in this place. It is the most far-reaching reform of the industrial relations law since the first Conciliation and Arbitration Bill was introduced into this Parliament in 1904.

In addition, Mr Willis will be continuing with the operations of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, which will adopt the working title of Worksafe. The Commission comprises 17 members under a full time Chairman and Chief Executive and has representatives from the ACTU and the Confederation of Australian Industry. It has seven representatives from each of the six States and the Northern Territory and representatives of the Federal Ministers responsible for industrial relations, health and the Australian Capital Territory. Mr Willis has moved forward on that very important initiative. Safety in the workplace is crucial to not only the well-being of workers, which is the first principle that must be adopted, but also the economy of Australia and the good conduct of industrial relations and the productivity that will be expected from it.

The workplace can be very dangerous. Although there have been vast improvements in the safety of the workplace, brought about by legislation and a greater consciousness over the years of the need for safety, there remains a great need for it to go forward even further on a national basis so that Australians, no matter where they go-there is no doubt that the Australian work force is a mobile one; it goes from State to State-can enjoy uniform safety standards and safety that is of the highest quality. That is another initiative that the Minister has undertaken. The other initiative undertaken is the plan to bring about affirmative action. That initiative has been put in place and is continuing to be a success. Former Senator Susan Ryan, who introduced the affirmative action legislation, deserves much praise in that respect.

Some concern is to be had by the ordinary people of Australia about the tax policy which the Liberals announced this month. When I say `ordinary' I mean ordinary in the sense of their being people who depend on wages to live and who try to make their place in the world on the basis of an economy which depends on a wage packet each week. Senator Maguire has already touched upon this in a much more learned fashion than I am able to do. But I think it is worth mentioning some things here again. The Liberals' taxation policy provides that there will be a two-rate income tax system, that there will be no broad based consumption tax but a reform and rationalisation of the existing indirect tax system. As Senator Maguire has indicated, there is some real concern about what in fact that means. What does a rationalisation of the existing indirect tax system mean? I suppose one way in which we might be able to obtain an answer to that is to look at what happened when Mr Howard was Treasurer immediately prior to the time this Government came into office in March 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at antique clocks.

—That is the point, we are referring to an antique clock. I think it is probably fortunate for Australia that what happened then can be regarded as an antique clock. I think we would be in a fairly disastrous state if that clock had continued to tick away and operate over the years since March 1983. I think Senator Parer will see what I mean if I illustrate my argument by using some figures that have been given to me by Senator Maguire. There were big rises in sales tax revenue in 1981 and 1982 under Senator Parer's beloved leader. I know that Senator Parer speaks most highly of him. But under Mr Howard all sales tax rates were lifted by 2 1/2 percentage points in both the 1981-82 and 1982-83 Budgets. So the old 2 1/2 per cent rate went up to 5 per cent in 1981 and then to 7 1/2 per cent. This happened in just two Budgets.

SPEECH.PARA: The rates of sales tax in respect of cars elucidate the point that I am making. The rates on cars started at 15 per cent, went up to 17 1/2 per cent and finished at 20 per cent. Of course, as a Victorian senator I am quite concerned about what might happen in the car industry if sales tax rates are increased. In the 1980-81 Budget $2,102m was raised by sales tax and in the 1982-83 Budget $3,490m was raised. So there was a 66 per cent rise in revenue from this source in two Budgets.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened since then?

—I am talking about what will happen if the antique clock that Senator Parer mentioned were somehow to operate in the modern era. I am talking about what is likely to happen. As I have said, Senator Maguire has already dealt with the reform and rationalisation of the existing indirect tax system which is contained in the summary of the Liberal tax policy dated May 1988. If we lift tax rates by 2 1/2 per cent one year and 2 1/2 per cent the next year, what will be taxed in this way? Senator Maguire said that there is only one area that can be taxed in this way and that is the necessities of life-food, clothing, rent and all of the other things that are absolutely essential for some sort of decent way of living in this economy. If the Opposition were elected to government Senator Chaney, as the Minister for Industrial Relations, would conduct a campaign against unions and those whom they seek to protect. As a result, living conditions would be lowered even further and the worker would take even less back.
—Do you think that is really what Senator Chaney wants to do here?

—Of course he would not want to do it. He is such a decent man that he would not want to act in that way. But the fact of the matter is that the sorts of statements he makes and the sorts of corners he seems to paint himself into mean just that. That is the problem. I think these sorts of things will be done in a sense by blundering into them rather than by doing them intentionally. But there is no other conclusion that we can draw if we have regard to the sorts of statements he makes in regard to the oppressive conduct he wants to perpetrate against workers and their organisations.
—Such as?

—I will tell the honourable senator what he wants to do. He wants to increase the tough compliance provisions. Senator Puplick may not have been in the chamber when I spoke before of the fact that there is no legal right--
—They were the ones introduced by Mr Willis last year, were they?

—The honourable senator should listen to this because what I am saying is very useful. There is no legal right for unions to take industrial action now. In that fairly oppressive circumstance, Senator Chaney wants to increase the penalties even further. He wants to stop unionists from trying to get their members together to form some sort of united front against powerful employers so that they are not isolated. I am sure that Senator Puplick does not want them sent back to the days of Mr Bounderby, Gradgrind, Hard Times and Dickens when unions did not exist. All of the great reforms that have taken place have been brought about by the unions.
—But you are going to insist that they have 3,000 members, aren't you?
—I want to do that because that is a rationalisation of the system.
—I thought you were opposed to rationalisation a few minutes ago.

—I have never been opposed to rationalisation. I am opposed to the oppression of the ordinary person who, as I said before, has to pay his mortgage, send his children to school, buy his children shoes and clothes and somehow try to give his wife a reasonable style of living. I am opposed to oppression that arises in the name of rationalisation. I am opposed to the situation that would arise if Senator Puplick's Party were returned to power and its proclaimed policies that have been coming forth recently were implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not, of course, attack the personnel in the Opposition. What I do is attack their policies because, unfortunately, they seem to lead to the conclusion that the people of Australia will be squeezed in both directions-that indirect taxes will go up and the necessities of life such as bread, milk and meat will become dearer and, at the same time, less will be paid to them in wages. I notice that there are several honourable senators who are listed to speak in the debate. If they can explain during their speeches how I happen to be wrong, I will certainly accept that correction. However, if we look at the tax policies pursued by the coalition when it was last in office and its industrial relations policy now, I do not see how one can, on that evidence, draw any conclusion other than the one that I have.

I conclude by saying this: Under this Government and the Minister for Industrial Relations there has been a great change in the attitudes adopted by various parties to the industrial life of this country. There has been a great change in the stance taken by employers, employees, their organisations and governments. A great change in the relations that over the years have been established has been produced under this Government. There is abroad in this community now a sense of cooperation, a sense of the various groups getting together to realise the great potential of this country. The Round-up for April 1988, which is published by the Treasury, shows quite clearly that this is the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of this debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 and cognate Bills, including the Supply Bills, which provide the Government with approval for expenditure supplementary to that approved in last year's Budget, it is appropriate to consider some aspects of the taxation and expenditure record of this Government together with some related matters. Reviewing the record of this Hawke Labor Government is made even more appropriate at this time, coming as it does shortly after the five-year mark of its time in office has been reached. Half a decade of hard labour has been suffered by the Australian people! The major cause of that suffering, which is reflected in these Bills, relates to the fact that this Hawke Labor Government is the biggest spending and biggest taxing government in Australia's history.

SPEECH.PARA: Only in the last two Budgets has any restraint at all been exercised in regard to expenditure-to some extent matching the restraint demonstrated by the Fraser Government in its whole period in office. However, the Hawke Labor Government in its first three Budgets made even the Whitlam Government look parsimonious, with a massive 43 per cent increase in spending. This profligate spending spree undid all the good work of the Fraser Government which had restored some semblance of responsibility and commonsense to government spending after the Whitlam disaster. Let no-one be fooled by the Labor myth machine peddling the line that this Government is one of restraint and discipline in relation to spending. The fact is that this Government in its period in office has increased spending by 60 per cent, way in front of inflation of about 40 per cent over the same period. This is a rate of increase nearly three times that of the Fraser Government in its period in office. What do we have to show for it? The normal aspirations of Australian life are slipping away from more and more Australians. Since 1983 an extra 700,000 Australians have fallen below the poverty line so that now 2.6 million people, including some 800,000 children, are living in poverty. This represents one in every eight households.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful.

—As Senator Puplick said, it is disgraceful. Sixty thousand people live on the verge of homelessness. Forty thousand people sleep in refuges. Since Labor came to power the number of people on public housing waiting lists has gone up by 50 per cent to 154,000. More than 600,000 people, including 140,000 teenagers, remain virtually permanently unemployed with the average duration of unemployment having increased to 52 weeks-a whole year-across the board and to 75 weeks for the older unemployed. Real household disposable income continues to fall. Therefore far from improving the welfare of the community, the only real justification for government spending, the Government's profligacy has sent living standards reeling backwards-unless, of course, one is among the coterie of Labor's rich mates who can do special deals with the Government.
—Gareth's friend Sir Peter.

—That is one of them, yes. With regard to taxation there is not even a latter day pretence at restraint. Federal Government tax revenue this financial year will approach $80 billion for the first time in Australia's history. It is up a massive 80 per cent from the $44 billion raised in the last Fraser Government Budget. This means that Federal taxation has increased at twice the rate of inflation under Labor and now gobbles up about 27 per cent of all the goods and services produced in Australia-our gross domestic product. It is no wonder Australian families are paying $43 a week more income tax now in real terms, that is, even after allowing for inflation, than when the Liberal and National parties left office. This Government stands condemned for such an appalling record of financial mismanagement. It is no wonder that in a debate of some 22 speakers on these Appropriation and Supply Bills we are hearing from only four Labor senators, plus the Minister who will be winding up. Who would want to defend such an appalling record?

SPEECH.PARA: Let me take issue with one of those earlier speakers, Labor Senator Childs, who criticised Senator Bishop, Senator Alston and me for incorporating in the report of Senate Estimates Committee A our reservations about various items of Government administration. He described us as engaging in a nitpicking exercise. That attitude and comment epitomise the sloppiness of this Labor Government. It is this very lack of attention to detail which has allowed the multiplicity of extravagances and waste so accurately identified and documented by the Opposition Waste Watch Committee. Senator Childs would do well to remember the old dictum: Look after the pennies and the pounds will look after themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever tried to make a non-haranguing speech?

—Senator Evans does not like this speech because he knows that every word of it is true. That is the thing that is embarrassing him. In developing this myth of restraint the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has of late-especially at the Premiers Conference last week-been admonishing the States for their profligate spending and excessive borrowings, yet the Budget figures demonstrate that growth in Federal spending has far outstripped that of the States. The marginally smaller percentage increases in Federal spending than those of the States in the last couple of years are in fact a further percentage increase on an already vastly expanded sum compared with the States. Since the last Fraser Government Budget this Labor Government has spent an additional $21.9 billion on its own direct outlays compared with the States' extra $15.2 billion spent on their own direct outlays. That represents an increase of 74 per cent for the Commonwealth as against 65 per cent for the States. Thus the rate of increase in spending has been one-seventh greater for the Commonwealth Government. Whereas the level of Commonwealth Government spending exceeded the levels of the States by 27 per cent at the end of the Fraser era, it now exceeds them by 34 per cent, a more than one-quarter increase. While neither the Commonwealth nor the States have practised adequate restraint and, instead, have contributed to higher levels of indebtedness and eventual lower living standards, let there be no doubt in any one's mind as to who is the main culprit.
—Why don't you restrain yourself and sit down?
—I can see that Senator Collins also is finding these facts embarrassing to the Government. The people of this country can thank the Treasurer for putting us in a debt hole--
—A dettol!
—from which we and even our yet to be born children may never emerge.
—That is a very sterile thing to say.

—It is all very well for the Federal Treasurer to impose heavier and heavier cuts on the States. I inform Senator Collins that perhaps it is this Government that needs to be sterilised and thrown out of office. The Treasurer has completely failed to set an adequate example in cutting Federal spending. This treatment of the States is both hypocritical and selective. What is this cosy deal about a swap of $25m special grant between South Australia and Western Australia one year to the next in order to help them out prior to their respective State elections? Also we see that because of the formula adjustments of the Commonwealth Grants Commission South Australia would have received a lower allocation this year. According to the rules, no State is to receive a nominal cut. This meant that South Australia got an extra $10m special grant and a very favourable hospital grant to top up its financial assistance grant. While this might please me as a South Australian representative one can understand the other States viewing it with a jaundiced eye.

SPEECH.PARA: This whole round of Premiers Conference revenue paybacks and Loan Council grants are all wrong and most people know it. It is fine to have a system which provides a degree of equality between the States. Of course, that is one of the main purposes for my being here in the Senate. However, it has to be recognised that in terms of finding a better system greater weighting needs to be put on efficiency. We have seen Victoria and New South Wales heavily advantaged by protection for manufacturing industry through tariffs and other forms of protection. The Grants Commission takes no account of this in its recommendations. Conversely, we see the resource-rich States penalised because their resources are factored into the grants they do not receive in order to top up the others. This is not to say that citizens of the less resource-rich States should be penalised. However, on the ground of efficiency, resources should, from an economically rational point of view, be directed to the areas which will show the most return.

The Grants Commission in its Report on General Revenue Relativities 1988 rejects the view that fiscal equalisation should play a positive role in enhancing efficiency. New South Wales and Victoria argued in their submissions to the Commission that the existing methodology of the Commission contributes to significant losses of efficiency in the Australian economy.

New South Wales said that the Commission's concern with efficiency had been restricted to technical or productive efficiency in the context of business undertakings, to the exclusion of economic or allocative efficiency. Its submission indicated five main areas of concern: first, the Commission's use of broad judgment in applying the factor assessment method; secondly, the impact of dispersion and isolation allowances on the spatial distribution of resources; thirdly, the impact of the scale factors on the efficient delivery of public services; fourthly, the arbitrary range of expenditure covered by the Commission's approach, in particular the exclusion of public sector capital expenditure; and, finally, the Commission's partial approach to revenue capacity assessment.

Victoria argued that, by equalising the fiscal capacities of governments rather than those of individuals, the Commission's methodology fails to achieve horizontal equity among individuals living in different States. Victoria also implied that, by contrast with the Grants Commission in its early years after 1933, the present Commission makes assessments which have the effect of compensating States for the poverty of their resources by discouraging population shifts from resource poor States to resource rich States, with detrimental consequences for Australia's economic prospects and growth. Like New South Wales, Victoria was mainly concerned with the consequences of expenditure equalisation, which it said drives a wedge between true economic costs and tax prices. Victoria especially objected to departures from equal per capita assessments in respect of scale, dispersion, isolation, urbanisation, and economic environment and physical environment factors, which the State referred to collectively as factors involving location specific expenditure equalisation.

Location specific equalisation was contrasted with what Victoria called individual specific expenditure equalisation, achieved under the Commission's methodology through the application of units of use, social composition and age and sex composition factors. Both New South Wales and Victoria argued that it is inappropriate for the Commission to make any allowance for location specific factors, claiming that to do so distorts the economic allocation of resources. While they were prepared to concede a case for individual specific equalisation, they were concerned about the extent to which the Commission found it necessary to exercise broad judgment in assessing factors for this purpose.

South Australia, my home State, submitted that it is inappropriate for the Commission to be concerned with making choices between the conflicting goals of fiscal equalisation and allocative efficiency, and concluded that it was unlikely that the effects of the former on the latter could ever be conclusively established. While it conceded that fiscal equalisation alters the distribution of resources in the public sector, it questioned the assumption that shifts in resources to high cost, low income areas from low cost, high income areas under conditions of fiscal equalisation necessarily result in a loss of efficiency. South Australia argued that the maximisation of production and allocative efficiency needs to be concerned with marginal product, whereas the redistributive effects of fiscal equalisation are concerned with average income and output levels. If high cost areas have significant developmental potential, it is inefficient not to promote their development by providing appropriate government services, according to the South Australian submission.

South Australia in any case doubted whether differences in the level and cost of State government services operate as a major incentive for the relocation of resources. It referred to an empirical study which suggested that the allocative effects of fiscal equalisation relate more to the pattern of development than to the overall level of production. It suggested that the issue of allocative efficiency is less relevant to Australian conditions than to those of other federations. This is because of the peculiarities of the Australian approach to fiscal equalisation, which achieves a comprehensive measure of equalisation while respecting States' rights to offer diversity rather than uniformity in government service provision. However, South Australia submitted that if the underlying concern about efficiency was with the level of support given to country areas, this enhanced South Australia's case for the exclusion of business undertakings from the Commission's assessment. While it may be currently difficult to calculate which States get the worst deal, I believe that a degree of allocative efficiency needs to be included in Grants Commission figuring. Unfortunately, the Grants Commission has totally rejected this proposition. However, if we are to avoid the constant bickering between the States and the Federal Government which was in evidence again last week, I believe that some account of fiscal allocative efficiency needs to be addressed.

I turn to another matter. This Labor Government has sought to balance the Federal ledger by walking down the privatisation path. It has identified a number of Government statutory authorities and commercial undertakings as possible privatisation targets, if its left wing can be persuaded to agree. But an examination of the Additional Estimates sought under Appropriation Bill (No. 3), which is one of the Bills we are debating tonight, reveals that the Government's initial sortie into privatisation should not give us any confidence about its capacity to lead Australia towards this worthwhile objective.

The largest increase sought by any one department for Additional Estimates is $250.6m for Defence. This increase reflects a whole range of requirements, including exchange rate variations, salary increases, defence housing and, most importantly, costs associated with the sale of Williamstown dockyard and the takeover arrangements for the Government Aircraft Factories. I am extremely alarmed about the costs associated with this sale and transfer, as I am sure most Australians would be. The failure of this Government to realise a reasonable return on the sale of Williamstown dockyard cuts to the heart of the Government's privatisation attempts. If this is the best it can do, no wonder Labor ranks are deserting the privatisation path.

The fact that the Government will not come clean with the real figures on this sale is a pretty clear indication of how badly it has been botched. A number of important questions require answers. How much are these assets worth? What were they sold or transferred for? What was the net return or loss on the sale and transfer? How much will the ships and planes now cost the Department of Defence? What have been the human costs, with thousands of people laid off? Will the reduced work force really result in improved productivity and efficiency and reduced costs to the taxpayer? Has the capacity of the dockyard and the Aircraft Factories been so much reduced that they will now not be capable of seeking extra commercial work in order to reduce their unit costs of production? I can guess the answers to these questions, but I do not know them for certain. I was not much enlightened through the Estimates committee questioning process.

I doubt whether the Government has any idea of the benefit cost of Government assets sales. The Department of Defence certainly does not, and I doubt whether it really cares. It was asked to proceed with these sales for politically expedient reasons. The Government did not get too much opposition because most people thought it would be a good idea, especially since our defence factories seem to be costing us so much money. But the sale and transfer process was never open for discussion. The unions were left to negotiate the best package possible for their members. There was not too much opposition from employees because the packages were so good that the workers were climbing over themselves to get the money. The fact that many of them will have spent this within a couple of years, will not have found a job in the meantime and will perhaps eventually be looking for the unemployment benefit did not enter anyone's head at the time. Thus there will be imputed long term costs. How much will they amount to?

As I said, there has not been much debate over this asset sale. There has been plenty of debate surrounding the proposed sale of Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank. In fact, the benefit cost of these sales appears to be far more clear cut than those surrounding defence assets. With the projected net cost to Government revenue entailed in retaining Qantas and Australian Airlines with a requirement to purchase more aircraft, the imperative to sell becomes all the greater. In these times of fiscal austerity, which we have been dragged into by this Government as a result of the high level of debt with which it has saddled us and future Australians, I fully support the proponents of Government assets sales. These sales, however, should take place where cases have been openly considered and where they will result in improved efficiency and productivity and, above all, a substantial return to revenue and thus a reduced requirement on taxpayers to fund past Government excesses.

A sizeable net return is apparently not the case with the sale of Williamstown dockyard. Although $100m was obtained, we are told in this Bill that a further $24.8m is required, mostly for redundancy payments for 1,000 employees. This is in addition to the sum of money spent on redundancy and retrenchment over the past several years, when the dockyard once employed nearly 2,000 workers. I understand that the Australian Taxation Office made different valuations for the dockyard depending on its purpose. Land value only would be close to $200m, but because the Government required that it be retained as a dockyard $100m was the most that could be expected. Again, this could have been substantially increased if some guarantee could have been given regarding contracts for the construction of the new surface combatant ships. But given the past record of the dockyard, no more than an implicit guarantee could be given, based on a hoped for improved industrial climate with the change of ownership.

The recent strikes at the dockyard do not augur well for the new owners. Many of these workers, replete with their redundancy payments and now re-employed by the new owners, are now going to extract every concession they can. If the Department of Defence does give the contract to Williamstown to build the next generation of surface combatant ships-and there is a very good chance that it will, despite excess shipbuilding capacity in Australia-what guarantee is there that once started the dockyard will not be just as unproductive and inefficient as it was in the past, with huge cost overruns to be borne by the taxpayer?

A similar situation is evident with the conversion of the Government Aircraft Factories to a Government-owned company called Aerospace Technologies of Australia. The dubious benefit that this will bestow appears to be costing, in terms of this Bill, an additional $78m. This is in addition to previously allocated expenditure. We find that a large proportion of this expenditure is for restructuring expenses, accountancy, consultancy and the like. But what guarantee do we have that this new structure is going to be any better than the last one, especially since it is still Government owned? Every time this organisation runs into trouble it will come running to the Government for more money. Anyway, it is bound to try to operate at least on a break-even basis so it will simply increase the cost of production to the Department of Defence to cover shortfalls or inefficiency, and the Department will be powerless to do anything about it. So much for this Government's effort at privatisation and rationalisation of its assets. The Defence Department is currently reviewing all of its facilities Australia-wide with a view to rationalisation. Given this present record, I suggest that a full open discussion on this program be undertaken.

The Government's examination of a graduate tax must be viewed with considerable alarm. It is not that the principle of user pays should be discredited, but who are the users and beneficiaries of this further education should be clearly defined. There is a case for students who will personally financially benefit substantially from certain courses of study, such as medicine and law, eventually paying for their education. However, it may not be appropriate for students of other courses such as science and engineering to pay for the high cost of their education. This is because in these latter professions, which are vital to the technological development of this country, there is not the remunerative benefit from studying these courses. A higher than average tax on graduates from these courses would serve as a positive disincentive to studying these vital disciplines.

But, as usual, this Government shows little or no foresight and has little consideration for the future of this country. It is all very well catering to the unions and considering what is best for them-many trades people receive salaries far in excess of tertiary qualified people. What is the incentive for further education? The fact that further educated people provide innovation and improved productivity in this country is lost on the many beneficiaries in the community at large. As with privatisation, the costs and benefits of the graduate tax proposal must be carefully examined. We can only hope it is not the thin end of the wedge of this Government adopting the disastrous union blueprint for this country outlined in Australia Reconstructed.

I have raised a number of matters tonight which indicate the way in which the Government is now poorly administering this country. There are matters of taxation and Government spending. As I said at the outset of my remarks, this Government is the highest taxing, highest spending government in Australia's history. Further matters relate to its botching of the privatisation issue. I have given the specific examples of Williamstown dockyard and the Government Aircraft Factories. Finally, of course, I have referred to the proposal by the Government to introduce a graduate tax. It is no wonder that in the opinion of the Australian community this Government is on the nose when these sorts of shortcomings in its administration are clearly evident. It is for that reason that the Opposition has foreshadowed an amendment to the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 3), which is one of the Bills being debated in this cognate debate. To the motion for the motion for the second reading, the Opposition will move as an amendment:
At the end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate notes:
(a) Australia's $86.77 billion net foreign debt at the end of December 1987 and its continuing balance of payments deficit on the current account which increased by $1,185 million during March 1988;
(b) the Government's inappropriate response, which has been to increase taxation revenue collections to the highest levels in post-war Australia; and
(c) the urgent need to reduce public sector outlays as the major element of a Government policy response to our current economic difficulties''.

I support that amendment, foreshadowed by Senator Stone in leading this debate for the Opposition. It spells out clearly the failings of this Government to provide effective economic management for this country, and for that reason it must be passed by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the address of Senator Chapman, which the Senate has just heard. In terms of the appropriations and responsibilities of Government, I want to address tonight Australia's estimated $11.5 billion current account deficit for this year. Last year's deficit was $13.4 billion and the previous year's deficit was $14.6 billion. Our accumulated foreign debt is now in the vicinity of $111.5 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week a visiting American observed that Australia was a big country that thinks small, and in my opinion that well describes Australia's place in the highly competitive but critically important world of international trade and our deplorable performance of recent years. On the basis of generous natural endowments in agriculture and minerals, this country was given a running start. We squandered our advantages and became insular, short-sighted and negative. We have been taught a trading lesson by nations with no natural advantages other than a recognition of the importance of trade and a determination to succeed. Countries such as Japan and in more recent times Taiwan and Korea are running huge trade surpluses.

If we boost our trade, everything will follow-the capacity of this country to meet reasonable defence needs, influence in foreign relations that arises from economic strength, and a capacity to meet national requirement in health, education and welfare. With our small population base we cannot provide for those things solely through the domestic economy. The requirement for governments to maintain standards for those for whom they are responsible in times of poor growth related to trading failure has led to huge borrowings and a downward spiral that will be difficult to get out of.

Servicing Australia's foreign debt will now cost governments this year $8.7 billion or, to put it in relative terms, more than three times the entire budget of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The theme of the comments I want to make tonight is what government can do to influence change. Although it tends to be the practice of government to pass the responsibility for our trading failure off onto individuals, I would argue that a great deal of responsibility falls upon government. It is government, through its wage policies, its taxation policies-particularly its indirect taxation policies-its protectionist policies such as, in our case, those involving coastal shipping, air transport, and tariffs on productive equipment, which affect the cost of our products and therefore our capacity to compete. It is government, through borrowing policies, that has the capacity to insulate the domestic economy for a while and protect the community from the pressures of international competition and thus, in turn, to influence people's attitudes.

It is government that regulates imports, through quotas and tariffs. In our instance, it is government that determines what can be exported and how much, such as in the case of uranium. In fact, in some instances it is government that can determine who can market a product, such as applies with wheat, and so on. It is governments that have the resources to positively influence trade, through their trade policies. In Australia we have the policies and practices of Austrade, our aid policies, and schemes such as the development import finance facility scheme, as well as other supports that can be given. There is support through research and development, through grants, and the upgrading of plant and equipment through accelerated depreciation.

What I am saying is that certainly the attitude of governments has led to our trade failure, and, therefore, individuals and governments have reinforced each other, with the view that there must be an easier way and, to put it in the terms of our American visitor, we have reinforced each other that we might in this country think small.

Our share in world trade has fallen, from 1.7 per cent in 1970 down to 1.3 per cent in 1987. I remind the Senate that we are now behind such countries as Brazil and India, and just in front of Spain and Mexico. In 1976 we accounted for 1.3 per cent of the value of world exports. By 1986, we had slipped to twentieth place in the world, with only 1 per cent of exports.

The first reason for our failure has been our over-reliance on commodities-approximately 60 per cent of our exports. We have provided the basic foodstock for the industrial development of Japan, Taiwan, Korea, and other countries, by which they have developed sophisticated, high value added export orientated manufacturing industries. But instead of Australia reinvesting profits and diversifying industry with research and development spending and export orientated service industries we have rather absorbed such profits in consumption and in maintaining a high standard of living.

I suggest that it was inevitable that the terms of trade would turn against us, as more Third World competitors came on line, as substitute materials developed for the natural resources that we were offering, as more efficient uses were found for energy, and so on. Therefore, although there has been an improvement from our point of view in very recent times, particularly as a result of gold and wool, our terms of trade are in fact still some many points worse than they were five years ago. So, it is something of a myth to suggest that our terms of trade have recovered to former positions. That has not occurred, and I suggest that they are unlikely to do so and that in the long term they are unlikely to sustain trade recovery.

It is noteworthy that of the 24 countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), four stand out for the severity of balance of payments swings: Australia, New Zealand, Ireland and Iceland-all, of course, dependent on the export of primary produce. That does not mean that we cannot do better in the commodity area, and we should be doing better as our economy diversifies into other areas. The cost of tariffs, high indirect taxes, expensive and often inefficient transport and high interest rates in this country have in fact cost us dearly in trade terms. This has been documented by such bodies as the National Farmers Federation. The conservative estimate of the cost to the Australian economy of such barriers is in the vicinity of $4 billion.

The Government has, to varying degrees, the capacity to influence all the matters that I have raised. While the highly publicised initiatives of the Government, such as the Cairns Group and its General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade initiatives might serve a useful role in opening up markets-and it has been said that if in fact we could totally open up the United States of America market we could gain the benefit of $1 billion-what I am saying is that if the Government simply puts its house in order at home the benefits in this sector alone could be increased by some $4 billion.

Even given such improvement, I would argue that diversification will be necessary. We will not be able to maintain our standard of living without a competitive manufacturing sector, competitive in exports and in import replacement. Some 75 per cent of our imports are manufactured goods. They are often highly value added manufactured goods, with almost half from Japan and the United States. On the other hand, 60 per cent of our exports comprise basic commodities. Only 20 per cent of our exports are in manufactured form, and often in a form of simple processed foodstuffs and simple metal forms.

It is worth noting how far we have fallen out of step with other OECD countries. The OECD average growth in manufacturing output over the past decade is 27 per cent; in the case of Japan, 50 per cent; the USA, 42 per cent; while in the case of Australia it is only 10 per cent. Further, we are not getting the capital investment to upgrade our manufacturing capacity that is necessary. We are not getting it because we are not offering the right environment to attract it. In the first six months of the year 1987-88, Japan's direct foreign investment in our region grew by 127 per cent, up to $US3.7 billion, going largely into manufacturing, with an emphasis on transportation and machinery. But that investment was not attracted to Australia; rather, it was attracted to the newly industrialised countries, which will provide the next level of competition for our manufacturers.

Japanese money coming to Australia was mainly concentrated in areas of property and tourism-in other words, an investment in our lifestyle, often for Japanese visitors. It is of some value, I concede, but not in building a powerful industrial and post-industrial economy in our country. As I have said, we do not attract investment for that purpose because we do not offer the right environment. Our company tax is too high. One has only to consider our competitors in the region: for example, Hong Kong, with a company tax of 17.5 per cent, and Singapore, with a maximum company tax of 40 per cent, in comparison with our flat corporate tax rate of 49 per cent.

Further, transport costs in Australia are too great, as all senators in this chamber would know. Regrettably, our work force is unreliable, and although there have been improvements in some areas I remind the Senate that in 1987 there were 250 industrial disputes on the waterfront, involving stoppages affecting 360 ships. When one travels to Japan and seeks investment, they complain of our industrial record on the waterfront and those figures in fact prove their case to be true. Lastly, of course, they encounter within this country inefficient work practices.

Sydney port handles 17,000 tonnes of cargo per employee as compared with the United States figure of 80,000 tonnes and the Canadian figure of 120,000 tonnes. In considering the comparative numbers of containers handled, one notes that, for every 100 containers handled in a given time in Australia, New Zealand handles 138, the United Kingdom 141, northern Europe 214, North America 250 and Japan 312. Therefore we do not offer the environment that will attract that investment in our manufacturing sector. The point that I particularly wish to stress again is that it is within the capacity of Government to influence nearly all of those matters.

If we are to maintain high wage levels in this country, which of course we wish to do, then we must offer high productivity growth, greater productivity, more ingenuity, better quality and competitive price. There is no doubt that in the manufacturing sector the rewards are there for the taking. If one looks simply, for example, at the market available in the area of processed foodstuffs in Japan, it is enormous. To take another simple example, if one looks at the price of one tonne of aluminium ingot it will be found to be 20 times higher than that of four tonnes of bauxite from which it originated. That is a simple demonstration of the value of manufacturing to this country which for too long has been overlooked.

The third important sector to be considered is that of services-our capacity to sell transportation, communications, finance, health care, education, tourism, consultancy and entertainment activities, currently amounting to about 17 per cent of our exports. The services industry within Australia is growing, but in exports it has remained largely stationary. We come in at about twentieth in the world scene with only one per cent of the world service industry exports. There is great scope within this area, and it is helpful that the terms of trade for services have held up so much better than those for goods.

Let us consider one example of the room we have in which to improve. I take Singapore, with only 2,500,000 people, as a comparison. Singapore decided in the early 1970s to step up its services activity and it now ranks twelfth in the world, compared with our twentieth, even though it has a much smaller population-because it chose a field and was determined to succeed. That example shows what can be done. Again, so much is in the hands of government. In the area of communications, if we consider organisations such as Telecom Australia, Aussat Pty Ltd and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission we realise that so much is controlled by government, and these are simply not export oriented bodies.

Education is making positive strides forward. Last year 12,000 overseas students studied in Australia. This year we will get $80m to $100m from full fee paying students, and that is commendable. However, again government enterprises have been slow to adapt to this opportunity. The private sector is showing more initiative, particularly if one considers the record in Western Australia and what is clearly to come in Queensland. The market is enormous. Just consider the 80,000 Japanese who travel abroad each year to engage in English studies, usually short courses of four to six weeks. Most go to the United States; only 3 per cent come to Australia. What an opportunity abounds in that simple example for further improvement in providing services to our overall advantage.

If we consider the area of consultancy, our record of taking up consultancies from the Asian Development Bank, the World Bank and other such international bodies has not been good. Again, I regret to say that the Government has not been giving much of a lead. The decision of this Government to withdraw from the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation-which provides industrial assistance to developing countries-for a saving of $2m is short-sighted. The consultancies we will lose from that short-sighted decision will far exceed the benefits that accrue from it.

Similarly, the intended withdrawal of the Government from another United Nations body-the International Fund for Agricultural Development-will lose us major agricultural consultancies throughout the world. That is totally a short-sighted attitude. Last September, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), pursuant to outdated policies in relation to trade with Taiwan, is reported to have personally blocked a $2.5 billion contract won by the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation-which I remind honourable senators is a government authority running at a loss-to build a dam and hydro-electricity plant in Taiwan. So the Government is simply not giving the lead.

I will consider briefly the other example in the services field-tourism. I readily concede that tourism in Australia has vastly improved, but it is not helped by the outdated entry facilities in Sydney-and that is in the Government's hands-entry and departure taxes that the Government imposes, industrial disruption that tourists find in this country, and the high internal costs of air fares. All those matters are related to Government policies or are within the Government's capacity to rectify at least partly.

I bring home much of our trade failure to the hands of the Government. However, I would not want it thought that I am not prepared to give credit where credit is due. The Opposition has said that deregulation of the financial sector and the floating of the Australian dollar-both initiatives of this Government-were courageous steps in forcing Australia into the wider competitive world. What has happened might be difficult in the short term but it will be in our best interests in the longer term. In so many instances, the Government remains blinkered and is frustrating and hindering the readjustment so urgently required by this country.

Fancy not allowing direct flights from South Korea, our fifth largest trade partner, and Taiwan, our seventh largest trade partner-but they are policies of the Government. Moreover, fancy having one quasi-governmental trade representative in Taiwan when the United States of America and our other competitor countries have powerful trade offices. Someone should tell this Government that things have changed. In fact, last year the People's Republic of China and Taiwan had trade of about $US1.5 billion. Things have changed a great deal. Other countries are seizing the opportunity in this area. Taiwan's trade with Canada last year rose by 30 per cent and its trade with West Germany by 32 per cent, while Australia labours under outdated Government policy and is not taking advantage of these opportunities.

How could this Australian Government downgrade the Australia-Japan Foundation, moving it from Sydney to an office within the department in Canberra where it becomes lost, and reducing its staff and the status of its head, all at a saving of just $67,000, yet our trade with Japan is $17 billion a year? What is necessary more than anything else for our trade with Japan to improve is a better understanding of Japan, particularly through cultural and other means of producing such an understanding. The Australia-Japan Foundation was giving us that opportunity. The initiative of this Government in response to that was simply to downgrade it, and that is, at the very least, short-sighted.

Where are the benefits of the amalgamation of the Department of Trade and the Department of Foreign Affairs which were promised by this Government and which by now should be obvious? All I can find is a highly publicised row over the future of the previous Special Trade Representative for North Asia, Mr Barratt, who now seems to be in limbo because he was apparently too aggressive in his work. Heads of branches that existed in the old Department of Trade in such areas as agriculture, services, and other commodities, instead of being brought into the new Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to give it a sharper cutting edge have been dispersed within other departments, such as the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Department of Resources, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, and so forth. In those circumstances, what was there to be gained from amalgamating these departments, presumably to improve trade policy, if these men and women at the fine cutting edge were in fact not brought in within the amalgamated department? This has separated trade policy from trade marketing or, in other words, Austrade, and created a bridge that simply should not exist.

Why can the Government not recognise that we will trade better with Asia, the region of greatest growth in the world, when we better understand Asian people and are better able to speak their language? Despite all the rhetoric of this Government, at present less than 2 per cent of Australian students of all levels study Asian languages-again, something which is within the capacity of the Government to influence. I stress that. Why does the Government inhibit exports by charging and seeking to charge new imposts such as those under the Export Inspection Charges Collection Bill which passed into law in April this year, or impose a levy on exports such as uranium through the work of the Office of the Supervising Scientist whose services are so costly because he and his staff are based in Sydney and carry out inspection work in the Northern Territory? Why have policy decisions on defence exports been tied up in Cabinet since February this year? The defence industry throughout the world is worth $1,000 billion yet this Government is not prepared to face up to the opportunities it presents to Australia. One could go on, but it is a frustrating story.

It must be conceded that Australian businessmen seem to need a lot of educating and encouragement, so it is not solely up to the Government. One can recall the much publicised example, I think it was late last year, when the Austrade office in Japan sent out letters to 65 Australian companies seeking expressions of interest in contracts worth $1 billion. I regret to say that only a handful replied to the letters of indication sent out by Austrade. A more recent example can be found in the office of the United Nations in Sydney, which is one of the four major procurement offices of the UN in the world. Last year it sent out letters to Australian companies inviting tenders for $50m worth of contracts. The office hardly received a reply and in the end only $3.2m of that $50m opportunity was taken up by Australian businesses.

There is no doubt that we need to further educate our businessmen and businesswomen about these opportunities. I return to the principle that so much of this falls to the Government because it is the Government that sets the economic parameters. It is the Government, if it has the resolve, which can guide Australia to be not only an efficient producer of primary products but also a nation with a thriving industrial base and a skilled and outward looking services sector. That will determine the economic future of this country, but I regret to say that, with very few exceptions, this Government has failed to show the necessary leadership in this particularly critical area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time remaining to me tonight I wish to speak to the Appropriation Bills and I will begin by referring to the opening of the new Brisbane Airport. I mention this because, at around $600m in today's terms, it is now a very big investment for this country. Because of the hatred of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) for this project the nation is not getting the benefit from the investment that it has made and paid for. I will talk about four aspects very briefly: the history of the airport; why a new airport was required in Brisbane; the problems at the present time; and what needs to be done in relation to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Brisbane Airport began at Eagle Farm as a boggy dairy farm in 1922 when Captain Jack Tracey first used it. In 1926 the Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Services set up the Brisbane flying school there. On 6 June 1928 it was the terminating point for Kingsford Smith in the Southern Cross on his first Pacific crossing from Oakland in California. In January 1930 it was also the site of the first Sydney to Brisbane air service for the original Australian National Airways, which was the company founded by Kingsford Smith and Charles Ulm. It eventually went broke and was succeeded by the Holyman company some years later. The airport was closed in 1931 because of its boggy nature and it was transferred to Archerfield. In 1942 the Americans created a military airfield there which became the Eagle Farm field that was used as a civil airfield up until March this year.

It was quite apparent to everyone in the 1960s that the old airport was inadequate and after due consideration the then Liberal Government decided in the early 1970s to build a new airfield. A prime mover behind this was the late Hon. Kevin Cairns. He fought endlessly for the development of the new airport. He was supported by Donald Cameron, David Jull and by Liberal senators of the time. I took a major part in the proposal both within the State Liberal Party organisation and from the time I entered Parliament. In 1972 the Liberal Government made a commitment to spend $1m in 1973-74, $13m in 1974-75 and $18m in 1975-76 to develop the new airport. I will return to the outcome of that proposal later.

A new airport was necessary in Brisbane simply because the existing airport had been overtaken by the growth in traffic. The main runway was 04/22, and the 22 degrees heading pointed straight for the central business district-right at the heart of the downtown area. That had inherent safety problems and imposed height limitations on the development of the central business district. Most importantly, there were great social problems associated with the old Brisbane Airport. It was surrounded by high density old residential areas and the social problems associated with operating a modern airport with heavy jet traffic created considerable suburban problems which led to the introduction of a curfew. That imposed another burden on the air fare structures for Australian travellers. It was quite impossible to expand the old airport because the runways were too short. As a consequence, the design parameters for the new airport envisaged something that would be curfew free and would be far more acceptable socially because the number of houses affected by noise would be reduced by quite a large magnitude. The airfield to be provided was to be operationally adequate and would have a runway length able to allow a Boeing 747 aircraft to operate at maximum all up weight.

I will deal briefly with the question of the cost of curfews because it is a cost that is borne by everyone in Australia. The fact that we have airport curfews in Sydney and Adelaide, and formerly in Brisbane, means that the great trunk routes of Australia cannot be operated on a 24-hour basis. That means that airlines cannot use highly expensive equipment on a 24-hour basis. Airlines cannot amortise that equipment by using it 24 hours a day in the finite life the aircraft have before they are superseded by more efficient equipment. The fact that most Australian airports cannot be used between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. means that for 7 hours out of 24 hours-nearly a third of a day-that equipment cannot be used. Off-peak air fares cannot apply between Sydney and Adelaide because those airports are closed during the curfew-and that was formerly the case out of Brisbane-and aircraft cannot operate freight runs late at night. For a small country like Australia it is economically efficient to use aircraft through the daylight hours to carry passengers when there is that demand and then at night remove the seats and use them to transport freight. That makes it unnecessary for airlines to acquire separate freight aircraft, as Ansett Airlines of Australia has been forced to do. Its new freight aircraft will commence operations next year.

Another important economic constraint is that aircraft cannot be positioned. An aircraft may land at an airfield with an 11 p.m. curfew. The airline may wish to start it 600 miles away at 6 a.m. the next day but cannot position the aircraft through the night. The on-costs associated with this for Australian air fares are highly significant, and Australian air fares, despite what the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) said earlier today, are expensive compared with many other countries. The noise problem associated with the old Brisbane airport was very significant and it applied to both sides of the river because of the high density housing.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 16 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In regard to the voucher system available to pensioners in obtaining a discount on their Telecom accounts, what advantage or benefits does this system provide to Telecom.
(2) What is the extent of the cost savings, if any, involved with this scheme.
(3) Does the cost to the Department of Social Security of mailing out these vouchers outweigh the savings to Telecom by not having to print the pensioner discount on Telecom accounts.
(4) Is this voucher system under review at the present time, or is a review planned in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telecom Australia, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Pensioner Telephone Concession Voucher Scheme provides benefits to Telecom through greater efficiency in administration. Benefits to Telecom include:
Telecom's reimbursement claims on DSS are simplified.
A reduced number of billing enquiries are received by Telecom from pensioners in relation to the telephone concession.
Telecom no longer is required to process concession applications and cancellations.
Concession recipients do not need to be recorded as such within Telecom's billing system.

(2) Telecom is currently able to achieve savings of about $860,000 per annum in its unrecovered administrative costs of operating this scheme on behalf of the Department of Social Security, as compared with the costs of operating the previous concession scheme.
(3) and (4) No.
